    The commission shall meet regularly at the City Hall on the first and third Monday of each month at the hour of five-thirty p.m. unless some other time and place shall be specifically fixed by the commission. 
(Ord. 877 (part), 2008: Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.120 - Special meetings. 
    Special meetings may be called at any time by the president, or any two commissioners to consider matters mentioned in the call of such meetings. Written notice of any special meeting shall be given to each commissioner, and the official newspaper of the city, at least twenty-four hours before the time of the meeting, unless the special meeting is declared at any other public meeting. 
(Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.130 - Public attendance-Journal of proceedings. 
    All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public, and a journal of its proceedings shall be kept. 
(Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.140 - Quorum. 
    A majority of the commissioners shall constitute a quorum to do business but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time. The commission may compel the attendance of absentees under such penalties as may be prescribed by ordinance, and may employ the police for that purpose. 
(Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.150 - Rescinding votes. 
    No vote of the commission shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting unless there is present at such special meeting as large a number of commissioners as were present when such vote was taken. 
(Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.160 - Rules for meetings. 
    Rules for the parliamentary government of the commission shall be governed by "Roberts Rules of Order." 
(Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.170 - Order of business. 
    The order of business shall be as follows: 
A.  Minutes of previous meetings; 
B.  Bids and/or hearings; 
C.  Visitors or delegations; 
D.  Commission portfolios; 
E.  Old business; 
F.  New business; 
G.  Bills; 
H.  Adjournment. 
(Ord. 861, 2003: Ord. 739 (part), 1989) 
2.08.180 - Salaries of city commissioners. 
    The salaries of the city commissioners shall be fixed by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 748 (part), 1990) 
Chapter 2.10 - MUNICIPAL JUDGE 
Sections: 

2.10.010 - Generally. 
    There shall be elected each four years a municipal judge who shall hold office until a successor is elected and qualified. The municipal judge shall perform all the duties prescribed by law and the ordinances of the city, and shall receive an annual salary as full compensation for all services rendered. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.020 - Report to board of city commissioners. 
    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to make a full report, under oath, of all proceedings in the actions or matters in which the city is a party, or interested therein, to the governing body of the city, at the close of each month. Until such report has been filed with the city auditor, no salary shall be paid the judge for such work. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.030 - Contents of report. 
    The report described in Section 2.10.020 shall contain the names of the parties to such actions or proceedings, a statement of all orders made whether the defendants be committed, fined or released from custody, the judgement, the extent thereof, the costs, the amount of costs and fine paid, if any, with the disposition thereof, together with an itemized account of any fees of all officers and witnesses and the names of each, the name of each person making the complaint, and the nature and date thereof. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.040 - Receipt to accompany report. 
    The report will be accompanied by a duplicate receipt or receipts of the city auditor for the total amount of the fees and money so collected on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.050 - Court hours. 
    The municipal judge shall be in attendance at municipal court for the transaction of business, and shall devote the time necessary to handle and dispose of the business. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.060 - Duties. 
    Additional duties of the municipal judge shall be as provided by the provisions of Chapter 40-18 of the North Dakota Century Code and all amendments thereto. 
(Ord. 746 (part), 1990) 
2.10.070 - Distribution of fees for domestic violence cases. 
A.  The municipal judge is authorized to assess a fee, not to exceed twenty-five dollars as part of a sentence imposed on a defendant who pleads guilty or is convicted of a criminal offense for which the maximum penalty that may be imposed by the law for the offense includes imprisonment. 
B.  The fee assessed is in addition to any fine, penalty, costs, or administrative fee prescribed by law. The municipal judge may assess the fee when sentence is imposed or when sentence is suspended or imposition of sentence is deferred, unless the defendant is indigent and unable to pay the fee. 
C.  All fees paid to the city must be deposited monthly in the city treasury for allocation by the governing body of the city to one or more of the following programs as determined by the governing body: 
1.  A victim/witness assistance program of which the primary function is to provide direct services to victims of and witnesses to crime; 
2.  A private, nonprofit domestic violence or sexual assault program. 
(Ord. 773, 1992) 
Chapter 2.12 - APPOINTIVE OFFICERS* 
Sections: 

2.12.010 - Appointive officers-Right to dispense with offices. 
A.  At the first meeting after the qualification of its members, or as soon thereafter as possible, the board of city commissioners shall appoint the following officers: 
1.  City attorney; 
2.  City auditor; 
3.  City assessor; 
4.  Chief of police; 
5.  City engineer; 
6.  Fire chief. 
B.  In addition, the governing body may appoint such other officers it may deem necessary, or may, by a majority vote, dispense with any appointive office, and provide that the duties thereof shall be performed by other officers or boards, by the board of city commissioners, or by a committee or committees thereof. 
(Ord. 878 (part), 2008: Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.020 - Term of appointive officers. 
    The term of all appointive officers shall begin on July 1st, after the regular election of city commissioners and shall continue for a term of two years until their successors have been appointed and qualified. Any person appointed to fill a vacancy shall hold the office for the unexpired term unless appointed as an "acting" officer. An acting officer shall serve at the pleasure of the governing body. Before entering upon the duties of their office, appointed officers shall take oath and give the bond required by law. 
(Ord. 878 (part), 2008: Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.030 - Postponement of appointments. 
    The commission may, upon the concurrence of two-thirds of the commissioners present, postpone action on such appointments, or any of them, to a special session of the commission to be held not later than one week from the date of such adjournment. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.040 - Appointive officers-Removal upon hearing-Suspension of appointment-Removal of temporary officer. 
    Any person appointed to any office may be removed by a majority vote of all the members of the board of city commissioners, but no officer shall be removed except for cause and unless charges are preferred, and the person is accorded an opportunity to be heard. Within ten days after charges are filed against any such person in the office of the city auditor, the board shall proceed to hear and determine the case upon its merits. The president of the board of city commissioners, or the board, by a majority vote of its members, may suspend any officer against whom charges have been preferred until the disposition of the charges. The president may appoint a person to fill any vacancy temporarily until charges against the incumbent of such office have been disposed of. Any person appointed by the president without confirmation may be removed when the president deems it is for the best interests of the city. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.050 - General duties of city attorney. 
    The city attorney shall conduct all the law business of the city and of the departments thereof, and all law business in which the city shall be interested; and shall furnish written opinions when requested by the city commission, or any other department. It shall also be the city attorney's duty to draft all ordinances, bonds, contracts, leases, conveyances and such other instruments as may be required by the officers of the city; to examine and inspect tax and assessment rolls and all other proceedings in reference to the levying and collection of taxes and to perform each and every and all duties and things prescribed to do by statutes of the state, or by an ordinance, resolution or proper instruction of the city commission. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.060 - General duties of other appointive officers. 
    All other appointive officers shall perform such duties as directed by the board of city commissioners, these ordinances, or directed or authorized by the laws of the state of North Dakota. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.070 - Bonds of municipal officers and employees. 
A.  The following officers and employees of the city shall be bonded in the sums as hereinafter set forth: 
1.  President of the city commission; 
2.  City auditor-finance officer; 
3.  City commissioners; 
4.  Deputy city auditor; 
5.  Municipal judge; 
6.  Police officers; 
7.  City assessor; 
8.  City engineer. 
B.  Said officers or employees shall be bonded from the State Bonding Fund in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 26-23 of the North Dakota Century Code and in such amounts as are set by the laws of the state of North Dakota, the board of city commissioners, or the commissioner of insurance. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.080 - Oaths of municipal officers. 
    Every person appointed to any municipal office, before entering upon the discharge of the duties thereof, shall take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed for civil officers and, except in the case of the city auditor, shall file the same with the city auditor within ten days after notice of election or appointment has been given. The oath of the city auditor shall be filed in the office of the county auditor. In addition, each commissioner shall take an oath that they are not under any direct or indirect obligation to appoint or elect any persons to the office of policeman, fireman, or any other office, position or appointment under the city government. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
2.12.090 - Salaries of city officials and appointive officers. 
    Salaries of city officials and appointive officers, except as otherwise provided by law, shall be in such sums and amounts as may be, by resolution of the governing body, fixed from time to time. 
(Ord. 747 (part), 1990) 
Chapter 2.16 - POLICE DEPARTMENT* 
Sections: 

2.16.010 - Members. 
    The police department shall consist of the chief of police and as many policemen, policewomen, patrolmen and officers as may be authorized by the governing body. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.020 - Additional officers-Emergency. 
    In case of riot or unusual or general disturbances of the peace, the chief of police shall have the power to appoint such other and additional policemen and policewomen as he may deem necessary for the preservation of the public peace. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.030 - Duties of chief. 
    The chief of police shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or by the governing body. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of its functions, and all persons who are members of the police department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. The chief of police shall have the authority to administer oaths to police officers under his supervision. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.040 - Rules and regulations. 
    The chief of the police department may make or prescribe such rules and regulations as he shall deem advisable; such rules, when approved by the governing body, shall be binding on such members. Such rules and regulations may cover, besides the conduct of the members, uniforms and equipment to be worn or carried, hours of service, vacations and all other similar matters necessary or desirable for the better efficiency of the department. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.050 - Duties of police-Generally. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the police department, and each and every member of the police force, to notice and diligently inquire into and report to the chief of police all violations of the city ordinances, violations of the criminal laws of the state and breaches of peace, and to make complaint against the person or persons guilty thereof, and to attend punctually on all trials of offenses in regard to which complaint has been made by any policeman. 
B.  Within the city limits and for a distance of one and one-half miles in all directions outside the city limits, the police officers shall perform the duties and exercise the powers of peace officers as defined and prescribed by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.060 - Duties of police-Hot pursuit-Defined. 
    A police officer in hot pursuit may continue beyond the one and one-half mile limit to make an arrest, in obedience to a warrant or without a warrant under the conditions of Section 25-06-15 of the North Dakota Century Code, whenever obtaining the aid of peace officers having jurisdiction beyond that limit, would cause a delay permitting escape. As used in this subsection, "hot pursuit" means the immediate pursuit of a person who is endeavoring to avoid arrest. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.070 - Duties of police-Service of process. 
    Police officers shall serve and execute any warrant, writ, process, order and notice issued to them by a municipal judge within the city in which the city is a party or interested beneficially. The police, within the limits prescribed in this section, may serve and execute all writs and process issued by justices in civil actions. In addition to the duties set out in this section, the police shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by chief of police and governing body. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.080 - Special police. 
    At the request of any corporation, firm or person, the chief of police may appoint one or more special policemen or policewomen to duty for such corporation, firm or person which special policemen or policewomen shall have all the authority now, or which may be hereafter conferred by law upon policemen, and may make arrangements that such special policemen or policewomen shall be paid by the corporation, firm or person requesting the same, and covered by their Workmens Compensation coverage in which case such special police shall receive no compensation from the city and the city shall not be responsible for the negligent or unauthorized acts, this being the responsibility of the firm, person or corporation requesting their appointment. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.090 - Money or property of arrested persons. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department, and of each and every member of the police force, to safely keep all moneys or property which may be found on the person, in possession of, or claimed by, any person arrested for crime, and pay or deliver over the same by the order of the municipal judge, and forthwith after taking the same, to report in writing the kind and amount thereof, to the municipal judge. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.100 - Arrested persons. 
    Any police officer after making any arrest, with or without a warrant, for any violation of city ordinances, shall take the person or persons so arrested, without any unreasonable delay, before the municipal judge, to be dealt with according to law and the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.110 - Stolen, abandoned, lost property. 
    The chief of police shall have the custody of all lost, stolen or abandoned property recovered in the city and shall make a report concerning such property. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.120 - Traffic administration. 
    The police department shall have such duties concerning enforcement, investigation, record keeping and other matters concerning traffic administration as are more fully set forth in ordinances. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.130 - Witness fees and mileage of municipal police officers. 
    Police officers of the city shall be entitled to be paid the witness fees and mileage expenses allowed by law for other witnesses while off duty when such officers are subpoenaed to testify in actions involving the city. The police officers shall submit vouchers for the above payment in accordance with department policies. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.140 - False alarms-Interference. 
    No person shall give or cause to be given, or make, or place or cause to be given any false report, call or communication of any kind to the police, or any false police alarms with intent to deceive; or tamper with or set off any police alarm or signal box with like intent; or tamper, meddle, or interfere with any such police alarm box, or intentionally cut, break, deface or remove any such box, or any of the wires or supports thereof, connected with the police alarm system; or intentionally interfere with or injure any property of any kind belonging to or used by the police department; or hinder or delay any apparatus or equipment or vehicle belonging to the police department. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
2.16.150 - Right-of-way. 
    Any motor vehicle or motorcycle of the police department shall, when going to or returning on business of the department, have the right-of-way upon giving an audible signal by bell, siren, exhaust whistle or red flashing light. The driver of any other vehicle shall drive to the nearest right-hand curb or edge of the road, stop and remain until the police vehicle shall have passed. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1989) 
Chapter 2.17 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.17.010 - Appointment of members. 
A.  The city commissioners, when found to be necessary, shall appoint three reputable persons as members of a commission which shall be known as the special assessment commission. The terms of office for said members shall be as follows: 
1.  One member shall hold office until the first meeting of the governing body in April in the first odd-numbered year following the appointment; 
2.  One member shall hold office until the first meeting of the governing body in April in the second odd-numbered year following the appointment; 
3.  One member shall hold office until the first meeting of the governing body in April in the third odd-numbered year following the appointment. 
B.  At the first meeting of the governing body in April of each odd-numbered year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the city commission shall appoint a member of such commission. After the members of the initial special assessment commission have been appointed as provided in this chapter, each appointment thereafter shall be made for a term of six years. 
C.  In addition to appointing the members of the special assessment commission, the governing body, at the first meeting in April of each odd-numbered year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, will also name an alternate member to the special assessment commission. This alternate member shall serve until the next odd-numbered year. The alternate member shall serve as an alternate no more than six years. The alternate member shall act as a member of the special assessment commission in the absence of any member of the special assessment commission. This will include the alternate member having a vote as a member of the special assessment commission when the alternate does act as a member of the special assessment commission in the absence of a member of the special assessment commission. 
(Ord. 860, 2003; Ord. 758 (part), 1991) 
2.17.020 - Incorporation by reference. 
    Words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings as defined and provided in the North Dakota Century Code in Title 40. In addition, all existing provisions and/or subsequent amendments in Chapter 40-23 of the North Dakota Century code, which are not inconsistent with this chapter, shall be and are incorporated by reference as the governing rules and procedures for the special assessment commission so created by this chapter. 
(Ord. 758 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 2.28 - HISTORICAL PRESERVATION COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.28.010 - Purpose. 
A.  The purpose of this chapter is to establish a program for the preservation, protection and regulation of historic properties within the city for the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the public; to safeguard the heritage of the city by preserving and regulating historic properties which reflect elements of its cultural, social, economic, political and architectural history; to preserve the city's economic base by the stimulation of the tourist industry; to establish and improve property values; to foster economic development; to manage growth; to foster civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past; and to promote the use of historic properties for the education, pleasure and welfare of the people of the city. 
B.  It is intended that the commission will cooperate with and assist various local, state and federal entities and/or agencies in the enforcement of federal and state legislation to identify, evaluate, designate, record, protect and preserve properties significant in the prehistory, history, architecture, engineering and culture of the community, state and nation. 
C.  It is further declared that the purposes of this chapter are to: 
1.  Retain and enhance those historic properties within the city while allowing their adaption for current use by assuring that alterations are compatible with their historic character; and 
2.  Assure that new construction and subdivision of lots in historic districts, i.e., concentrations of historic properties, are compatible with the character of such districts. 
(Ord. 743 § 1, 1990) 
2.28.020 - Preservation commission-Created. 
    There is created a commission to be known as the city historical preservation commission. 
(Ord. 743 § 2, 1990) 
2.28.030 - Commission members-Number-Appointment-Terms-Compensation. 
A.  Numbers. The commission shall consist of no less than five members and up to and including eight members. 
B.  Appointment. The commission members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city commission. 
C.  Terms. Each of the members of the commission shall be appointed for a term of two years, and such terms shall be staggered. 
D.  Compensation. The members shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. 808, 1997; Ord. 743 § 3, 1990) 
2.28.040 - Member qualifications. 
    Members appointed by the mayor shall be persons who, in the opinion of the mayor, have demonstrated outstanding interest and knowledge of history or architecture. A majority of the commission members shall be made up of persons from among professionals in the disciplines of architecture, history, architectural history, art history, planning, engineering, archeology or other historic preservation related disciplines, such as urban planning, American studies, American civilization, cultural geography or cultural anthropology, to the extent that such professionals are available in the community. 
(Ord. 743 § 4, 1990) 
2.28.050 - Selection of chairperson. 
    The mayor shall designate one of the members of the commission to be chairperson and one to be vice-chairperson. 
(Ord. 743 § 5, 1990) 
2.28.060 - Authorization to conduct studies and surveys. 
    The commission shall have the authority to conduct or to have conducted on its behalf studies and/or surveys of properties within the city limits. The commission shall conduct such studies and/or surveys in accordance with guidelines recommended by the state Historical Society. All collected data shall be recorded and maintained. Copies of such data must be provided to the state Historical Society. 
(Ord. 743 § 6, 1990) 
2.28.070 - Commission powers. 
A.  Unless otherwise specified herein, the powers and duties of the commission shall be to: 
1.  Promulgate criteria for classifying properties within the city as having historic significance; 
2.  Prepare, or have prepared on its behalf, a comprehensive inventory of historically significant and potentially historically significant properties within the city; 
3.  Make recommendations to the city commission concerning the acquisition of fee simple and less than fee simple rights in properties within the city for purposes of historic preservation; 
4.  Make recommendations to the city commission for any additional ordinances and/or administrative procedures required to implement the public policy declared in Section 2.28.010; 
5.  Develop and participate in public programs to increase public awareness of the value of historic properties and of the preservation program established by this chapter; 
6.  Make recommendations to the city commission (i) regarding application for and acceptance and utilization of grants from federal, state and local agencies or other entities, private groups, and individuals, and (ii) for budgetary appropriations to promote and achieve the preservation of historic properties in the city and to otherwise implement the public policy declared in Section 2.28.010 of this chapter; 
7.  Evaluate and comment upon plans, proposals, permits and applications which are developed or required by federal, state, municipal agencies or other public agencies, including those developed by other commissions, offices, and departments of the city, which may affect, either directly or indirectly, any property or properties deemed by the commission to have historic value; 
8.  Prepare and submit, in accordance with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations, nominations to the National Register of Historic Places for properties deemed by the commission to be significant in local, state and/or natural history; 
9.  Review and comment upon all certifications of significance and certifications of rehabilitation as requested by the state Historic Preservation Officer; and 
10.  Perform any other functions which may be designated to it by resolution or motion of the city commission. 
(Ord. 743 § 7, 1990) 
2.28.080 - Power to adopt rules of procedure. 
    The commission shall have the power to make whatever rules are necessary for the execution of its duties as set forth in this article. All such rules shall be approved by the city commission by resolution before becoming effective. 
(Ord. 743 § 8, 1990) 
2.28.090 - Meetings-Notice-Minutes. 
A.  The commission shall meet not less than four times annually, according to a schedule established one year in advance. The commission may meet at such other times as deemed convenient, prudent and necessary by the commission. 
B.  All commission meetings shall be open to the public and advertised not less than ten days in advance of the meeting. 
C.  Minutes of all meetings shall be maintained and kept in the office of the mayor and shall be provided to the state Historical Society within sixty days following each commission meeting, or at such other times as may be directed. 
(Ord. 743 § 9, 1990) 
2.28.100 - Authority to employ staff and services. 
    Within the limit of funds appropriated generally for the performance of its work, the commission may obtain the services of qualified persons to direct, advise, and assist the commission and may obtain the equipment, supplies, services and other material necessary to its effective operation. 
(Ord. 743 § 10, 1990) 
2.28.110 - Authority to receive funding. 
    The city commission may annually appropriate funds, within budget limitations, for the operation of the city historical preservation commission. A fund known as historical preservation will be created as a trust and agency fund. All revenue from any source will be deposited in this fund. 
    The city historical preservation commission may receive revenues and turn them in to the city auditor for deposit into this fund. The city historical preservation commission shall make recommendations for expenditures they deem necessary to the city commission. All expenditures from this fund will be disbursed in the customary and usual manner as other disbursements are handled by city policy and procedures. 
(Ord. 743 § 11, 1990) 
Chapter 2.32 - SHADE TREE COMMITTEE 
Sections: 

2.32.010 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the municipal shade tree ordinance of the municipality of Devils Lake, county of Ramsey, state of North Dakota. 
(Ord. 636 § 1, 1980) 
2.32.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directive. 
A.  "Forestry department" is that department that works under the supervision of the shade tree committee of the municipality, under whose jurisdiction city-owned trees fall. 
B.  "Large trees" mean those attaining a height of forty-five feet or more. 
C.  "Medium trees" mean those attaining a height of thirty to forty-five feet. 
D.  "Municipality" is the city, town, village, subdivision or otherwise designated area unit of Devils Lake, county of Ramsey, state of North Dakota. 
E.  "Nuisance" means any dangerous or unsafe tree or portions thereof; and any tree harboring insect or disease organisms of a contagious and fatal nature which pose a serious threat to surrounding trees if not immediately removed and disposed of. 
F.  "Park" means and includes all public parks having individual names. 
G.  "Person" is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
H.  "Property line" means the outer edge of a street, highway or other public places owned by the city. 
I.  "Property owner" means the person owning such property as shown by the county auditor's plat of Ramsey County, state of North Dakota. 
J.  "Public places" means and includes all other grounds owned by the municipality of Devils Lake, county of Ramsey, state of North Dakota. 
K.  "Public trees" means and includes all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter growing on any street or any public place where otherwise indicated. 
L.  "Shade tree foreman" means the forester, tree warden or other qualified official of the municipality of Devils Lake, county of Ramsey, assigned to carry out the enforcement of this chapter under the supervision of the shade tree committee. 
M.  "Small trees" mean those attaining a height of twenty to thirty feet. 
N.  "Street" or "highway" means the entire width of every public way or right-of-way when any part of it is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
O.  "Tree lawn" means that part of a street or highway, not covered by a sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 636 § 2, 1980) 
2.32.030 - Established. 
A.  There shall be a committee known as the shade tree committee of Devils Lake composed of ten citizens. The members shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of the city commission. The majority of the members of the shade tree committee shall be residents of the city. The committee shall consist of the following or a similar composition: 
1.  One member of the city commission; 
2.  One member of the planning commission; 
3.  One staff member of the city as named by the city commission; 
4.  One representative of a licensed local nursery or greenhouse; 
5.  One representative of public utilities; 
6.  One representative of the North Dakota State University, Bottineau School of Forestry, or other recognized school of forestry or horticulture; 
7.  No less than four and no more than six citizens at large. 
B.  Terms shall be for three years. Upon adoption, the initial terms shall be a continuation of the terms under the previous shade tree ordinance. The slate of officers shall also be carried over from the committee under the previous shade tree ordinance. Vacancies caused by death, resignation or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments are made. All members of the committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 852, 2002; Ord. 833 (part), 2000; Ord. 811, 1997; Ord. 636 § 3(I), 1980) 
2.32.040 - Powers and duties. 
    The duties of the shade tree committee shall be as follows: 
A.  To study the problems and determine the needs of the municipality of Devils Lake, county of Ramsey, state of North Dakota, in connection with its tree planting and maintenance program; 
B.  To recommend to the proper authority, the type and kind of trees to be planted on the right-of-way or berm, which include but are not limited to Canadian Red Cherry (tree), Burr Oak, Linden, Ash and Seedless Cottonwood. Other species may be permitted by the forester granting a written permit. Conifers, shrubs and similar plantings shall not be acceptable for right-of-way plantings; 
C.  To assist the properly constituted officials of the municipality, as well as the commission and citizens of the municipality, in the dissemination of news and information regarding the selection, planting and maintenance of trees within the corporate limits, whether it is on private or public property, and to make such recommendations from time to time to the city commission as to de- sirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities for the municipality; 
D.  To provide regular and special meetings at which the subject of trees insofar as it relates to the municipality may be discussed by members of the committee, officers and personnel of the municipality and its several divisions, and all others interested in the tree program. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000; Ord. 636 § 3(II), 1980) 
2.32.050 - Foreman-Appointment and salary. 
    The shade tree foreman shall be appointed by the city commission upon the recommendation of the shade tree committee, and shall receive a salary commensurate with his training and experience as full compensation for all services rendered and in lieu of all fees. 
(Ord. 636 § 4, 1980) 
2.32.060 - Foreman-Duties. 
    The shade tree foreman, under the direction of the shade tree committee, has the authority to promulgate the rules and regulations of the arboricultural specifications and standards of practice governing the planting, maintenance, removal, fertilization, pruning and bracing of trees on the streets or other public sites in the municipality, and shall direct, regulate and control the planting, maintenance and removal of all trees growing now or hereafter in public of the municipality. He shall cause the provision of this chapter to be enforced. In his absence these duties shall be the responsibility of a qualified alternate designated by the shade tree committee. 
(Ord. 636 § 5, 1980) 
2.32.070 - Foreman-Planting and removal of trees. 
    The shade tree foreman, under the supervision of the shade tree committee, has the authority and jurisdiction of regulating the planting, maintenance and removal of trees on streets and other publicly owned property to insure safety or preserve the aesthetics of such public sites. 
(Ord. 636 § 6(I), 1980) 
2.32.080 - Foreman-Work supervision. 
    The shade tree foreman has the authority and it shall be his duty to supervise or inspect all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. 636 § 6 (II), 1980) 
2.32.090 - Foreman-Conditions for granting of permit. 
    The shade tree foreman has the authority to affix reasonable conditions to the granting of a permit in accordance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. 636 § 6(III), 1980) 
2.32.100 - Foreman-Community forestry management plan. 
A.  The shade tree foreman has the authority to formulate a community forestry management plan with the advice, a hearing and approval of the shade tree committee. The community forestry management plan shall specify the species of tree to be planted on each of the streets or other public sites of the municipality. The city commission shall annually review, alter if necessary, and approve the plan by resolution. From and after the effective date of the community forestry management plan or any amendment thereof, all planting shall conform to it. 
B.  The shade tree foreman shall consider all existing and future utility and environmental factors when recommending a specific species for each of the streets and other public sites of the municipality. 
C.  The shade tree foreman, with the approval of the shade tree committee, has the authority to amend or add to the community forestry management plan at any time that circumstances make it advisable. 
(Ord. 636 § 6(IV), 1980) 
Chapter 2.36 - DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED OR UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 
Sections: 

2.36.010 - Storage of abandoned property. 
    Any personal property abandoned or left unclaimed upon the streets, alleys or other public ways of the city for a period exceeding ten days shall be taken up by any police officer of the city and stored and held in such place as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 408 § 1, 1958) 
2.36.020 - Police department to keep records. 
    An accurate record of any property taken by the police department as described in Section 2.36.010 shall be kept in the office of the police department with the date of such taking. 
(Ord. 408 § 2, 1958) 
2.36.030 - Redemption by owner. 
    Any person who satisfactorily establishes that he is the owner thereof, may reclaim any such articles of personal property from the chief of police thereof as set forth in this chapter, upon payment to the city treasurer of the necessary expenses of taking and storing, payment to be certified to by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 408 § 3, 1958) 
2.36.040 - Sale of abandoned property. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the chief of police, sufficient articles have been accumulated and held for a period of sixty days or more, to justify the expense of a sale thereof, the articles may be sold by the chief of police at public auction. Each item of property, which has been held by the police department for more than sixty days, shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash and the chief of police shall convey to the purchaser, by bill of sale, title to the property. Accurate records of each sale shall be kept, showing the price for which each article was sold. 
(Ord. 408 § 4, 1958) 
2.36.050 - Notice of sale. 
    Notice of time and place of sale and a brief description of the articles to be sold shall be published not less than ten days prior to the date of sale. 
(Ord. 408 § 5, 1958) 
2.36.060 - Owner entitled to proceeds of sale. 
A.  At any time within six months after the sale, the owner of the property, upon written application, shall be entitled to receive the proceeds of the sale less the necessary expenses of taking, storing and selling them. 
B.  Applications for repayment by the owner of any such property shall be filed with the city auditor and passed on by the city commission. 
(Ord. 408 § 6, 1980) 
2.36.070 - Report and remittance of funds to commission. 
    Immediately after a sale, the chief of police shall report to the city commission his proceedings upon the sale, together with the price of each article sold, and shall remit to the city treasurer the entire proceeds of the sale. 
(Ord. 408 § 7, 1980) 
Chapter 2.40 - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT 
Sections: 

2.40.010 - Vehicles not to interfere with takeoff and landing of aircraft. 
    No one shall drive or cause to be driven, any vehicle other than an aircraft, upon the runways, taxiways or aircraft parking ramps at the municipal airport or at any place thereon which will interfere with the taking off or landing of aircraft at the airport, except authorized repair and maintenance men. 
(Ord. 484 § 1, 1968) 
2.40.020 - Livestock running loose prohibited. 
    No one shall permit livestock to run loose upon the municipal airport, nor shall any animal be driven upon the runways, taxiways or parking ramps of the airport. 
(Ord. 484 § 2, 1968) 
2.40.030 - Lessee to keep premises in neat condition. 
    Any lessee of a site upon the municipal airport shall keep the leased premises in a neat condition. 
(Ord. 484 § 3, 1968) 
2.40.040 - Leased premises not to be used as living quarters. 
    No one shall use any of the leased premises as living quarters or maintain residential quarters in any hangar. 
(Ord. 484 § 4, 1968) 
Chapter 2.41 - AIRPORT REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

2.41.010 - General provisions. 
A.  Designated Representative. The airport manager shall be the designated representative of the Devils Lake municipal airport authority to enforce the regulations and ordinances provided for in the Devils Lake Municipal Airport Standard Operating Procedures and any city ordinances. The airport manager is authorized to administer fines and corrections in accordance with this chapter of the municipal code. 
B.  Hunting or Shooting Within Boundaries of Airport. Hunting or shooting within the boundaries of the airport is strictly prohibited, other than wildlife control that is deemed necessary by the airport manager or designee. No persons, except law enforcement officers, members of the Armed Forces of the United States on official duty, or persons duly authorized by the Devils Lake municipal airport authority, shall carry any weapons, explosive material or hazardous material on the airport, except cased sporting firearms carried for trans-shipment or in locked racks covered under the North Dakota Century Code. 
C.  Public Nuisance. No person shall be or become intoxicated, commit any disorderly, obscene or indecent act, or commit any action of nuisance, destroy, injure, deface or disturb in any way any building, sign equipment, marker, light fixture or other structure or property in the airport. 
D.  Advertisement. No person may post, distribute or display a sign, advertisement, circular, or other written or printed matter in the airport without the permission of the airport manager. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.020 - Commercial activity. 
A.  General. No person shall use the airport for commercial activities without a written contractual arrangement with the airport authority and the holder of a commercial lease at the airport will be authorized to conduct only those legal commercial activities that are approved in the commercial lease. Commercial activities shall include, but are not limited to, carrying passengers for hire, flight instruction, aircraft rental, sales of goods and services, agricultural operations and aircraft maintenance and repairs. Any individual owner of aircraft, or where joint ownership exits which engages in these activities for hire, shall be considered to be engaged in commercial activities. 
B.  Commercial Authorization. All commercial aviation activities shall be authorized by the airport authority, in accordance with all local, city and federal regulations. 
C.  Nondiscrimination. Any commercial operation engaged in providing services to the public shall perform those services in a fair, equal, safe and legal manner and shall not discriminate against any user but shall make reasonable and nondiscriminatory all pricing, discounts, rebates or other price reductions to volume customers. 
D.  Fuel. No aviation fuels shall be brought in the airport for use or for sale without the expressed permission of the airport authority. This permission is to be granted in a written document providing for safety in storage and handling. All fueling performed on the airport must be in accordance with the 14 CFR Part Section 139 of the Federal Aviation Regulations. 
E.  Aerial Application. Any person using the airport as a base for agricultural aerial application which involves the loading, unloading and storage of chemical must receive a permit from the airport authority. This permit will specify the areas to be used, restrictions which will apply, and the payment of an operating fee. No permit will be granted for less than a thirty-day period. Spraying operations are strictly prohibited on taxiways, runways and other controlled areas. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.030 - Leases. 
A.  General. All tenants shall be required to maintain their lease property in a condition of cleanliness and free from all fire hazards, and shall dispose of garbage, refuse or other material in the receptacles approved for that purpose. No tenants, lessees or grantees will be permitted to affect structural or decorative changes or additions of any type without submitting plans to the city assessor/building official for review and obtaining prior permission of the airport authority. Tenants, and their lessees and grantees, shall be fully responsible for all damages to buildings, equipment, real property and appurtenances in the ownership or custody of the airport caused by their negligence or abuse of carelessness. 
B.  Property Improvement. No person shall use, occupy, improve or construct any structure on any part or portion of the airport without first submitting plans to the city assessor/building official for review approval, and issuance of any necessary building permit and have secured written permission from the airport authority. 
C.  Construction. No person shall construct, erect or install any building or improvements upon any of the lots at the airport without first securing written permission from the airport authority. A proper building permit must be obtained from the city assessor/building official and any required FAA for including FAA Form No. 7460-1 shall be completed and submitted to both the FAA and the airport manager for review, before any construction is commenced. The airport authority shall have the right to inspect the plans and specifications of any such buildings, structures and improvements prior to construction or maintenance. The airport authority reserve the right to refuse such construction or maintenance, if the external appearance does not meet reasonable requirements for substantial uniformity of appearance of all buildings and structures on the airport, or if the type of construction or installation or the location does not meet reasonable requirements for safe use of the airport and appurtenances. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.040 - Vehicle regulations. 
A.  Vehicle Authorization. Only authorized vehicles that have been certified by the airport manager and are in possession of a valid airport operations security badge will be permitted to drive on the apron or other controlled area in the airport. Airport operation security badges will be issued by the airport manager upon successful completion of any requirements set out by the airport authority and may be suspended or revoked at any time by the airport authority. 
B.  Unauthorized Vehicles. No private vehicle shall be driven onto the ramp, except as necessary to go directly to and from specific aircraft for loading and unloading baggage or other special purposes and must be escorted by an authorized vehicle driven by personnel in possession of a valid airport operation security badge. 
C.  Two-wheeled Vehicles. No person may operate a bicycle or a two-wheeled motor vehicle on the landing area or ramp in the airport. 
D.  Speed Limit. No unauthorized vehicle, other than airport maintenance or FAA personnel equipped with a UNICOM and whose vehicle has a flashing light mounted on the roof, may operate a motor vehicle at a speed of more than ten miles an hour on any taxiway, runway, restricted service road, or other aircraft movement area. 
E.  Operational Control. No person may operate a motor vehicle in the airport in a careless or reckless manner as to endanger the life or property of others. Each person operating a motor vehicle in the airport will have a valid operator's license, and shall operate it so as to have it under proper control at all times. 
F.  Parking. No person may park or stand a motor vehicle in the airport, except in an area specifically designated for parking or standing. No person may park a motor vehicle in any area in the airport for a period longer than is designated for that area. No person may park or stand a motor vehicle within ten feet of a water hydrant in the airport. 
G.  Removal. The airport authority or its authorized representatives may tow away or move any motor vehicle in the airport that is parked in violation of the regulations of the airport. Any vehicle, equipment, mobile structure, trailer or boat without any specific aviation use, or abandoned property left for a period of more than seventy-two hours will be removed. The airport may charge a reasonable amount for the moving service and for storage of the vehicle, equipment, mobile structure, trailer or boat, if any. The moved property is subject to a lien for reasonable charges. 
H.  Large Vehicles. Any vehicles larger than a one-ton truck, excluding buses used to transport passengers to and from the airport terminal, are prohibited from driving or parking on the streets or parking lots restricted by the airport authority. 
I.  Traffic Code. Any vehicles operating in the airport are subject to the provisions of the city traffic code. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.050 - Aircraft regulations. 
A.  General. All aircraft operating on the Devils Lake airport shall conform with all rules and regulations set by the Federal Aviation Administration and shall only operate on those areas designated for aircraft use, unless otherwise permitted, in writing by the airport authority. 
B.  Aircraft Parking. All aircraft parked on the airport whether temporary or permanent shall be parked only in assigned or designated parking areas. Aircraft not parked in the proper area will be notified, if possible, and will be given twenty-four hours in which to move the aircraft to an authorized parking area. 
C.  Minor Maintenance. Only minor maintenance or repairs, excluding fluid changes (oil, hydraulics, battery acid, coolant, etc.), will be performed on aircraft parked on the ramp of the airport, except when necessary to move the aircraft to a designated maintenance facility. 
D.  Securing of Aircraft. The operator of each aircraft permanently based and parked on the airport will be responsible for properly securing the aircraft to protect it and other aircraft from wind damage. Individual airplanes may tie down in designated and established tie-down areas. The airport authority, airport manager, or authorized agent of the airport shall not provide tie-down restraints, including ropes, chains, etc.; nor shall the airport authority, airport manager or authorized agent be responsible to the owner of any aircraft for any damage sustained to such aircraft while using the tie-down space. A schedule of fees for tie-downs may be established by the airport authority, if so deemed necessary. 
E.  Engine Warming. Aircraft engines will be warmed up only in places normally approved for such purpose. At no time will aircraft with engines running be left unattended by any person. At no time shall engines be warmed up or operated when hangars, shops, offices, buildings, persons, equipment, passengers or aircraft are in the path of the propeller stream or turbine engine exhaust. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.060 - Fire regulations. 
A.  Fueling. No aircraft shall be fueled or drained while its engine is running, or while in a hangar or other enclosed place, except for maintenance purposes. Fueling shall be done in accordance with 14 CFR Part Section 139 of the Federal Aviation Regulations as amended and in such a manner and with such equipment that adequate connections for the grounding of static electricity shall be continuously maintained during such time. No person shall perform or allow performance of any refueling operation during an electrical, wind or dust storm. 
B.  Hazardous Materials. No fuels, oils, dopes, paints, solvents, chemicals, acids or other hazardous material shall be disposed of or dumped in drains on the ramp area, catch basins, ditches or elsewhere in the airport. 
C.  Explosives. No person shall store, keep, use, dispose or transport to, in or upon the airport any Class A or Class B explosives (as defined in the ICC regulations for transportation of explosive and other dangerous articles), dynamite, nitroglycerine, black powder, fireworks, alcohol, ether, liquid shellac, kerosene, turpentine, or other flammable or combustible liquids, ammonium nitrate, sodium chlorate, powdered metallic magnesium, or other easily flammable solids, corrosive liquids or gas, any radioactive article, substance or other hazardous material prohibited by the transportation security administration (TSA), at such time or place or in such manner or condition as to endanger unreasonably or as to be likely to endanger unreasonably persons or property. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.070 - Airport safety. 
    Any accident or emergency shall be reported to the Lake Region Law Enforcement Center and the airport manager, immediately. No unauthorized personnel shall go to the scene of an accident, except to render aid in the absence of authorized personnel. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.080 - Terminal use. 
A.  General. The corridor and lobby areas of the terminal shall be open to all airport tenants and airline customers as long as the terminal is open. All private areas in the terminal (TSA screening rooms, airline offices, etc.) shall be occupied at the will of their perspective owners and shall be closed to public use, unless otherwise authorized by the owner. Unauthorized use of the terminal is prohibited, unless written authorization is obtained by the airport authority. 
B.  Smoking. Terminal facilities, as with all public facilities, shall be smoke free at all times. 
C.  Alcohol. Alcohol in the terminal facilities is strictly prohibited, unless specifically authorized by the airport authority. 
D.  Animals. Dogs, cats, birds, wild animals, rodents and other animals are prohibited in the terminal building, unless the animal is authorized to be transported on an aircraft and the animal is properly caged and/or restrained. This does not include any dog used to assist someone who is vision impaired. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
2.41.090 - Enforcement. 
A.  General. Any person who knowingly and wilfully violates any rule or regulation prescribed in these regulations or any order or instruction issued by the Devils Lake municipal airport authority authorized in this chapter may be fined and or ejected from the airport and may be denied the use of the airport and its facilities, if it is determined by the airport authority that such denial is necessary under the circumstances. An act is done "knowingly," if it is done voluntarily and intentionally, and not because of mistake or accident or other innocent reason. An act is done "wilfully," if done voluntarily and intentionally, and with the intent to do something which the actor knows the regulations forbid. 
B.  Fines. The airport manager or the airport authority has the authority to impose fines for any violation of this chapter of the Devils Lake Municipal Code. The fine shall be one hundred dollars for each violation. Each day in which a violation occurs is a separate violation resulting to one hundred dollars per day fine. A fine is imposed by written notification to the party against whom the fine is imposed. The party has ten days in which to appeal the decision of the fine to the airport authority. The failure to appeal the imposition of the fine or the decision of the airport authority on the fine shall be final. 
C.  Denial of Use. Any party may be denied of use of the airport by action of the airport authority. If the airport manager or the airport authority feels such action is necessary, notice shall be provided to the party whose privileges are sought to be denied. The notice shall specify the actions of the party considered to be such that the party's privileges may be denied, and the date, time and place when the airport authority will conduct a hearing on the denial of the privileges. The hearing will be in no less than seven or more than fourteen days from the date of the notice. The violation of any provision of this chapter shall be sufficient cause to deny a party the right to use the airport. The failure to pay a fine imposed in subsection B of this section is sufficient grounds to deny a party of the use of the airport. The airport authority may dismiss the matter, suspend the party's use of the airport for a period of time, impose such conditions on the party's use of the airport, if it feels necessary or suspend and deny the party's use of the airport. The decision of the airport authority shall be final. 
(Ord. 864 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 2.44 - CITY CEMETERY* 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Designated. 
    The land and property acquired by the city from the G.A.R. Cemetery Association and St. Joseph's Church of Devils Lake, together with all additions to it, shall be known as the Devils Lake Cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 1, 1948) 
2.44.020 - Maintained for inhabitants. 
    The cemetery shall be maintained as a burial ground for the inhabitants of the city and for such other persons as the city commission may by ordinance or resolution permit to be buried in it. 
(Ord. 314 § 2, 1948) 
2.44.030 - Interment within city prohibited. 
    No interment of any deceased person shall be made within the city. 
(Ord. 314 § 3, 1948) 
2.44.040 - Preferred right of burial to Roman Catholics on certain premises. 
    Persons dying in the Roman Catholic faith shall have a preferred right to burial on the premises deeded by St. Joseph's Church. Ministers of all faiths may conduct funeral services within the cemetery in accordance with the rituals of their respective faiths. Membership or nonmembership in any faith, however, shall not affect the right to burial in any part of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 4, 1948) 
2.44.050 - Recognition of rights of owners of burial lots. 
    The rights of all owners of burial lots or burial rights through conveyances heretofore made by the respective owners of the cemetery property shall be recognized and the title is accepted by the city subject to all burial rights heretofore granted. 
(Ord. 314 § 5, 1948) 
2.44.060 - Platting. 
    Portions of the cemetery have heretofore been platted and the plats are recognized, and additional portions of the cemetery shall be platted from time to time as may be found necessary. The plots are laid out in blocks, lots and single grave rights. 
(Ord. 314 § 6, 1948) 
2.44.070 - Purchase of grave sites by residents and nonresidents. 
A.  Any resident of the city or nonresident owning property and paying property taxes within the city may purchase one or more single grave sites at the city cemetery. The number of such grave sites may be limited by the superintendent or other official of the city to such number as the purchaser may reasonably use for his immediate family. Any person who has shown a bonafide intent to become a permanent resident of the city by residing in the city for ninety days or more shall be deemed a resident for the purpose of this chapter. The ordinance codified in this section shall be in full force and effect after its passage and approval as provided by law. 
B.  Nonresidents of the city may purchase one or more single grave sites within the city cemetery as long as the superintendent or other official of the city deems the facilities ample to provide for the future requirements of the residents of the city. Any person who moves from the city after establishing residence in it shall be deemed a resident until the person has established residence elsewhere. 
C.  The date of burial or cremation shall be the date of the committal service (North Dakota Century Code 23-0604). Bodies may be stored in the storage vault at the cemetery from the date of the committal service to the date of interment. 
(Ord. 745, 1990; Ord. 696, 1986; Ord. 645 § 1(part), 1981: Ord. 544 § 1(part), 1973: Ord. 485 § 1(part), 1968: Ord. 455 § 1(part), 1965) 
2.44.080 - Fees. 
    The fees to be charged for burial rights, grave openings and other services shall be established by resolution of the city commission and revised as it may see fit. 
(Ord. 645 § 1(part), 1981: Ord. 544 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 485 § 1(part), 1968: Ord. 455 § 1 (part), 1965) 
2.44.090 - Burial of infants. 
    Persons desiring to bury infants in the cemetery may, with the approval of the superintendent, purchase less than a single grave right and in such case appropriate notation shall be made by the superintendent on his records. 
(Ord. 314 § 9, 1948) 
2.44.100 - Burial of more than one person in single grave. 
    Not more than one person shall be buried in any single grave right except in the case of infants. 
(Ord. 314 § 10, 1948) 
2.44.110 - No title to land to purchasers of grave rights. 
    Purchasers of grave rights shall acquire only the right to make interment in the space purchased and shall acquire no title to the land. 
(Ord. 314 § 11, 1948) 
2.44.120 - Superintendent-Office created. 
    There is created the office of superintendent of cemetery. The superintendent shall be appointed by the president of the board of city commissioners for a term of two years. The same person may be appointed as assessor of the city and as superintendent of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 16, 1948) 
2.44.130 - Superintendent-Receipt to purchaser for grave rights. 
    The superintendent shall issue to the purchaser of all grave rights a receipt specifying the amount of money paid by the purchaser and designating the specific grave rights in which burial may be made. One copy of the receipt shall be delivered to the purchaser and one copy shall be furnished to the city auditor, while one copy shall be retained by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 314 § 12, 1948) 
2.44.140 - Moneys received credited to cemetery fund. 
    All moneys received from the sale of lots or grave rights and all other moneys received under the provisions of this chapter shall be credited to the cemetery fund of the city. All expenditures for the maintenance of the cemetery shall be paid out of such fund upon vouchers properly certified and approved by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 314 § 13, 1948) 
2.44.150 - Certificate procured for interment. 
    When the owner of any grave right desires to have interment made, the owner or his representatives shall procure from the superintendent a certificate designating the specific grave right in which interment will be made, and he shall pay to the superintendent the sum of fifty cents for such certificate. 
(Ord. 314 § 14, 1948) 
2.44.160 - Superintendent-To keep records of grave rights. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent to keep adequate and sufficient records to readily show who are the owners of grave rights which have been sold and also to show the particular grave rights in which interment has been made and who has been buried therein and to comply with all laws of the state and regulations of the State Health Department with reference to burial permits and the keeping of records in connection with burials in the cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 15, 1948) 
2.44.170 - Superintendent-Salary. 
    The salary of the superintendent shall be fixed by the board of city commissioners from time to time and in the event the same person may hold another appointment under the city, his salary may be apportioned among the several departments served, as the board of city commissioners may determine. 
(Ord. 314 § 17, 1948) 
2.44.180 - Superintendent-Jurisdiction. 
    The superintendent shall have general jurisdiction over the cemetery and shall supervise the digging of graves, the placing of monuments, the planting of trees and shrubbery, the erection of improvements and the general management of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 18, 1948) 
2.44.190 - Superintendent-Power to make rules. 
    Subject to the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances and resolutions as may be adopted by the board of city commissioners, the superintendent shall have the power to make such reasonable rules and regulations as he may deem necessary with reference to the use, care and improvement of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 314 § 19, 1948) 
2.44.200 - Superintendent-May employ assistants. 
    The superintendent, subject to approval by the board of city commissioners, may employ such assistance as may be required for the operation and management of the cemetery and shall direct the activities of such employees. 
(Ord. 314 § 20, 1948) 
2.44.210 - Superintendent-Opening of grave. 
    All graves shall be opened under the direction of the superintendent. When a certificate for burial is issued by him he shall collect from the person desiring to make interment an amount sufficient to pay for the opening of a grave. The amount shall be determined from time to time by the superintendent with the approval of the board of city commissioners. The superintendent at his discretion may permit the person desiring to make interment to himself open the grave or hire the opening to be made. 
(Ord. 314 § 21, 1948) 
2.44.220 - Superintendent-Additional platting and land set aside for chapels. 
    The superintendent shall cause additional portions of the cemetery to be platted from time to time as need may occur. Upon application of any church within the city he may set aside a portion of the cemetery to be occupied by a chapel to be erected by such church, but all costs in connection with the erection or maintenance of such chapel shall be borne by such church, and it and the surrounding grounds must be maintained in good condition. 
(Ord. 314 § 22, 1948) 
2.44.230 - Use regulations for burial vaults. 
    The burial vault at the cemetery may be used for the storage of cemetery equipment but otherwise shall be used exclusively for storing dead bodies during such time as it is impracticable to make interment in the cemetery, and such storage shall be made without discrimination. Such storage shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent and he may require any body to be removed from the vault and interred when conditions require. 
(Ord. 314 § 23, 1948) 
2.44.240 - Construction of burial vaults. 
    All burial vaults used in the Devils Lake cemetery shall be constructed of permanent material which is acceptable by the State Health Department and meets the minimum requirements of any applicable federal or state law; provided, however, that certain exceptions to this section may be allowed in the event of religious beliefs contrary to the requirements specified in this section. 
(Ord. 529 § 1, 1972) 
2.44.250 - Improperly installed monuments to be reset. 
    Monuments and markers which are not properly installed or which constitute a hazard or are in an unsightly condition shall be reset by the employees of the cemetery when time and facilities permit. The cost shall be charged to the lot owners, and shall be collected before other burials are permitted in the lot belonging to such owner. 
(Ord. 314 § 24, 1948) 
2.44.260 - Installation of monuments on concrete foundation. 
    Installation of monuments and markers shall be made on a concrete foundation in such a manner as to assure the permanence and sightliness of the monument or marker, and to facilitate the cutting of grass around it. 
(Ord. 314 § 25, 1948) 
2.44.270 - Foundation installation supervised by superintendent. 
    All foundation work shall be done under the supervision of the superintendent. He may direct such work to be done by regular employees or may engage persons qualified for the work. Individuals with experience in this work may do their own work with the permission and under the supervision of the superintendent. 
(Ord. 314 § 26, 1948) 
2.44.280 - Fees for work and services. 
    Fees for all work and services shall be fixed from time to time by the superintendent, subject to approval by the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 314 § 27, 1948) 
2.44.290 - General regulations. 
A.  No person shall disturb the quiet by noise of any kind, or by any improper conduct. 
B.  No person shall have in his possession or shall discharge any firearm in the cemetery, except soldiers and veterans at military funerals and at Memorial Day services. 
C.  No person shall drive any vehicle faster than ten miles per hour nor drive anywhere except on the roads. 
D.  No person shall obstruct passage by parking on any road. 
E.  No person shall loiter any place in the cemetery. 
F.  No person shall remove any object or make any excavation without the express consent of the superintendent. 
G.  No person shall wilfully injure or destroy any monument, marker, tree or decoration or commit any act of vandalism in the cemetery. 
H.  No person shall leave or store any object or property in the cemetery which is not for immediate installation in it. 
(Ord. 314 § 28, 1948) 
Chapter 2.48 - PUBLIC LIBRARY 

2.48.001 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the board of city commissioners means the governing body of the city, and the board of directors means the governing body of Lake Region Public Library. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.010 - Established. 
    There is organized and established for the city a public library to be known as Lake Region Public Library. 
(Prior code § 477) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.020 - Taking of library materials against rules prohibited. 
    Every person who takes from the public library any library materials, pamphlet, periodical, paper, audio-visual materials, or other property, except in accordance with the rules of the library, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for each offense as provided in the fees and rates. 
(Prior code § 478) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.030 - Late return of library materials prohibited. 
    Every person who takes or borrows from the public library any library materials, pamphlet, periodical, paper, audio-visual materials, or other property and who refuses or neglects to return it within three weeks from the date of mailing a notice of delinquency to the person's address, and refuses or neglects during that time to pay the librarian the value of the property, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished for each offense as provided in the fees and rates. 
(Prior code § 479) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.040 - Damage to library property prohibited. 
    Every person who willfully and wantonly cuts, mutilates, marks, tears, writes upon, defaces or otherwise destroys or injuries, in whole or in part any library property, pamphlet, periodical, map, document, picture, audio-visual materials, or written or engraved or printed paper belonging to the public library, or suffers any such injury to be done while such property is in the person's custody, or willfully or wantonly injures any of the furniture or property in the rooms or buildings occupied by the library, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine for each offense as provided in the fees and rates. 
(Prior code § 480) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.050 - Fines. 
    All fines collected under this chapter shall be paid into the library fund for the use of the library; provided, however, that all costs due the city must be paid before any sums are paid into the library fund; and it shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute all violations of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 481) 
2.48.060 - Library fund. 
A.  For the purpose of maintaining a public library service, the board of city commissioners has established a library fund. The library fund consists of annually levying and causing to be collected as other taxes are collected, a municipal tax not exceeding six mills as previously voted on by the electors, and any other moneys received for library purposes from any source. 
B.  The city auditor shall maintain the fund to account for library revenues and shall make payments from the fund for invoices that have been submitted and approved by the library board of directors. On request of the city auditor, the library board of directors shall supply its records. The records must be provided on a timely basis. The fund may not revert to the city at the end of any fiscal year. The fund must be used exclusively for the maintenance of public library service. 
C.  Whenever a tax for county library service is levied, the city auditor shall execute a written application to be exempted from the county tax levy for the property located within the city limits, as allowed under the provisions of North Dakota Century Code 40-38-02. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
2.48.070 - Board of directors. 
A.  The board of directors of the Lake Region Public Library shall consist of seven persons. The board of city commissioners shall appoint four of those directors to govern the library. Of the four directors appointed by the city commission, one of them shall be a member of the board of commissioners or designated as the representative of the board of city commissioners. The remaining three members of the board of directors of the library shall be appointed by the Ramsey County Commission. 
B.  The director's term of office shall be three years from the first day of July in the year of appointment and until a successor has been appointed. No member shall serve for more than two consecutive terms, after which an interval of one year must elapse before the same member may be reappointed. 
C.  All vacancies on the board of directors shall be reported to the appointing board, who shall appoint to the unexpired term for the residue only. This unexpired term shall count as one of the two consecutive terms which a director is limited to serve. 
D.  No compensation shall be paid or allowed to a director. At the first meeting following the appointment of its members, the board of directors shall meet and organize by electing a president. 
E.  The board of city commissioners may contract directly with the library board established by another governing body of a municipality, county or school board for the purpose of public library service. 
(Ord. 817, 1997: Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.080 - General powers and duties. 
    The board of directors shall have the following powers and duties: 
A.  To make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations relating to the duties of their officers as may be expedient and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter, and file the same with the city auditor; 
B.  To make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for the management of the library as are expedient and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter, and file the same with the city auditor; 
C.  To control, exclusively, the expenditures of all moneys collected for or contributed to the library fund; 
D.  To have the supervision, care, and custody of the library property and of the rooms or buildings constructed, leased, or set apart for use of library purposes; 
E.  To contract to receive library service from other counties, school districts, cities and the state library; 
F.  To employ qualified personnel to administer the public library and dispense library services. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
2.48.090 - Library buildings. 
A.  The board of directors, with the approval of the board of city commissioners, may build, lease, lease-purchase, or purchase an appropriate building for a library and purchase a site therefor. 
B.  Prior to approval, the board of city commissioners shall hold a public hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be published at least once, not less than six days prior to the hearing, in the official city newspaper. 
C.  The board of city commissioners shall seek the advice and comment of the state library and the general public at the hearing. After such hearing the board of city commissioners may establish by resolution a library building fund for the purpose of construction, enlargement, alteration of a building or for the purchase of an existing building to be used as a public library. 
D.  The city auditor shall place in the library building fund all monies as may be appropriated or received for such purposes from any source. 
E.  The library building fund shall not revert to the library general fund or the general fund of the city without authorization by formal resolution from both the library board of directors and the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.100 - Vouchers. 
    The city auditor may draw money from the library fund only upon vouchers approved by the board of directors without any other approval. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
2.48.110 - Library free to residents of Ramsey County. 
A.  The library established under this chapter and the services provided thereof shall be free to all residents of Ramsey County, subject to such reasonable rules and regulations as the board of directors may deem necessary to adopt to render the greatest benefit. Such rules shall be posted in a location readily accessible to the public. The board may exclude from the use of the library any and all persons who willfully violate such rules. 
B.  Pursuant to North Dakota Century Code, any person residing outside of Ramsey County, North Dakota, shall be considered a non-resident and shall be charged a fee for public library service, the amount of which and duration of time paid for shall be determined by the library board of directors. 
(Ord. 771, 1992; Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.120 - Donations. 
    All persons desirous of making donations of money, books, personal property or real estate for the benefit of the library may vest the same in the board of directors. The board of directors shall hold and control all property accepted for the use of the library as a special trustee. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
2.48.130 - Annual report of board of directors. 
    The board of directors shall make a report not later than May 1 of each year to the board of city commissioners stating: 
A.  The condition of the library and property; 
B.  The various sums of money received from all sources; 
C.  How much money has been expended and for what purpose; 
D.  The number of books and other materials on hand; 
E.  The number of books and other materials added by purchase or gift during the year and the number thereof lost or loaned out; 
F.  The character and kind of materials contained in the library;
