G.  Such other statistics, information, and suggestions or as may be required by the state library. Copies of the report shall be filed with the state library by the board of directors. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 930, 9-21-15) 
2.48.140 - Open records exception. 
    Any record maintained or received by the library, which provides a patron's name or information sufficient to identify a patron together with the subject about which the patron requested information, is considered private and is excepted from the public records disclosure requirements of Section 44-04-18 of the North Dakota Century Code. These records may be released when required pursuant to a court order or a subpoena. 
(Ord. 759 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 2.52 - PROCEDURE FOR BIDS 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Filing, sealing, endorsing, opening, considering. 
    Bids for the work to be let shall be forwarded to the city auditor and shall be sealed securely to prevent the opening thereof without detection. There shall be endorsed upon the outside of the envelope containing the bid, a statement of what work such proposal is for. The bids shall be opened by the board of city commissioners at the expiration of the time limited in the advertisement for receiving the same, which shall not be less than seven days after the first publication of the advertisement, or at such other time as the board of city commissioners may appoint. Only bids which are accompanied by the bond provided for in Section 40-22-20, North Dakota Century Code, or any act amendatory to thereof, shall be considered by the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 720, 1988) 
Chapter 2.60 - EMERGENCY EMPLOYEES 
Sections: 

2.60.010 - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to require emergency employees to reside within the city so that they are available to assist in emergency situations and that the response to emergency situations is timely given. 
(Ord. 806 (part), 1997) 
2.60.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this chapter: 
    "Emergency employee" means an employee of the public works department, the fire department or the police department of the city of Devils Lake. 
    "Resident" means a person who has their place of abode in the city of Devils Lake and is a bona fide resident of the city of Devils Lake. A bona fide resident is a person having a permanent domicile within the city of Devils Lake and a domicile which has not been adopted with the intention of later moving back to a previous residence acquired outside of the city limits. 
(Ord. 806 (part), 1997) 
2.60.030 - Residency requirements. 
    All emergency employees, as a condition of their employment, shall be residents of the city. 
(Ord. 806 (part), 1997) 
2.60.040 - Exceptions to residency requirements. 
    Residency requirements in Section 2.60.030 of this chapter do not apply to the following: 
A.  Emergency employees who on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter are not residents of the city. This exception is not intended, however, to allow present emergency employees who are residents of the city to move their residence outside of the city after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter; 
B.  Administration personnel, not including department heads, who are designated by their department head as an employee who is not required to be available in an emergency. The department head is intended to be an emergency employee; 
C.  An emergency employee who does request, in writing, to be granted an exception to the residency requirement, which request is granted by the city commission. 
(Ord. 806 (part), 1997) 
2.60.050 - Effective date. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter will be effective upon its adoption by the Devils Lake city commission. 
(Ord. 806 (part), 1997) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.01 - UTILITY BILL 
Sections: 

3.01.010 - Utility bill. 
A.  A utility bill consisting of charges for the service and usage of water, sewer (wastewater), garbage, and other charges authorized by the city commission, shall be sent to each customer using any or all of these services monthly on a cycle basis. 
B.  For all utilities, the monthly charge shall be added to and collected as a part of the utility bill, but each service shall be separately stated on the bill. The proceeds from the collection of the fees and charges for each service shall be placed in the appropriate fund for each respectively. 
C.  If the utility bill, together with the penalty is not paid, the city may maintain an action for the collection of such charges. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.020 - Special assessment of unpaid utility bill. 
    It shall be the duty of the city auditor to certify to the county auditor such unpaid utility bill in the same manner and at the same time as other assessments are certified, and they shall be assessed and collected in the same manner. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.030 - Rates and charges. 
    Rates shall be fixed from time to time by resolution of the governing body and the city reserves the right to change the rates from time to time as it deems best. The resolution fixing rates and charges shall be kept on file in the office of the city auditor and shall be open for public inspection. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.040 - Penalty. 
    A late charge shall be assessed according to the current resolution of fees and rates to all account amounts shown as previous balance. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.050 - Rates and charges-Liability. 
A.  The owner or owners of all real property in the city furnished service or repairs shall be responsible for the payment of any and all such charges regardless of who the occupant or tenant may be. 
B.  Owners of premises where service is supplied shall notify the city auditor's office in case any tenant moves from the premises, prior to such moving. 
C.  On request of the owner, the city auditor will bill the occupant or tenant for such charges. 
D.  If such charges are not paid within sixty days of the consumption period by the occupant or tenant, the owner or owners shall be responsible for such charges. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.060 - Notice of discontinuance required. 
    Any person desiring to discontinue the use of the water must give notice thereof at the office of the city auditor. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.070 - Billing method. 
    The method of billing shall be as follows: 
A.  Payment due twenty-five days after billing with shutoff sixty days after the consumption period. 
B.  Any account with an amount not paid within sixty days of the consumption period will receive a disconnect notice on the past due amount as shown on the utility billing. This notice is sent to the renter and owner of the account as appropriate. 
C.  If a city representative is sent to this account for shutoff or if water is shutoff, a charge will be assessed to the account according to the current resolution of fees and rates. Any insufficient checks received as payment for a past due account will be an immediate disconnect. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.080 - Shutoff ordered. 
    Whenever shutoff is ordered the days of Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday will be utilized as much as possible. This is intended to not shutoff on Mondays, Fridays, weekends or holidays. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.090 - Payment after shutoff ordered. 
    Payment of the entire amount due including reconnect fee will be made prior to turning the service back on. 
(Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
3.01.100 - Curb stop box inoperative. 
    Should it become necessary to dig out the curb stop box for turning the water on or off, the city shall be required to stand the expense of it. 
(Ord. 855 (part), 2003: Ord. 765 (part), 1992) 
Chapter 3.04 - CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY 
Sections: 

3.04.010 - Referred to proper departments. 
    All demands, claims or accounts against the city shall be referred to the proper departments and shall by such departments be reported to the city auditor with recommendations thereon, and when so reported the city auditor shall present the same to the board of city commissioners with his recommendations. 
(Prior code § 7) 
Chapter 3.08 - SALES, USE, AND GROSS RECEIPTS TAX 
Sections: 

3.08.010 - Definitions. 
    All terms defined in Chapters 40.05.1, 57-39.2, 57-39.4, 57-39.5, 57-39.6 and 57-40.2 of the North Dakota Century Code (N.D.C.C.), including any future amendments, are adopted by reference. All references to the N.D.C.C. include amendments adopted by the North Dakota Legislative Assembly. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.020 - Collection and administration. 
    Where not in conflict with the provisions of this chapter, the provisions of N.D.C.C. chapters 40.05.1, 57-39.2, 57-39.4, 57-39.5, 57-39.6, and 57-40.2, and all administrative rules adopted by the tax commissioner, pertaining to the collection and administration of the retail sales, use, and gross receipts tax, including provisions for liability, refund, penalty, interest or credit, govern the administration by the North Dakota Office of State Tax Commissioner (hereinafter "tax commissioner") of the taxes imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.030 - Sales tax imposed. 
    Subject to the provisions of N.D.C.C. § 40.05.1-06, and except as otherwise provided by this chapter, or the sales and use tax laws of the State of North Dakota, a tax of two and one quarter percent is imposed upon the gross receipts of retailers from all sales at retail, including the leasing or renting of tangible personal property, within the corporate limits of the City of Devils Lake, North Dakota. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.040 - Use tax imposed. 
    Subject to the provisions of N.D.C.C. § 40-05.1-06, and except as otherwise provided in this chapter, or the sales and use tax laws of the State of North Dakota, an excise tax is imposed upon the storage, use, or consumption within the corporate limits of the City of Devils Lake, North Dakota, of tangible personal property purchased at retail for storage, use, or consumption in this city, at the rate of two and one quarter percent of the purchase price of the property. An excise tax is imposed on the storage, use, or consumption within the corporate limits of the City of Devils Lake, North Dakota, of tangible personal property not originally purchased for storage, use, or consumption in this city at the rate of two and one quarter percent of the fair market value of the property at the time it was brought into this city. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.050 - Gross receipts of alcoholic beverages. 
    Subject to the provisions of N.D.C.C. § 40-05.1-06, and except as otherwise provided in this chapter, a gross receipts tax of two and one quarter percent is imposed upon all gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city. A person who receives alcoholic beverages for storage, use, or consumption in this state is subject to tax on storage, use, or consumption of those alcoholic beverages at the rate of two and one quarter percent. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.060 - Exemptions. 
    In addition to the exemptions provided by state law, this chapter provides exemptions from imposition and computation of the city sales or use tax for sales of the following: 
A.  Sales of natural gas; 
B.  Gross receipts from coin-operated amusement devices; 
C.  New farm machinery; 
D.  New farm irrigation equipment. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.070 - Contractors. 
    Sales to contractors that are exempt pursuant to subsection 15 of N.D.C.C. § 57-39.2-04 shall be exempt from any city sales tax, but contractors shall be subject to the city use tax on those items used within the city that would be taxed pursuant to N.D.C.C. § 57-40.2-03.3 on which the city sales tax has not previously been paid. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.080 - Maximum tax imposed. 
    Any patron or user paying a tax imposed by this chapter in excess of twenty five dollars upon any single transaction of one or more items may obtain a refund of the excess tax payment by filing a request for refund upon the forms provided by the tax commissioner. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.090 - Contract with tax commissioner. 
    The Devils Lake city auditor is hereby authorized to contract with the tax commissioner for administration and collection of taxes imposed by this chapter. The city auditor has all powers granted to the tax commissioner, and in the absence of a valid contract with the tax commissioner or failure of the tax commissioner to perform the delegated duties, shall perform these duties in place of the tax commissioner. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.100 - Dedication of tax proceeds. 
    The proceeds from the tax imposed by this chapter are hereby dedicated as follows: 
A.  Debt reduction for sewage treatment system, property tax relief, infrastructure improvements, economic development, and debt reserve shall receive forty five percent of the tax. 
B.  Financing of the construction of Flood Protection District No. 1-96 (dike system) shall receive twenty-two percent of the tax. When the debt to finance the city's share of the construction of Flood Protection District No. 1-96 (dike system) has been retired, this twenty-two percent of the tax shall be extended and will be designated by the city commission for the following purposes: funding for water treatment, water source, storm water, infrastructure improvement, community development, library, and other public facilities. 
C.  Infrastructure improvements shall receive thirty-three percent of the tax. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.110 - Compensation. 
    City sales, use, and gross receipts tax permit holders are allowed to retain a portion of tax collected under this chapter to help recover administrative expenses. This compensation shall equal three percent of the city tax due; however, the deduction is limited to 83.33 per month or two hundred fifty per quarter. A tax return must be filed and paid in full by the scheduled due date or the compensation will be disallowed and the tax obligation will be subject to penalty and interest. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
3.08.120 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall take effect after its passage, approval, and publication, but not prior to October 1, 2018. 
(Ord. 874 (part), 2006) 
(Ord. No. 952, 4-16-18) 
Chapter 3.09 - RESTAURANT TAX 
Sections: 

3.09.010 - Restaurant tax-Imposition-Amount-Disposition. 
    There is imposed a tax of one percent upon the gross receipts of retailers on the leasing or renting of a hotel, motel, or tourist court accommodations within the city for periods of less than thirty consecutive calendar days or one month and upon the gross receipts of a restaurant from any sales of prepared food or beverages, not including alcoholic beverage, which are subject to state sales tax. For purposes of this section, "restaurant" means any place where food is prepared and intended for individual portion service for consumption on or off the premises and "prepared" includes heating prepackaged food. Accommodations, food and beverages may all, each, or in any combination be subjected to the tax under this section, if all items in any category which are taxable under state law are taxable, except as otherwise provided by Chapter 40-57.3, North Dakota Century Code. The tax imposed under this section is in addition to state sales taxes on rental accommodations and restaurant sales which the city imposes under this section and the proceeds shall be deposited in the city visitors' promotion capital construction fund. Moneys deposited in the city visitors' promotion capital construction fund shall be spent only as provided in Chapter 40-57.3 of the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 863, 2004: Ord. 854, 2003: Ord. 797 (part), 1995) 
3.09.020 - City visitors' promotion fund-City visitors' promotion capital construction fund-Visitors' committee-Establishment-Purpose. 
    There are established a city visitors' promotion fund, a city visitors' promotion capital construction fund and a visitors' committee. The visitors' committee shall serve as an advisory committee to the city commission in administering the proceeds from the taxes available to the city under this chapter. The moneys in the visitors' promotion fund must be used generally to promote, encourage and attract visitors to come to the city and use the travel and tourism facilities within the city. The moneys in the visitors' promotion capital construction fund must be used generally for tourism or the purchase, equipping, improving, construction, maintenance, repair and acquisition of buildings or property consistent with the visitor attraction or promotion. The committee shall consist of seven members appointed by the city commission. These appointees shall serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for necessary expenses. Committee members shall serve for a term of four years, except that three of those initially appointed must be appointed for an initial term of two years. Vacancies must be filled in the same manner as the initial appointment. The committee shall elect a chairperson and vice-chairperson from among its members to serve for a term of two years. 
(Ord. 810, 1997; Ord. 797 (part), 1995) 
3.09.030 - Budget-Contracts-Bonds-Capital construction. 
    The city commission shall annually set the budget, if any, under which the committee shall operate. The city commission may contract with any person, firm, association, corporation or limited liability company to carry out the purposes of the city visitors' promotion fund or the city visitors' promotion capital construction fund created under Section 3.09.020. The city commission may irrevocably dedicate any portion of revenues from the tax authorized under Section 3.09.010 and may authorize and issue bonds or other evidences of indebtedness in a manner prescribed by Section 40-35-08 of the North Dakota Century Code to be paid by those revenues for any purpose that moneys in the city visitors' promotion capital construction fund may be used; and such tax upon being pledged to payment of bonds or evidences of indebtedness issued pursuant to this section may not be reduced or repealed by the city commission or by the electors of the city by any initiated amendment to or referendum of the ordinance establishing Section 3.09.010, so long as any of such bonds or evidences of indebtedness remain outstanding. The proceeds from the tax imposed under Section 3.09.010 may be used only for payment of bonds issued, and the costs of issuance related thereto, under this section or capital construction, maintenance and repair or acquisition of property consistent with the purpose of this chapter. 
(Ord. 797 (part), 1995) 
3.09.040 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall become effective sixty days from the date of its adoption by the Devils Lake city commission. 
(Ord. 797 (part), 1995) 
3.09.050 - Minimum tax. 
    The tax imposed under this chapter shall at no time exceed one percent. 
(Ord. 797 (part), 1995) 
Chapter 3.10 - LAKE REGION HERITAGE CENTER, INC. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE 
Sections: 

3.10.010 - Intention. 
    Historical promotion and historical work of the city of Devils Lake is declared an enterprise as provided in Article X, Section 18 of the North Dakota State Constitution. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this enterprise is the preservation and promotion of our past the benefit of the public. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.030 - Assistance to engage in enterprises. 
    The city of Devils Lake is not able to engage in this enterprise without the assistance of the Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc., and Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. is not able to engage in this enterprise without the financial assistance of the city of Devils Lake. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.040 - Findings for financial assistance. 
    The city of Devils Lake will provide financial assistance to Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter. In providing financial assistance, the Devils Lake city commission makes the following findings: 
A.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. is a non-profit corporation in good standing and authorized to do business in the state of North Dakota. 
B.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. has been determined to be exempt from federal income tax under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
C.  The historical preservation commission is created by Ordinance No. 743, which is codified as Chapter 2.28 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code. The purposes of Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. and the historical preservation committee are separate and distinct. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.050 - Procedure to obtain financial assistance. 
    The city commission may authorize a grant to Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. to carry out the purposes of this enterprises as set out in this chapter by the following procedure: 
A.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. shall request from the city of Devils Lake an amount of funding. 
B.  The request shall include Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. providing written information as to how the money will be spent. This information will address how the spending of this funding will implement the purposes of this enterprise. 
C.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. shall provide to the city of Devils Lake any information, including financial, requested by the Devils Lake city commission. 
D.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. will provide the city of Devils Lake with an accounting which shows how these funds were spent. 
E.  Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. will report to the Devils Lake city commission on the activities of Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc., which address how the purposes of Section 3.10.020 are implemented. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.060 - Qualifications for funding. 
    In order for Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. to qualify for funding from the city of Devils Lake, the following must be met: 
A.  The purpose of this enterprise as set out in this Section 3.10.020 must be met, as determined by the Devils Lake city commission. 
B.  The findings for financial assistance, as set out in Section 3.10.040, must continue to be met, as determined by the Devils Lake city commission. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
3.10.070 - Compliance with law. 
    Lake Region Heritage Center, Inc. agrees that it will at all times be in compliance with and shall in no way violate federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, or regulations. 
(Ord. 849 (part), 2001) 
Chapter 3.11 - IMPROVEMENT BY SPECIAL ASSESSMENT 
Sections: 

3.11.010 - Additional powers of the city to defray expense of improvement by special assessment. 
    In addition to the power to defray the expenses of improvement by special assessment in Section 40-22-01, N.D.C.C., and subsequent amendments, the city of Devils Lake shall have the following powers: 
A.  Upon complying with the provisions of Chapter 40-22, N.D.C.C., and subsequent amendments, the city of Devils Lake may defray, by special assessment, the cost of beautification of the city. This is intended to include the purchase and maintenance of banners, garbage cans, decorative or seasonal lighting, and flower baskets. 
(Ord. 850, 2001) 
Chapter 3.12 - MOTOR VEHICLE RENTAL TAX 
Sections: 

3.12.010 - City motor vehicle rental tax. 
    There is imposed a tax of one percent upon the gross receipts of a retailer on the rental of any motor vehicle for fewer than thirty days if that motor vehicle is either delivered to a renter at the Devils Lake municipal airport or delivered to a renter who is picked up by the retailer at the Devils Lake municipal airport. The tax imposed under the section is in addition to the state sales taxes on the rental of motor vehicles for fewer than thirty days. 
(Ord. 868 (part), 2005) 
3.12.020 - Deposit of proceeds. 
    The proceeds from the tax imposed under this chapter shall be deposited in the city visitors' promotion fund as enacted by Chapter 3.09 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 868 (part), 2005) 
3.12.030 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions do apply: 
    "Motor vehicle" means a motorized passenger vehicle designed to be operated on highways. 
    "Retailer" means a company for which the primary business is the renting of motor vehicles for periods of fewer than thirty days. 
(Ord. 868 (part), 2005) 
3.12.040 - Effective date. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be effective January 1, 2006. 
(Ord. 868 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 3.13 - WATER SOURCE 
Sections: 

3.13.010 - Definitions. 
    The city in this chapter is the city of Devils Lake, North Dakota. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.020 - Findings. 
    The adoption of this chapter is supported and based upon the following findings: 
A.  The city is subject to a mandate from the federal government to have the arsenic level of its water in compliance with amounts acceptable to the federal government. 
B.  The present water supply system of the city presently exceeds the normal life of a water supply system. 
C.  The city has acquired the title to real property for the location of wells to provide a new water source for the city. 
D.  The city has acquired the permits needed to use the water from these new well sites. 
E.  The city has requested financial assistance from various sources to finance the acquisition, construction and operation of a new water source. 
F.  Regional flooding has caused the present water supply line to be covered by significant amounts of lake water, making rerouting, routine maintenance and repairs extremely difficult and costly. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.030 - Enabling provision. 
    The city does operate under a Home Rule Charter approved by the voters of the city at a special election held on June 1, 1977. Article 3(b) of the Home Rule Charter gives the city certain power, provided as follows: 
A.  To control its finances and fiscal affairs; to appropriate money for its purposes and make payment of its debts and expenses; to levy and collect taxes, excises, fees, charges and special assessments for benefits conferred, for its public and proprietary functions, activities, operations, undertakings and improvements; to contract debts, borrow money, issue bonds, warrants and other evidences of indebtedness; to establish charges for any city or other services, and to establish debt and mill levy limitations; provided that all real and personal property in order to be subject to the assessment provisions of this subsection shall be assessed in a uniform manner and; provided further that the mill levies ordered imposed by the governing body on taxable property subject to ad valorem taxation shall not exceed in total the sum of levies authorized by state statutes and the constitution for cities of similar classification to that of the city of Devils Lake, however, same may be budgeted for any city purposes. The governing body shall be permitted to promulgate the city budget without regard to the specific dedications of mill levies to specific purposes as long as the total budget is not more than the total amount of mills authorized to be levied by a city. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.040 - Funding. 
    The city will fund the purchase of the well sites, the construction of the pumps, water lines, treatment plant, and any other necessary equipment for providing water, and the acquisition of any necessary permits or easements as follows: 
A.  The city will levy taxes to retire any debt incurred by the city for these purposes from any combination levies allowed under the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.050 - Purchase of water. 
    The city may purchase water from another entity, subject to the conditions as set forth in this section: 
A.  The water needs of the city must exceed the amount of water which the city's supply and treatment system can efficiently deliver; 
B.  The purchase of additional water must be agreed to in a written agreement between the city and the entity providing the additional water; 
C.  The water owned by the city, or which the city has the right to use, shall be the first water used for city purposes, and the secondary water used shall be the water purchased by the city from the other entity; 
D.  In the event of an emergency caused by the failure or problems to the city's supply and treatment system. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.060 - Voter approval. 
    Any provision of Section 40-33-02 or 40-33-16, N.D.C.C., which may require voter approval of any provision of this chapter, are rejected, and the provisions of this chapter shall supercede any provision which may require voter approval. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.070 - Severability. 
    Should any section, provision, or part of this chapter be adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication should not affect the validity of the ordinance codified in this chapter as a whole or any section, provision or part thereof not ad-judged invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
3.13.080 - Effective date. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be effective upon its adoption. 
(Ord. 870 (part), 2006) 
Chapter 3.14 - SALES TAX REVENUE BONDS 
Section: 

3.14.010 - Sales tax revenue bonds. 
    The city of Devils Lake is hereby authorized, by resolution or resolutions of its board of city commissioners, to issue revenue bonds of the city in an amount not exceeding three million dollars for the purpose of improving the city's embankment and flood protection facilities. The resolution authorizing the issuance of the bonds may provide that the principal and interest on the bonds shall be payable from the Sales and Use Tax imposed by Chapter 3.08 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code. 
    Pursuant to Article 5, Section 1 of the Home Rule Charter and Section 1.17.020 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code, the provisions of Chapter 3.08 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code shall not be subject to referral by the citizens of Devils Lake during such time as the sales and use tax collections are required to meet the obligations of bonded indebtedness authorized by the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 885, 1-19-10) 
3.14.020 - Sales tax revenue bonds-[Water, sewer and street improvements]. 
    The city of Devils Lake is hereby authorized, by resolution or resolutions of its board of city commissioners, to issue revenue bonds of the city in an amount not exceeding three million dollars for the purpose of financing infrastructure including water, sewer and street improvements within the city. The resolution authorizing the issuance of the bonds may provide that the principal and interest on the bonds shall be payable from the sales and use tax imposed by Chapter 3.08 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code. 
    Pursuant to Article 5, Section 1 of the Home Rule Charter and Section 1.17.020 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code, the provisions of Chapter 3.08 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code shall not be subject to referral by the citizens of Devils Lake during such time as the sales and use tax collections are required to meet the obligations of bonded indebtedness authorized by this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 926, 7-20-15) 
Chapter 3.15 - VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES FOR SENIORS 
Sections: 

3.15.010 - Intention. 
    Providing volunteer activities for seniors in the City of Devils Lake are declared to be an enterprise as provided in Article X, Section 18 of the North Dakota State Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this enterprise is providing volunteer services by seniors for the benefit of the citizens of the City of Devils Lake. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.030 - Assistance to engage in enterprise. 
    The City of Devils Lake is not able to provide volunteer services by seniors without the assistance of midwest state volunteer. Midwest state volunteer is not able to provide its services without the financial assistance of the City of Devils Lake. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.040 - Findings for financial assistance. 
    The City of Devils Lake will provide financial assistance to midwest state volunteer subject to the terms and provisions of this ordinance and Chapter 3.10 of this Code. In providing financial assistance, the Devils Lake city commission makes the following findings: 
A.  Midwest state volunteer is a non-profit corporation in good standing and authorized to do business in the State of North Dakota. 
B.  Midwest state volunteer has been determined to be exempt from federal income tax under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
C.  The services provided by midwest state volunteer do not compete with private businesses in the City of Devils Lake. The services provided by midwest state volunteer are needed in the City of Devils Lake to make available volunteer services by seniors. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.050 - Procedure to obtain financial assistance. 
    The city commission may authorize a grant to midwest state volunteer to carry out the purposes of midwest state volunteer's enterprise as set out in the ordinance and codified in this chapter of this Code by the following procedure: 
A.  Midwest state volunteer shall request from the City of Devils Lake an amount of funding. 
B.  The request shall include midwest state volunteer providing written information as to how the money will be spent. This information will address how the spending of this funding will implement the purposes of this enterprise. 
C.  Midwest state volunteer shall provide to the City of Devils Lake any information, including financial, requested by the Devils Lake City Commission. 
D.  Midwest state volunteer will provide the City of Devils Lake with an accounting which shows how these funds were spent. 
E.  Midwest state volunteer will report to the Devils Lake City Commission on the activities of midwest state volunteer, which address how the purposes of the ordinance codified as Section 3.15.020 are implemented. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.060 - Qualifications for funding. 
    In order for midwest state volunteer to qualify for funding from the City of Devils Lake, the following must be met: 
A.  The purpose of this enterprise as set out in this chapter and codified as Section 3.15.020 must be met, as determined by the Devils Lake City Commission. 
B.  The findings for financial assistance, as set out in this chapter and codified as Section 3.15.040, must continue to be met, as determined by the Devils Lake City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
3.15.070 - Compliance with law. 
    Midwest state volunteer agrees that it will at all times be in compliance with and shall in no way violate federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 886, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 948, 10-16-17) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

5.04.005 - Food store employees. 
    Subject to the authorization of North Dakota Century Code, Section 12.1-30-03 (30) (1989), the following businesses are authorized to operate on Sunday: 
    Food stores operated by an owner or manager in addition to not more than thirty-five employees working in the store at one time on a Sunday. 
(Ord. 733, 1989) 
5.04.010 - License-Issued by auditor. 
    All licenses provided for by this title shall be issued by the city auditor, upon the filing with him of the authorized application and its approval by the person authorized to act thereon, and upon the payment to the city treasurer of the proper license fee. 
(Prior code § 397) 
5.04.020 - License-Recordation. 
    It shall be the duty of the city auditor to make a record of all licenses issued in a book for that purpose, including the date issued, the name of the person to whom issued, the purpose for which it is issued, the amount of the license tax received therefor, and the length of time for which issued. 
(Prior code § 398) 
5.04.030 - License-Application of fees. 
    All money paid into the city treasury under the provisions of this chapter shall be credited to and become a part of the contingent fund of this city, and shall be used for the payment of such liabilities and necessary expenses of the city as are not otherwise specially provided for in the annual appropriation bill. 
(Prior code § 399) 
5.04.040 - License-Revocation. 
    When any person to whom a license has been granted pursuant to this chapter or any other ordinance shall be convicted of violating any provisions of the ordinance relating to his business, his license may be revoked by the board of city commissioners. 
(Prior code § 400) 
5.04.050 - License-Expiration. 
A.  After June 24, 1940, all annual licenses required under any and all of the ordinances of the city, shall expire on the thirtieth day of June of each and every year following their issuance; provided, however, that this chapter shall have no application to any expiration date which may be established by state law. 
B.  Any licenses issued and in existence on June 24, 1940 and bearing a different date shall not be affected by this chapter, but upon the expiration of such licenses a new license shall expire on the thirtieth day of June following, as provided in subsection A of this section, and that the license fee for the license as provided in the ordinance which under such license issued shall be prorated according to the time from the expiration until the thirtieth day of June following. 
C.  Any provision of any ordinance of the city relating to the date of expiration of licenses which may be in conflict with this chapter is expressly repealed, and the expiration of all licenses under the ordinances of the city shall be as provided for in this section. 
(Ord. 278 §§ 1,2, 1940) 
5.04.060 - Penalty. 
    Any license not renewed by June 30th of each year shall incur a penalty on a daily basis. Such penalty shall be established by resolution of the city commission and revised as it may see fit. 
(Ord. 677(part), 1984: Ord. 635 § 3, 1979) 
Chapter 5.08 - CARNIVALS, CIRCUSES AND STREET SHOWS 

5.08.010 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation within the city to exhibit any carnival, circus, menagerie, tent show or similar show, without first obtaining a license as provided in Section 5.08.020 and paying the fee prescribed by Section 5.08.020. 
(Ord. 381 § 1(part), 1956: Ord. 238(part), 1934: prior code § 401) 
5.08.020 - License-Application requirements. 
A.  All applications for license shall be in writing and must be made by the owner or operator to the city auditor and the city auditor, with the advice and consent of the city commission, may grant a license upon the payment of the fee prescribed. Such fee shall be established by resolution of the city commission, and revised as it may see fit. 
B.  All license fees must be paid on or before the first day of showing. 
C.  Each carnival, circus, menagerie or other type of show must, at the time of making application, furnish information as to number of railroad cars, trucks, trailers, semitrailers, rides, shows and concessions, and such other information as the city auditor requires to determine the proper classification of the applicant. 
D.  Any person, firm, corporation or organization sponsoring any of the carnivals, circus exhibitions and shows mentioned in subsections A through C of this section shall provide proof of liability insurance in a minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars per person and one million dollars per occurrence prior to the issuance of any license or permit. 
(Ord. 677(part), 1984; Ord. 651, 1982: Ord. 381 § 1(part), 1956: Ord. 238(part), 1934: prior code § 402) 
Chapter 5.10 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 884, adopted August 3, 2009, in effect, repealed the former Chapter 5.10, §§ 5.10.010-5.10.110, and enacted a new Chapter 5.10 as set out herein. The former Chapter 5.10 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 761, 1991 and Ord. No. 792, 1995. 

5.10.010 - Definitions. 
    In this chapter, unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires: 
    "Merchandise" does not include the sale of livestock or agricultural products for processing, or the sale of living livestock. 
    "Transient merchant" includes any person, individual, copartnership, or corporation, either as principal or agent, who engages in, does, or transacts any temporary or transient business in the city and who does not intend to become or does not become a permanent merchant of the city. The term "transient merchant" shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business nor shall it apply to a person, firm or corporation exhibiting goods for sale concurrent with and as an adjunct to a group display, meeting, convention, or event held in or at a publicly-owned or operated building or facility or sales of merchandise damaged by smoke or fire, or of bankrupt condition where such stocks have been acquired from merchants of the city thereof engaged in business; provided, however, no stocks of merchandise shall be augmented by new goods. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.020 - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or for any agent, servant or employee of any person or entity to engage in, carry on, or conduct the sale of merchandise as a transient merchant, without first obtaining a license to do so. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.030 - Application. 
    Any transient merchant desiring to engage in, do, or transact business, or the sale of merchandise, by auction or otherwise, in the city of Devils Lake, shall file an application for a license for that purpose with the city auditor which shall be in writing and include the following: 
A.  Applicant's name, present address, present home address, present business address, and date of birth. 
B.  Applicant's residence and business address for the prior two-year period, if different from the present residence and address. 
C.  Type of business in which applicant has been engaged in the previous two years. 
D.  Location of the business to be licensed. 
E.  Kind of business to be conducted. 
F.  The dates and hours when sales will be conducted in the city of Devils Lake. 
G.  An itemized list of merchandise to be offered for sale, reciting as to each type a description thereof including serial number, if any, the owner's actual cost thereof, and a designation by number corresponding with the number to be affixed to each item by a tag which shall be kept fastened to the item at all times until sold. 
H.  The location where the transient merchant will conduct business in the city. 
I.  The name and address of each political subdivision where the applicant has submitted an applicant for a transient merchant license in the past six months. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.040 - Fee. 
    The application in Section 5.10.040 shall be accompanied by a non-refundable license fee which is required of all transient merchants for the transaction of such business within the city of Devils Lake as is contemplated in and provided by NDCC Section 51-04-09 and any subsequent amendments. This fee is fixed at the sum of fifty dollars per day, for each and every day during which any such transient merchant shall transact business in the city of Devils Lake, or the sum of five hundred dollars for a permit for a period of ninety days. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.050 - Bond. 
    Any person desiring to transact business within the city of Devils Lake as a transient merchant shall, along with the application fee for a license, include with the application in Section 5.10.030 a surety bond or deposit of cash in lieu thereof, to the city auditor in the amount of five thousand dollars (the surety of which shall be a surety company authorized to transact business in the state of North Dakota). The contents and surety therein shall be subject to the approval of the city auditor, and be conditioned that the applicant will, in all things, conform to the laws relating to transient merchants and further conditioned upon full compliance with all material, oral or written statements and representations made by the applicant, the applicant's agents, representatives, or auctioneers with reference to merchandise sold or offered for sale, or faithful performance under all warranties made with reference thereto. The bond shall not be revocable nor terminate prior to the passage of two years' time after the expiration of the license issued pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.060 - Applicants license by attorney general. 
    No transient merchant's license shall be issued to any applicant unless the applicant provides written proof that such person has obtained a valid and current license as a transient merchant from the attorney general of the state of North Dakota as required by Chapter 51-04 of the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.070 - Location. 
    The holder of a transient merchant license shall conduct business in one location, but may go to other locations upon invitation. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.080 - Exemption. 
    An organization which is a bona fide nonprofit veterans, charitable, educational, religious, fraternal, civic and service club organization, or other public spirited organization as defined by the provisions of Chapter 53-06.1 of the North Dakota Century Code, and any bona fide school, service club or youth organization is not required to have a transient merchant license in order to conduct sales which would otherwise require such a license under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.090 - Sales in public facilities exempted. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to sales conducted in or at a publicly owned or operated building, park, or facilities as part of a civic event provided such sales are approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.100 - License display. 
    Any transient merchant licensed hereunder shall prominently display the license at the licensed location. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
5.10.120 - Penalty. 
    Any person who engages in business within the city of Devils Lake as a transient merchant without first obtaining a license to do so as herein provided shall be subject to a penalty of up to five hundred dollars. Each day a person conducts business in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be a separate offense and shall be punishable accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 884, 8-3-09) 
Chapter 5.12 - CONTRACTORS 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
    In this chapter, unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires: 
A.  "Contractor" means any person, as defined in subsection B of this section, who engages in construction work for consideration, including builders, carpenters, painters, plasterers, electricians, plumbers, heating contractors and any other person engaged in similar type work for others; however, any such person engaged in such work solely for himself or his neighbor and without compensation shall not be included in this definition. 
B.  "Person" includes any individual, firm, copartnership, association, corporation, or other group or combination thereof acting as a unit, and the plural as well as the singular number, unless the intent to give a more limited meaning is disclosed clearly by the context thereof. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 1, 1974) 
5.12.020 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to do business in the city as a contractor as defined in subsection A of Section 5.12.010 without having first secured a license therefor as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 2, 1974) 
5.12.030 - License-Exemption. 
    Any contractor as defined in subsection A of Section 5.12.010 who has a state contractors license pursuant to Chapter 43-07 of the North Dakota Century Code shall not be required to obtain a license from the city pursuant to this chapter to engage in business within the city limits. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 3, 1974) 
5.12.040 - License-Fee. 
    The license fee to be required of all contractors as defined in subsection A of Section 5.12.010 to engage in business within the city is fixed at the sum of one hundred fifty dollars per year or for any portion of a year. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 4, 1974) 
5.12.050 - License-Application. 
    Applicants for license under this chapter, when an individual, copartnership or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the city auditor, showing: 
A.  Applicant's name, present address, present home address, present business address, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
B.  The name, present residence, present home address, and present business address of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; 
C.  The residence, business address, and type of business in which applicant has been engaged in the previous two years; 
D.  The residence, business address, and type of business in which the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business has been engaged in the previous two years; 
E.  The place or places in the city, where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; 
F.  The kind of business to be conducted. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 5, 1974) 
5.12.060 - License-Bond. 
    Before any license is issued to a contractor for engaging in business in this city, the applicant therefor shall file with the city auditor a bond running to the city the sum of five thousand dollars executed by the applicant, as principal, and a responsible surety upon which service of process may be made in the state; the bond not to be revocable nor to terminate prior to passage of two years' time after the expiration of the license issued pursuant thereto nor until due notice that the terms of the bond are to be canceled has been given to the city auditor; the bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state, regulating contractors and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of the ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with the applicant, whether the misrepresentation or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 6, 1974) 
5.12.070 - License-Posted. 
    The license issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named in the license. In the event that the person or persons applying for the license desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 7, 1974) 
5.12.080 - License-Transfer. 
    No license issued to a contractor in the city shall be transferred. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 8, 1974) 
5.12.090 - License-Enforcement by city engineer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this chapter, to determine if this chapter has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 9, 1974) 
5.12.100 - License-Revocation. 
A.  Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the governing body of the city, after notice and hearing for the following causes: 
1.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
2.  Any violation of this chapter; 
3.  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
4.  Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
B.  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 10, 1974) 
5.12.110 - License-Expiration. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire at the expiration of the period for which application has been made and prepaid, to be renewable by the city auditor upon application and payment therefor. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 5 § 11, 1974) 
Chapter 5.16 - GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALES 

5.16.010 - Application for license. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to go out of business and conduct a going out of business sale shall first apply to the office of the city auditor for a license for the purpose of conducting the going out of business sale. 
(Ord. 558 § 1, 1974) 
5.16.020 - Cost of license. 
    The cost of obtaining the license for the purpose of conducting a going out of business sale shall be established by resolution of the city commission, and revised as it may see fit. Such fee shall be payable to the city auditor. 
(Ord. 677(part), 1984: Ord. 558 § 2, 1974) 
5.16.025 - Documents describing merchandise required-Sale restrictions. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that shall apply for a going-out-of-business license shall furnish, at the time of application for the sale, a copy of all orders for merchandise made prior to the application which have not yet been received by the applicant. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation which shall engage in a going-out-of-business sale shall, during the time of the going-out-of-business sale, offer for sale only lines of merchandise that were sold on the premises prior to issuance of the license by the city. 
(Ord. 672A, 1984) 
5.16.030 - Length of sale. 
    No such person, firm or corporation engaged in business in the city shall conduct any such going out of business sale for a period of not to exceed ninety days; however, the length of the going out of business sale may be restricted to sixty days or thirty days and the length of any such going out of business sale shall be determined by the city commission, taking into consideration such factors as the type of business involved, the type of merchandise to be sold at the sale, and all other conditions then existing. 
(Ord. 558 § 3, 1974) 
5.16.040 - Procuring of merchandise prohibited. 
    No such person, firm or corporation which engages in the conducting of a going out of business sale shall procure, order or obtain from any source any merchandise to be sold at the going out of business sale, which merchandise is obtained by such person, firm or corporation after the application for a going out of business sale is submitted to the city auditor pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. 558 § 4, 1974) 
5.16.050 - Advertisement to include license number. 
    Any advertisement by any person, firm or corporation of any going out of business sale shall include the license number of the license obtained pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 558 § 5, 1974) 
Chapter 5.24 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

5.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases have the meanings respectively ascribed herein: 
    "Alcoholic beverages" means any liquid intended for drinking by humans which contains one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume which is fit or intended for use for beverage purposes. 
    "Beer" means any alcoholic beverages that is of the alcohol content provided by the laws of the state in defining the word "beer." 
    "Food and beverage specialty license" means a license which permits the sale of beer and/or wine at retail, subject to the following: 
1.  Beer and wine only. 
2.  Beer only. 
    "Habitual drunkard" is a person who is habitually addicted to the use of any or all intoxicating liquors, regularly becomes intoxicated, or who, by reason of habitual intemperance drinking of intoxicating liquor is at times dangerous to himself or herself or others, or is incapable of managing himself or herself and his or her affairs. 
1.  Any person who has been incarcerated for the purpose of detoxification, or any person who has been arrested for any offense against the peace while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or a combination of such offenses more than five times in a twelve-month period, shall be deemed to be a habitual drunkard for the purpose of this chapter. 
2.  It is not necessary that such person be intoxicated most of the time, or have lost the will power to resist alcoholic drinks. 
3.  For the purposes of this definition, it is not necessary to prove the means of the intoxication is by drinking alcoholic beverages as defined herein, but only that the person was intoxicated by alcohol introduced into the person's system in some form regardless of the intended use of the alcohol. 
    "Hotel-motel license" means a special license that permits the sale of all alcoholic beverages on an on-sale and off-sale basis. 
    "Intoxicated person" means a person who displays signs and symptoms commonly associated with over consumption of alcoholic beverages. These signs and symptoms include, but are not limited to, any of the following: Strong odor of alcohol, poor balance, staggering, swaying, slurred speech, loud or obnoxious behavior, blood shot or watery eyes, vomiting, grogginess, poor hand-eye coordination, fighting behavior, or any combination thereof. 
    "Licensed premises" means that premises on which alcoholic beverages are normally sold or dispensed and shall be delineated by diagram or blueprint which shall be included with the license application or the license renewal application. Licensed premises includes all areas where alcoholic beverages are routinely stored, displayed, opened or mixed, and all lounges, bars and restaurants where alcoholic beverages are dispensed. Meeting rooms, banquet rooms or other rooms not part of the licensed premises may be leased by groups or individuals for private events, such as receptions, banquets and similar events at which alcoholic beverages may be consumed provided that the licensee does not open, mix or dispense alcoholic beverages in those areas not licensed. 
    "Licensee" means the person to whom a license has been issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
    "Liquor" means any alcoholic beverage other than beer. 
    "Lodge" or "club" means any corporation or association organized for civic, fraternal, social or business purposes, or for the promotion of sports, which has at least two hundred members at the time a license is applied for pursuant to this chapter. 
    "Off-sale" means the sale of alcoholic beverages in original packages for consumption off or away from the premises where sold. Off-sale is restricted to businesses with a Class I, II, III, IV, or V license. 
    "On-sale" means the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises where sold. 
    "Packages" and "original package" means any container or receptacle holding alcoholic beverages which is corked or sealed by the manufacturer and which cork or seal has not been removed or broken prior to the sale of such package to the purchaser. 
    "Person" means persons, partnerships, other unincorporated associations and corporations. 
    "Sale" means any transfer, exchange, or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration, and includes all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor, agent, servant or employee. 
    "Sell at retail" or "sale at retail" means a sale to a consumer for use consumption and not for the purpose of resale in any form. 
    "Supper club license" means a special license to sell alcoholic beverages on an on-sale and off-sale basis, which may be issued to steak, seafood or similarly menued supper clubs having a seating capacity of one hundred or more seats arranged in supper club style (i.e. adequate room to safely accommodate the number of tables required to have people seated two to eight persons to a table. 
    "Transfer" means any assignment, sale, exchange or other conveyance of any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. A transfer shall be deemed to have occurred upon the assignment, sale, exchange or other conveyance of fifty percent or more of the interest in a licensee partnership or stock in a licensee corporation, whether such assignment, sale, exchange or other conveyance occurred in one single transaction or multiple transactions. However, the term "transfer" shall not apply to the following described conveyances: 
1.  When an individual holding a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter has become deceased, the license may, upon application of the personal representative of the decedent, be transferred to another individual, partnership, firm or corporation; 
2.  When a corporation holding a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter voluntarily dissolves, a license may be issued to an individual shareholder in such corporation who held said stock at the time of the issuance or last renewal of the license and whose application is approved by the holders owning a majority of the outstanding shares of stock in the corporation prior to the time of dissolution; provided, however, that such shareholder shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter relating to the application for a license and to the qualifications of a licensee; 
3.  When an individual licensee desires to transfer a license to a corporation in which the licensee is the owner of at least a majority of the outstanding shares of stock in said corporation; provided, however, that such licensee may not permit his stock ownership in the transferee corporation to fall below the majority of the outstanding stock in said corporation without the prior approval of the commission and reapplication for license by the transferee corporation. The transferee corporation shall be subject to all the requirements of this chapter relating to the application for a license and the qualifications of a license; 
4.  When a licensee is a corporation or partnership which desires to transfer a license to another corporation or partnership having substantially the same partners or stockholders; provided, however, that such transferee corporation or partnership shall be subject to all the requirements of this chapter relating to the application for a license and the qualifications of a licensee; 
5.  When an individual licensee desires to transfer a license to a blood relative of the first degree, as defined by the North Dakota Century Code, or to a grandchild of the individual licensee if the grandchild's parents are deceased. For purposes of this subsection only conveyance of shares of stock in a licensee corporation shall not be considered a transfer if the person seeking to convey shares of stock owns at least a majority of the outstanding shares of stock in said corporation; 
6.  When a majority of the entire commission adopts a resolution and declares the conveyance not to be a transfer for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
(Ord. No. 905, 10-15-12) 
5.24.020 - Applicability of chapter-Exceptions. 
    This chapter is declared to be an exercise of the police power directly affecting and designed to promote the peace, safety, good order, health, and well-being of the people of the city. This chapter shall apply to all territory within the city and to such outlying contiguous territory without the corporate limits within which the city may exercise police jurisdiction as defined by law, provided, however, that the following exceptions shall be noted to the applicability hereof: 
A.  This chapter shall not apply to wines delivered to priests, rabbis and ministers for sacramental use. 
B.  This chapter shall not be construed to apply to the following articles, when they are unfit for beverage purposes: 
1.  Denatured alcohol produced and used pursuant to acts of Congress, and the regulations thereunder; 
2.  Patent, proprietary, medical, pharmaceutical, antiseptic, and toilet preparations; 
3.  Flavoring extracts, syrups and food products; 
4.  Scientific, chemical and industrial products, nor to the manufacture or sale of said articles containing alcohol. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.030 - License-Required. 
A.  A person may not sell at retail within the city limits of Devils Lake any alcoholic beverages without first having obtained a license therefor as herein provided. This section does not apply to public carriers engaged in interstate commerce. 
B.  A license may not be issued to any person engaged in business as the representative or agent of another. A license may be issued only to the owner or owners of the business being conducted at the location sought to be licensed. 
C.  The individual to be responsible for compliance with all city ordinances who is named in the license application must be the owner if the licensee is an individual, a partner or manager if the licensee is a partnership or other unincorporated association, and an officer of the corporation or manager if the licensee is a corporation. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.040 - License-Term. 
A.  All licenses issued hereunder shall be for a period of not more than one year and shall expire on the thirtieth day of June in each year. Where a license is granted for a period less than a year any subsequent renewal thereof must be made for the full annual term. 
B.  When the application is made for the transfer of an existing retail liquor and beer license, permitting the retail sales of alcoholic beverages during the license year for the unexpired portion of such year for said license, the proposed transferee for said license shall pay a transfer fee to the city in the amount of one hundred dollars for administrative processing purposes. Said license, if allowed to be transferred, shall then remain in full force and effect until the expiration of the term for which it was issued without payment of any additional fee by either party thereto. 
(Ord. 781, 1993: Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.050 - Classes of licenses, fees and limitation of number issued. 
A.  The board finds that in order to ensure compliance by all licensees with all applicable federal, state and city laws, ordinances and regulations, and in order to adequately police all licensed establishments and to promote the public welfare, it is necessary and proper to limit the number of licenses issued pursuant to the city's police powers and authority granted by Title 5, NDCC. 
B.  Pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the number of Class IV and V retail licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city shall be based upon the population of the city itself. Such population figures will hereafter be determined according to the official census last taken. All other license classifications hereunder shall not be limited by number or included in any population-license ration if any application therefore otherwise meets and satisfies the other provisions and requirements for the issuance hereof. 
C.  The city commission does further acknowledge that twenty-three retail licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages are in full force and effect in the city upon the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
    Each license is given a number by the city auditor. With each number the city auditor shall include the class, holder of the license, and business name if different than the holder of the license. 
    To insure that said licenses remain in full force and effect and otherwise are in compliance herewith upon the enactment of the ordinance codified in this chapter, the city commission does deem it necessary and reasonable to classify all existing licenses in the following manner by each license number: 
1.  Class I license and Sunday Special Permit; 
2.  Class I license and Sunday Special Permit; 
3.  Class I license and Sunday Special Permit; 
4.  Class I license; 
5.  Class III license and Sunday Special Permit; 
6.  Class IV license; 
7.  Class II license and Sunday Special Permit; 
8.  Class VI license and Sunday Special Permit; 
9.  Class VI license and Sunday Special Permit; 
10.  Class VI license and Sunday Special Permit; 
11.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
12.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
13.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
14.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
15.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
16.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
17.  Class IV license; 
18.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
19.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
20.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
21.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit; 
22.  Class VI license and Sunday Special Permit; and 
23.  Class IV license and Sunday Special Permit. 
    Each of the foregoing licenses has been designated in accordance with the provisions hereof and assigned the above permanent license which shall identify said license until such time as the license terminates through revocation or cancellation. The transfer of any such license shall not change the number so assigned. In the event, however, that any of the foregoing Class IV or V licenses are subsequently revoked or cancelled through voluntary action of the licensee or involuntarily through the action of the city commission, such license(s) may be reissued to any eligible application without regard to the population-license ratio as otherwise applicable herein. 
D.  The city commission shall at its discretion, hereafter issue only one additional Class IV or Class V retail license for the sale of alcoholic beverages, notwithstanding the licenses already issued in such classification, for each one thousand population increase for the city which exceeds the city's present population of seven thousand four hundred forty-two. 
E.  Provided further, that in the event any area is annexed into the city pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 40.51.2, NDCC and said area contains licensed retail liquor establishments thereon, the city commission shall be empowered at its discretion and upon proper application by said annexed licensee to issue a retail license within the designated classification as deemed appropriate to sell alcoholic beverages within the city without limitation to the population-license ration otherwise applicable herein. 
F.  Licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages are divided into the following classes for the purpose of determining the number of licenses to be issued and outstanding: 
1.  Class I License. To any nationally organized fraternal order, club or any nationally organized service or veteran's organization which is under the control and supervision of a national organization of officers. A Class I license shall authorize the license to sell alcoholic beverages on-sale or off-sale. 
2.  Class II License. To the operator of a supper club food and beverage establishment. The license may not be transferred and must be held only by the operator who has been awarded the license and be held only for the period of the operator's license and shall terminate with the termination of the food and beverage establishment. A Class II license shall authorize the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages on-sale and off-sale. 
3.  Class III License. To a hotel or motel that provides at least fifty rooms for transient guests with continuous service and dining facilities with a seating capacity of at least fifty seats as a part of the hotel or motel operations and a full menu normally provided by a restaurant, and maintained and open seven days a week. The fifty seats for dining facilities are in addition to seating facilities for customers of the liquor facilities. A Class III license authorizes the licensee to sell on-sale and off-sale. However, this restriction does not preclude customary room service to registered guests of the licensee. 
4.  Class IV License. To any applicant for the on-sale and off-sale of alcoholic beverages other than applicants in other classifications hereof. 
5.  Class V License. To any applicant for the sale at retail for off-sale. 
6.  Class VI License. To any applicant for a specialty restaurant license to sell beer and/or wine in conjunction with food sales at retail, subject, however, to the following: 
a.  Gross sales of alcoholic beverages may not be greater than forty percent of total gross sales of food and alcoholic beverages. All Class VI license holders shall file with the application for license renewal a statement certifying gross food sales and liquor sales for the previous calendar year. The board of city commissioners may, in its discretion, require certification of any statement by a certified public accountant, retained by the licensee. All sales of alcoholic beverages by Class VI licensees must be separately receipted to the customer by cash register receipt and clearly identified as sales of beer or wine on all receipts. 
b.  The license is for on-sale only, and off-sale is not permitted. A cessation of business at a licensed location for a period of ninety days or longer shall constitute cause to revoke such license pursuant to Section 5.24.110(A)(2). 
c.  Once a license has been established at a particular location, the license may not be transferred to another location without prior approval of the city commission. 
d.  The licensee may not permit public dances or dancing of any kind on said premises. 
e.  Specialty restaurant licenses shall only be issued to specialty restaurants having a seating capacity of seventy-five or more people. 
f.  Specialty restaurants must be constructed so that minors not accompanied by adults are seated in an area separate from the area where tap beer and/or wine is served. 
g.  Any specialty license issued under this section shall be cancelled if for any reason the licensee ceases to be qualified as the specialty for which the license was issued. 
7.  Class VII License. To any organization, corporation or association that functions on less than a daily basis and is operational less than one hundred days in a calendar year. These special occasion clubs primarily cater to members and their guests. 
a.  The license is for on-sale only, and off-sale is not permitted. 
b.  Once a license has been established at a certain location, the license may not be transferred to another location without prior approval of the city commission. 
c.  Special occasion clubs must be constructed so that minors will not have access to the area where liquor is served. 
d.  Section 5.24.110(A)(2), requiring suspension or revocation of a license if licensee ceases business at the location for a period of ninety days or more, does not apply to the Class VII license. 
e.  Any license issued under this section shall be cancelled if for any reason the licensee ceases to be qualified as the entity for which the license was issued. 
8.  Class VIII License. To the owner or licensee of any hotel in the city, containing twenty or more rooms. A license issued pursuant to this paragraph, however, may not be used for the off-sale of alcoholic beverages, except to registered guests thereof. 
9.  Class IX License. To an applicant for the sale of retail on-sale or off-sale, wine and beer only. A Class IX license will be issued in the sole discretion of the Devils Lake City Commission. The annual license fee for a Class IX license shall be set each year by the city commission, in the fees and rates. A Class IX license is subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The sale, dispensing, or consumption of wine and beer is allowed in only the licensed premises of the retail establishment. 
b.  The only alcohol sold, dispensed or consumed is wine and beer. 
c.  On-sale or off-sale of wine and beer on the licensed premises is permitted. 
d.  Gross sale of alcoholic beverages may not be greater than thirty percent of the total gross sales of all other items sold at retail and alcoholic beverages. All Class IX license holders shall file with the application for license renewal a statement certifying gross retail sales and wine and beer sales for the previous calendar year. The board of city commissioners may, in its discretion, require certification of any statement by a certified public accountant, retained by the licensee. 
e.  A partition dividing the licensed premises from the remainder of the retail store shall be installed. This partition shall allow customers and employees of the retail store access between the licensed premises and non-licensed premises, subject to the restrictions of minors in the licensed premises. 
f.  Minors are not allowed in the licensed premises, except as permitted by NDCC §5-02-06. 
g.  A retail store containing the licensed premises must be operational and open during regular business hours. The retail store must be open for business for wine and beer to be sold, dispensed, or consumed. 
h.  The maximum number of seats for the licensed premises shall not exceed twenty-five. 
i.  The square footage of the licensed premises shall not exceed twenty-five percent of the total square footage of the retail store, including the licensed premises. 
j.  Once a license has been established at a particular location, the license may not be transferred to another location without prior approval of the city commission. 
G.  The board of city commissioners may further provide in any license issued pursuant to this chapter the right of an eating establishment to dispense and sell beer and wine in conjunction with the sale of prepared meals on Sunday between the hours of twelve noon and nine p.m. for consumption only in the part of the eating establishment habitually used for the servicing or prepared meals.
