As used in this section, "eating establishment" means a restaurant, lodge, club or other commercial establishment that is licensed to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail pursuant to this chapter, and which derives fifty percent or more of its annual gross receipts from the sale of prepared meals and not alcoholic beverages. Whenever this provision for Sunday beer and wine sales is requested, commissioners shall require the licensee to pay an additional annual fee of seventy-five dollars. 
(Ord. 787, 1994: Ord. 775, 1992: Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
(Ord. No. 896, 7-5-11; Ord. No. 932, 2-16-16; Ord. No. 944, 12-5-16; Ord. No. 960, 2-22-19) 
5.24.060 - License qualifications for any applicant. 
A.  A license may not be issued or transferred under this chapter except to persons possessing the following qualifications: 
1.  Applicant, if an individual, must be a legal resident of the United States and a resident of the state and be a person of good moral character; 
2.  If applicant is a partnership or a corporation, the manager of the licensed premises must be a resident of the state and person of good moral character and the partners or officers, directors and stockholders must be legal residents of the United States and persons of good moral character. Corporate applicants must be properly registered with the Secretary of State. The manager must possess all of the qualifications required of an applicant; 
3.  Applicant cannot have had revoked, in the previous five years, any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages; 
4.  Applicant must be the owner or lessee of the licensed premises during the entire period licensed; 
5.  The building in which the business is conducted must meet all local and state requirements regarding sanitation and safety; 
6.  Property taxes for the building in which the licensed premises are located may not be delinquent. 
B.  A license may not be issued to an applicant if the applicant or manager has been convicted of any of the following offenses within the previous five years, and it is determined that the applicant or manager has not been rehabilitated within the meaning of Section 12.1-33-02.1, NDCC, or that the offense has a direct bearing on the person's ability to serve the public in the liquor business: 
1.  Any felony; 
2.  Any offense involving the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession for sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages; 
3.  Any offense involving the sale of drugs or felony possession of drugs; 
4.  Prostitution; 
5.  Obsenity; 
6.  Two or more convictions for driving under the influence of alcohol or actual physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol; 
7.  Any other offense determined by the board of city commissioners to have a direct bearing on the applicant's or manager's ability to serve the public as an alcoholic beverage retailer. 
    In the application of this section, it shall be presumed that a violation of subdivisions 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 of subsection B of this section has a direct bearing on the person's ability to serve the public. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.070 - License application-Investigation of applicant's fitness. 
    Any person desiring a license to sell alcoholic beverages at retail as described in this chapter shall make and present a written verified application to the city commission of the city of Devils Lake, North Dakota, and file the same with the city auditor, containing the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; if the applicant is a copartnership, the name and address and place of residence of each member of said copartnership; if the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of the officers of the corporation and the manager of the licensed premises. 
2.  Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States, and if a naturalized citizen, the date and place of naturalization and the place of residence of the applicant for a period of one year last preceding the date of application; if the applicant is a copartnership the same preceding information of each member of said copartnership; and if the applicant is a corporation, the date of incorporation, the state where incorporated, and if such corporation is a subsidiary of any corporation, the name of the parent corporation. 
3.  The legal description and the address of the premises for which license is sought. 
4.  The date on which the applicant acquired title to the premises sought to be licensed, and if the applicant does not have title to said premises, the name and address of the owner of the premises together with a copy of the applicant's lease under which he holds possession of said premises. 
5.  Whether there are any delinquent taxes against the premises sought to be licensed. 
6.  Whether the applicant has ever engaged in the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages prior to this application, and if so, the date and type of business and place where so engaged, whether within or without the state, and if the application is for a renewal license, the date the applicant first began to operate. 
7.  Whether the applicant has ever had a license revoked or canceled by any municipal, state or federal authority, and if so, the date of such cancellation, the place and authority canceling same, and the reason for such cancellation. 
8.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the violation of any law of the United States or of any state, or of the violation of any local ordinance, with regard to the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession of alcoholic beverages, and if so, the dates, name of places, and courts in which said convictions were had. 
9.  Whether the applicant has ever had a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages revoked for any violation of state laws or local ordinances, of if so, the names of the bodies revoking such license, the dates of such revocation, and the reasons assigned therefor. 
10.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any other crime than stated in subsections 8 and 9 of this section, in this state or any other state, or under any federal law, and if so, the date of such conviction, the name of the crime for which convicted, the amount and terms of sentence passed, and the court in which convicted. 
11.  The name and address and the place of residence for a period of one year prior to the date of application of any person who will have charge, management, or control of the establishment for which license is sought. 
12.  Whether any other person than the applicant has any right, title, estate or interest in the leasehold or in the furniture, fixtures, or equipment in the premises for which license is sought, and if so, the name and address of such person, together with a statement of the interest so held. 
13.  Whether the applicant has any interest whatsoever, directly or indirectly, in any other establishment dispensing alcoholic beverages, either at wholesale or retail, within or without the state, and if so, the names and addresses of such establishments. This provision is meant to include the holders of capital stock in any corporation dealing in alcoholic beverages, either at wholesale or retail, and within the borders of the United States. 
14.  The occupations which the applicant has followed during the past five years. 
15.  The names and addresses of at least three business references. 
16.  Whether the applicant is rated by any commercial agency, and if so, the name and address of said agency. 
17.  Whether the applicant is engaged in any other business or intends to be engaged in any other business than the sale of alcoholic beverages under the license for which application is made, and if so, the type of business, and if any employee, the name and address of the employer. 
18.  The classification of license applied for. 
19.  If the applicant is a lodge or a club, the date of organization, the number of members, the purpose for which organized, and the purpose for which profits to be derived from the sale of alcoholic beverages are to be applied and whenever required by the city commission, a list of the members belonging to such lodge or club. 
20.  Whether or not the property taxes of the applicant are delinquent, and if a copartnership, whether or not the property taxes of each member or the copartnership are delinquent, and whether or not the property taxes levied against the property to be used in conducting the business are delinquent. 
21.  A statement by the applicant that he consents to entry and inspection of the premises for which license is sought or any part thereof at any time by any police officer, sheriff, or any peace officer of the city or of the state, and that said applicant waives all rights, constitutional or otherwise, against unreasonable searches or seizures, and further consents that any alcoholic beverages or any other property found upon said premises which is held therein in violation of the laws of the state or in violation of this chapter may be seized and taken away by such officer, and that such alcoholic beverages or other property so seized may be received in evidence against him in any procedure brought pursuant to the laws of the state or pursuant to this chapter. 
22.  The chief of police or such other person or officer as may be designated by the city commission shall, upon the filing of an application, investigate the facts as stated in the application and the character, reputation and fitness of the applicant, and shall report on said matters to the city commission. In addition to the facts and information that is requested on the application forms, the designated investigator is authorized by the licensing authority to request from the applicant any other information the investigator considers necessary to make a determination of the fitness of the applicant, including but not limited to information pertaining to financing of the proposed establishment and other business interests of the applicant, or of the appli-cant's stockholders in the case of a corporate applicant. It shall be a requirement of any applicant to furnish the designated investigator with the information that he may request, and denial of such a request by any applicant shall be considered a violation of the alcoholic beverage license ordinances of the city and thereby disqualify the applicant from any further consideration. The provisions of this section shall apply equally to applicants for new licenses and applicants for license renewals. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.080 - License transfers and site locations-Restrictions. 
A.  A license may not be issued and/or transferred to engage in the sale of any alcoholic beverages within the city, or any license transferred to a new or different location, without license application and site approval by the board of city commissioners. 
B.  The hearing for license application and site location approval must be within twenty days of the filing of the license application. Public notice of the hearing must be published in the official newspaper one time, the publication being at least seven days prior to the hearing date. 
C.  At the hearing the board of city commissioners shall take the following factors into account to determine if the proposed site for the licensed business is proper: 
1.  Public convenience and necessity; 
2.  The proposed location to any church, public or parochial school, public library, hospital, college or university building used for academic purposes; 
3.  Compliance of proposed site with the applicable building code requirements; 
4.  Compliance of proposed site with the applicable health and sanitation ordinance; 
5.  A license application must be approved upon determination of the board that the applicant meets the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 786, 1994: Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.090 - Licenses-Limitation of number issued to license holder. 
A.  Not more than two licenses of a specific classification shall be issued or granted to any applicant who is already a license holder in the city, and each license shall be valid only for the specific premises licensed. 
B.  Not more than two licenses of a specific classification shall be issued or granted to any partnership, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, corporation, limited liability corporation, or other entity existing under North Dakota law. No license may be issued to any entity authorized to exist under North Dakota law if any person having an interest in the applicant entity holds or has an interest in an entity holding more than two licenses of the same classification sought by the applicant entity. 
C.  No license shall be issued or granted to any applicant who is employed in any capacity in connection with two or more licenses of the same classification. 
D.  No license shall be issued to any member of the immediate family or household of any person who holds two or more licenses of the same classification within the city or within a one-half mile radius of the city. 
(Ord. 848, 2001; Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.100 - Posting of licenses. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter must be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises for which issued. 
(Ord. 711 § 2 (part), 1988) 
5.24.110 - License termination, suspension, revocation and hearing provisions. 
A.  Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be revoked or suspended temporarily for any one or more of the following reasons: 
1.  The death of the licensee, unless upon application to the commission by the personal representative of the deceased, the board consents to the carrying on of such business by the personal representative. 
2.  When the licensee ceases business at the location licensed for a period of ninety days or more, or does not commence operations within nine months of the issuance of a new license or approval of a transfer to a new location. 
3.  When the licensee is convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter. 
4.  When the licensee ceases to be a bona fide legal resident and citizen of the state as required. 
5.  When the license or permit of the licensee from the state is suspended or revoked. 
6.  When the licensee is convicted of a crime or crimes such that the licensee would not, pursuant to Section 5-01-05, be qualified to be issued a license. 
7.  When the business of the licensee at the location licensed is conducted in violation of the health and sanitary regulations or other ordinances of the city. 
8.  When the licensee ceases to meet any of the qualifications required for issuance of a license. 
9.  When the licensee permits drunken, inebriate or disorderly persons to frequent the place of business. 
10.  When the licensee fails to pay when due property taxes or license fees. 
11.  When the licensee fails to pay the designated annual license fee for said license and more than ten days from its due date has elapsed. 
    The causes enumerated above are not all inclusive and the board of city commissioners retains and reserves the right to suspend or revoke the license for any cause which it may deem sufficient. 
B.  Hearing for Revocation or Suspension. 
1.  Before any license may be revoked or suspended for cause, the board shall notify the licensee of the proposed action and the right to a hearing on the action. The notice shall specify the action proposed to be taken, the reason for it, the time and place of the hearing, and the right of the licensee to appear. The notice must be mailed to the licensee by certified return receipt mail, not less than five days nor more than fifteen days before the hearing. A record of the hearing must be made as specified by Section 5-02-10, NDCC. 
2.  If after the hearing the board finds the violation charged has been proved by the evidence, the board shall issue its findings of fact, conclusions and order, which shall be served on the licensee. The order is appealable to the district court as specified in Chapter 28-32, NDCC. The order is stayed while the appeal is pending. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.120 - Restrictions on sale, service and dispensing of alcoholic beverages. 
A.  Sale or Use in Street Prohibited. The sale, serving or consumption of alcoholic beverages upon any street, alley, public way or area used principally for public parking is prohibited without prior approval of the city commission. No person shall have in his or her possession or control in any such public place any intoxicating beverage in any package, bottle or container, unless the package, bottle or container is sealed and stamped as required by the laws of the state and that such package, bottle or container has not been opened or the seal broken. 
B.  Solicitation of Drinks. No person shall frequent or loiter in any tavern, cabaret, bar or night club, with the purpose of soliciting persons to purchase drinks. No proprietor or operator of any such establishment shall allow the presence in the establishment of any person who solicits other persons to purchase drinks. 
C.  Acts Prohibited on Licensed Premises. A licensee at all times shall maintain good order in and about the premises licensed; he shall not permit, nor suffer, any carousing, boisterous conduct or behavior within or on such licensed premises. Nor shall any such licensed premises have or suffer others to have or maintain in such licensed premises, any slot machines, other gambling devices, or games of chance, except as permitted by state law and city ordinance pertaining to charitable gambling in any room or place in any building wherein any intoxicating beverages are retailed, and which room or place may be occupied by the license holder. It is unlawful for any licensee, or his agents, servants, employees, or any other persons whosoever, to permit any minor or any other person under the age of twenty-one years to sell or aid or assist in the sale of or in the delivery of intoxicating beverages on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. 731, 1989; Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.130 - Limitation on hours and days of sale. 
    No licensee shall dispense or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on licensed premises or permit other persons to remain on such licensed premises after two a.m. on Sundays, before eleven a.m. on Sundays, or between the hours of two a.m. and eight a.m. on all other days of the week, nor shall licensee dispense alcoholic beverages or permit consumption thereof on the licensed premises on Christmas Day, after two a.m. on Thanksgiving Day, or after six p.m. on Christmas Eve. 
(Ord. 869, 2005: Ord. 780, 1993) 
(Ord. No. 931, 9-21-15) 
5.24.140 - Employment of minors prohibited. 
    No person under twenty-one years of age shall be employed in any room or rooms constituting the place in which alcoholic beverages are sold, except as is permitted by state statute. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.150 - Sale to minors and certain persons prohibited. 
A.  Persons Under Twenty-one Years Prohibited. In accord with NDCC 5-02-06, no licensee shall dispense alcoholic beverages to a person under twenty-one years of age or permit such a person to remain on the licensed premises while alcoholic beverages are being sold or displayed; provided, however, that any person under twenty-one years of age may remain in a restaurant where alcoholic beverages are being sold if accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, or if employed by the restaurant as a food waiter, food waitress, busboy under the direct supervision of a person over twenty-one years of age, and not engaged in the sale, disposition, delivery or consumption of alcoholic beverages. Any establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold may employ persons from eighteen to twenty-one years of age to work in a capacity of musicians under the direct supervision of a person over twenty-one years of age. 
B.  Liability of Persons Under Twenty-one Years. It is unlawful for any persons under twenty-one years of age to purchase, or to consume, or be in possession of alcoholic beverages, or to furnish money to any person for such purpose, or to enter any licensed premises where such beverages are being sold or displayed except under the conditions permitted as set out in subsection A of this section. 
C.  Misrepresentation of Age. It is unlawful for any person to misrepresent or misstate his age or that of any other person, or to misrepresent his age through presentation of any document purporting to show such person to be of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages. Every licensee shall be required to keep a book which such licensee and his employees shall require anyone who has shown documentary proof of his age, which substantiates his age, to allow the purchase of alcoholic beverages, to sign such book if the age of such person is in question. Such book shall show the date of the purchase, the identification used in making the purchase, and the appropriate numbers of such identification, the address of the purchaser, and his signature. 
D.  Presumption of Licensee's Innocence When Certain Facts Established. The establishment of the following facts by a person making a sale of alcoholic beverages to a person not of legal age shall constitute prima facie evidence of innocence in a defense to any prosecution thereof: 
1.  That the purchaser falsely represented in writing, and supported with other documentary proof, that he was of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages; 
2.  That the appearance of such purchaser was such that an ordinary and prudent person would believe him to be of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages; 
3.  That the sale was made in good faith and in reliance upon the written representation and appearance of the purchaser in the belief that the purchaser was of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages; 
4.  Any person who is convicted of misrepresenting his age with the intention of purchasing alcoholic beverages shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars and thirty hours of public service as the same may be prescribed by the municipal court. 
E.  Delivery to Certain Persons Unlawful. It is unlawful for any person to deliver alcoholic beverages to a person under twenty-one years of age, a habitual drunkard, an incompetent, or an intoxicated person. 
1.  The chief of police shall maintain a list containing the name(s) of any persons deemed to be a "habitual drunkard" according to the definition in Section 5.24.010. If available, this list shall include a photograph of any person on the list. This list, and any information which identifies those contained on the list, will be provided by the city police department to all licensed liquor establishments in the city of Devils Lake. 
2.  Any person who is identified as a habitual drunkard shall be prohibited from being in any licensed premises in the city of Devils Lake. 
(Ord. 732, 1989; Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
(Ord. No. 906, 10-15-12) 
5.24.160 - Responsibility for conduct on premises-Gambling devices prohibited-Sale of other items restricted. 
A.  Every licensee is made responsible for the conduct of his place of business and is required to maintain order and sobriety in such place of business. No intoxicated person or persons shall be permitted to remain upon the premises or to be sold intoxicating liquor by any person or his employees holding any license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
B.  No licensee under this chapter shall be permitted to own or have in his possession and located on the premises for which a license is obtained pursuant to this chapter any slot machine, punchboard, pinball or other gambling device, except as provided by state statute. The possession of such device upon the premises licensed shall be sufficient cause for the revocation of the license issued under this chapter. 
C.  It is unlawful to sell any item on the licensed premises other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, tobacco products, drink mixing supplies, prepacked preserved sandwiches or pizzas approved by the State Laboratories Department, which shall be delivered to the purchaser with the packaging intact, dry packaged preserved snacks, and preserved pickled products served to the purchaser from the original container; except an on-sale liquor licensee and an on-sale beer licensee may sell alcoholic beverages in a restaurant separated from the room in which alcoholic beverages are opened or mixed if gross sales of food are at least equal to gross sales of alcoholic beverages which are consumed in the dining area, and except that anyone who operates a restaurant in conjunction with his on-sale liquor license or on-sale beer license under this chapter may serve food in the licensed premises; provided, however: 
1.  Other prepared foods may be served upon licensed premises so long as food is prepared by a person or business licensed to serve and prepare food and the preparer delivers and serves the food and, after consumption, returns all utensils used and uneaten food to the business or location at which the food was prepared. If the license holder obtains such food from a caterer and serves the food himself, the license holder must possess a restaurant license and meet the minimum requirements for a restaurant as set forth by the North Dakota State Laboratories and Consumer Affairs. 
2.  Before a city off-sale alcoholic beverage license may be issued to a person whose business to be licensed is located in a building that is primarily a gas station, grocery story or convenience store, the area to be licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages must be clearly set out in a blueprint or diagram. The area licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages must be separated from the nonlicensed portion of the business by a wall designed to allow sales personnel to serve customers and make sales in both the licensed and unlicensed portion of the premises, and that may allow customers in either portion of the premises access to the other portion. 
(Ord. 793, 1995; Ord. 754, 1991; Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.170 - Inspection of premises by police officers permitted. 
    In addition to the requirements as stated in Section 5.24.070 to be set forth in the application made by a person seeking the license for the sale of intoxicating liquor and alcoholic beverages, such person, copartnership, corporation, club or lodge seeking the license shall state therein that he consents to any city official, sheriff or any peace officer of the city or the state entering upon the premises for which license is sought for the purpose of inspecting the premises and any part thereof at any time, and that the persons making the application waive all rights, constitutional or otherwise, against unreasonable searches or seizures and further agrees that any liquor found upon the premises or any property found therein in violation of the laws of the state or of this chapter may be seized and taken away by the officer, and that such intoxicating liquor, alcoholic beverage or other property so seized may be received in evidence against him in any procedure pursuant to the laws of the state or this chapter. 
(Ord. 711 § 2 (part), 1988) 
5.24.180 - Closed booths and windows prohibited. 
    No licensee for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages shall maintain or suffer to be constructed, maintained or placed in the premises licensed any side room, closed booth or other enclosure. All booths located in such premises shall not be over forty inches high and open into the main part of the premises and shall be accessible from the aisles therein and shall not have thereon any kind preventing clear view into the booths from the main room or aisle of the premises. No licensee for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted to place in the windows or door of the licensed premises any sign, advertising matter, paper cards or any other material which shall in any manner obstruct the view into the premises above a line drawn parallel across the windows or door at a point six feet above the sidewalk level immediately in front of the windows or doors. 
(Ord. 711 § 2 (part), 1988) 
5.24.190 - Possession of unstamped and untaxed liquor unlawful. 
    No intoxicating liquor shall be permitted to be owned, held or possessed upon any licensed premises or by any person to whom a license for the retail sale of liquor has been issued unless the stamp tax as provided by the Liquor Control Act of the state has been properly affixed to the containers thereof and unless the taxes on such intoxicating liquor have been paid. The possession of any container of intoxicating liquor, which container does not bear the proper stamps issued by the state pursuant to the Liquor Control Act of the state shall be deemed to be illegal and a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.200 - Delivery of intoxicating liquor by nonlicensed persons unlawful. 
A.  It is found and determined by the board of city commissioners that the delivery of intoxicating liquor to homes in the city by nonlicensed persons facilitates the procuring of such liquors by juveniles and thereby contributes to breach of law and juvenile delinquency. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person not holding a liquor or beer license from the city to deliver or cause to be delivered within the city any intoxicating liquor to any private residence or to any person either for profit or in furtherance of any sale of such liquor. 
C.  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit the delivery of such liquor by a dealer licensed by the city or a person hired by the licensed dealer; provided, that the delivery is made only after the liquor has been purchased in a duly licensed place of business and delivery is made only to an adult person, nor shall this chapter apply to deliveries made to the place of business of licensed liquor dealers. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.210 - Hearing on alleged violations. 
    Any person having information that a retailer of alcoholic beverages licensed by the city has violated any provisions of this chapter may file with the city attorney an affidavit specifically setting forth such violation. Upon receipt of such affidavit the city attorney shall file a complaint in the municipal court or cause the matter to be set on for hearing not later than the next regular meeting of the city commission. A copy of the affidavit and notice of hearing shall be mailed the licensee by registered or certified mail not less than five days before such hearing, and in the event the date of receipt of such affidavit does not permit said required five days' notice, then such hearing before the city commission will be held at its next following regular meeting. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.220 - Severance clause. 
    The provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable, and if any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter shall for any reason be held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining sections, sentences, clauses and phrases of this chapter, but they shall remain in effect, it being the legislative intent that this chapter shall stand notwithstanding the invalidity of any part. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.230 - Violations-Penalties stated. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a violation, or whenever in this chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, any person upon conviction for the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars, by imprisonment not to exceed thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, for each such offense. In the construction and interpretation of this chapter, the revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered as a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. 
(Ord. 711 § 2(part), 1988) 
5.24.240 - Special permit. 
    The holder of a license issued pursuant to this chapter may request the city commission to authorize the license holder to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages at a special event, subject, however, to the following: 
A.  The holder of the license must file with the city auditor an application on a form provided by the city auditor, no later than thirty days prior to the special event, which application shall contain the following: 
1.  The date of the special event and any alternate date in the event of inclement weather; 
2.  The hours of the special event; 
a.  As provided in Chapter 8.28, outdoor events shall not proceed past midnight and indoor events shall not proceed past one a.m., unless permission has been granted by the city commission as set out in that chapter. 
3.  The location of the special event; 
4.  The name, address and license number of the holder of the license; 
5.  A description of the special event, including reasons why the city commission should determine that it is a special event and issue a permit allowing the license holder to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages; 
6.  A diagram which sets out the following: 
a.  Where the alcoholic beverages are to be dispensed; 
i.  If alcoholic beverages, other than beer, wine or sparkling wine are being dispensed, the location of the barrier which persons twenty-one years of age are prohibited from entering. 
b.  Where alcoholic beverages are to be consumed; 
c.  All entrances and exits; 
d.  The area set aside for those under twenty-one years of age, if there will be persons under twenty-one years of age present; 
e.  If persons twenty-one years of age are allowed to comingle with persons twenty-one years of age or older, whether alcoholic beverages, other than beer, wine, or sparkling wine will be dispensed; 
7.  Whether the special event will include a public dance, as defined in Chapter 8.28 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code, or a private dance as provided in Section 8.28.100 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code, and if so, an application for a public dance must accompany this application; 
8.  That the application has been reviewed and is approved by the chief of police; 
9.  If the chief of police recommends that police officers be present at the special event, the license holder will be responsible for the cost of hiring those police officers to be present; 
10.  The type of alcohol to be sold and the method of the sale of the alcohol. 
B.  The city commission may impose whatever restrictions or conditions it deems appropriate in granting a permit to authorize the license holder to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages at a special event. 
C.  In order to authorize the license holder to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages at a special event, the holder of the license must obtain a permit under this section. 
D.  Any conditions imposed by NDCC 5-02-01.1 are incorporated by reference. Any future amendments to NDCC 5-02-01.1 shall be incorporated by reference to this section. 
E.  The license holder must hold the class of license which allows for alcohol to be sold as requested in the application in this section. 
F.  The fee for a special permit to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be set out by the city commission and included in the adoption of its fees and rates. 
(Ord. 815, 1997) 
(Ord. No. 905, 10-15-12) 
5.24.250 - Consumption of alcoholic beverages adjacent to licensed premises. 
    The holder of a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may not allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages outside of its licensed premises unless the following conditions are met: 
A.  The area where the alcoholic beverages are consumed is adjacent to and contiguous to the licensed premises. 
B.  No minors are present. 
C.  The area where the alcoholic beverages are consumed is enclosed, which enclosure shall be approved, in writing, by the chief of police. 
D.  The only alcohol consumed in the area is alcohol which has been dispensed from the licensed premises. 
E.  The area where alcoholic beverages are consumed shall be open only when the licensed premises is open. 
F.  The diagram of the licensed premises shall include in that diagram the area where the alcohol will be consumed and shall be so designated as such an area. 
G.  The laws of the state of North Dakota and ordinances of the City of Devils Lake are in no way violated. 
H.  The class of license of the licensed premises shall include allowing on sale, and the only alcohol consumed in this area is that alcohol sold by the licensed premises on sale. 
(Ord. 816, 1997) 
5.24.260 - Server training. 
    The terms and provisions of server training are as follows: 
A.  Server training shall be mandatory within the City of Devils Lake. 
B.  Server training classes shall be provided to those who own, manage, or are engaged in the sale of or service of alcohol. 
C.  Server training shall be required of any person that works in any premises licensed under this chapter for the sale of alcoholic beverages, whether on or off sale, as a manager, bartender, waiter, waitress, or in any other capacity where such person may sell, serve, or deliver alcoholic beverages in or from premises licensed under this chapter or whose job description entails the checking of identification for the purchase of alcoholic beverages or admittance into the licensed premises. 
D.  All server certificates will be valid for three years from the date of issuance. The certificate of training must be renewed prior to its expiration. 
E.  Each establishment having an alcohol license under this chapter shall maintain on file, at its licensed premises, a list of all employees and the certification status of each employee. Such list shall be made available to Lake Region District Health Unit upon request. 
F.  The Lake Region District Health Unit will coordinate the dates and times of server training classes with the training provider, and make that information known to the public. Applications for server training shall be submitted to the Lake Region District Health Unit. Applications will be verified and shall contain such information as determined by the training provider to be reasonably required for the purposes of determining competency and eligibility. 
G.  All server training programs shall be pre-approved by the Devils Lake Police Department. 
H.  An approved training program shall include, but not be limited to the following topics: 
1.  Reducing accessibility of alcohol to minors. 
2.  How to handle over consumption of alcohol. 
3.  Over serving of alcohol. 
4.  Server liability. 
5.  Local ordinances pertaining to the sale, dispensation, and delivery of alcoholic beverages. 
I.  A new employee will obtain a server certificate within seventy-five days from starting employment. 
J.  Any establishment holding a license, as provided in this chapter, which does not comply with this section shall have its license subject to the provisions of Section 5.24.210 of the Devils Lake City Code. 
(Ord. No. 935, 3-7-16; Ord. No. 951, 3-19-18) 
Chapter 5.36 - TAXICABS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 938, adopted May 2, 2016, amended Chapter 5.36 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 5.36, §§ 5.36.010-5.36.090, pertained to similar material, and derived from Ord. No. 436, 1962; Ord. No. 534, 1973; Ord. No. 644, 1981; Ord. No. 677, 1984; Ord. No. 728, 1989; Ord. No. 828, 1999; Ord. No. 842, 2001 and Ord. No. 929, adopted August 17, 2015. 

5.36.010 - License-Required. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab business, nor shall any entity offer or make available its technologies or services to dispatch or in any way directly connect potential passengers with limousines or taxicabs, including electronic demand response or mobile application within the city without first having obtained a taxicab license as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.020 - License-Application. 
    Any person desiring to engage in the taxicab or limousine business, and any person desiring to drive a taxicab or limousine within the city shall make written application therefor to the city auditor and shall deposit with the city auditor the license fee required in Section 5.36.040. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.025 - Definitions. 
A.  Taxicab: As used in this chapter, the term "taxicab" means and includes any vehicle used to carry passengers for hire, which does not operate on a fixed route. 
1.  This definition shall include any of the following: 
a.  Taxi services. 
b.  Shuttle services. 
c.  Limousine services. 
2.  This definition does not apply to the following: 
a.  Any nonprofit corporation. 
b.  Any transportation provided to employees by their employer. 
B.  Rideshare: Shall mean the traveling of two or more persons by any mode of private passenger vehicle, including but not limited to; carpooling, van pooling, bus pooling, to any location incidental to another purpose of the driver, without charge, fee, or payment, for which a gratuity is neither accepted, collected, encouraged, promoted and/or requested, and for which the primary purpose of the driver cannot be profit or revenue based. Gratuity herein shall not include reimbursement for fuel usage. 
C.  Electronic Demand Response: The use of any electronic device in any manner, including internet pages, email, text message, push notification or application for the connection of or communication between a passenger and driver, or agents thereof, irrespective of whether such communication is from a portable or handheld device, monitor, smart phone or other electronic device or unit, for the demand response booking of transportation services. 
D.  Mobile Application: Any third party application installed onto a mobile device including smart phones, tablets, iPods or iPads used to arrange or coordinate limousine or taxicab transportation. 
E.  Limousine: A motor vehicle used for transporting passengers for a prearranged fare based on time, flat, or zone rates, but shall be prohibited from setting or collecting any charges passed upon time and distance combined or distance or through the use of any device or instrument. 
F.  Passenger(s): Any person or group of persons engaging a taxicab or limousine under the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.030 - License-Conditions for granting. 
    The application for license shall be presented to the board of city commissioners and if the applicant has: 
A.  Procured and filed with the city auditor an indemnity insurance policy, written by a company licensed to do business in the state, or, in lieu thereof, a satisfactory surety bond, indemnifying those using the taxicab line and the public in general against loss to person, or property, as follows: 
1.  Indemnity against property damage for which the taxicab proprietor is legally liable in the sum of not less than fifteen thousand dollars, 
2.  Indemnity against death or personal injury for which the taxicab proprietor is legally liable, in the sum of not less than one hundred thousand dollars to any one person and/or three hundred thousand dollars to more than one person involved in any accident or three hundred thousand dollars combined single limit, 
3.  The policy or bond shall contain a provision that the insurance company shall give the city auditor fifteen days' notice of cancellation by registered mail, 
4.  The form of, the sufficiency of, the policy or bond, and the surety thereon, shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney and the board of city commissioners; 
B.  Shown that the applicant is a person of good moral character; 
C.  Shown a reasonable need of the taxicab service; the license may be granted. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.040 - License-Fee. 
    The annual license fee for the operation of a taxicab business in the city shall be established by resolution of the city commission and revised as it may see fit. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.050 - License-Requirements. 
A.  No person shall drive a taxi cab, and no owner of a taxi cab shall permit any person to drive a taxi cab, unless the driver has a taxi cab license issued by the city auditor. 
B.  Any person desiring to obtain a license to drive a taxi cab shall file an application for a taxi cab license with the city auditor who shall collect an initial fee for the processing of the background check. The auditor shall forward the application to the chief of police. The application shall contain the information requested by the chief of police needed by the chief of police to determine whether the applicant meets the criteria to hold a taxi cab driver's license. 
C.  The criteria to determine whether the applicant may hold a taxi cab driver's license are all of the following: 
1.  The applicant is over eighteen years of age. 
2.  The chief of police determines the applicant is a careful and competent driver. 
3.  The chief of police has determined the applicant has no criminal violation which would cause the applicant to be an improper taxi cab driver. 
4.  The applicant is not a registered offender. 
5.  The applicant has submitted to a drug screening test. The results of such screening shall be submitted with the application to the chief of police. 
a.  Screening tests shall be administered by a person certified to conduct screening tests of urine or saliva for the purpose of determining the presence of illicit substances prohibited by law, or the presence of legal substances requiring a subscription that has not been prescribed to the applicant. 
b.  Any positive result for illicit substances or other substances requiring a prescription for which the applicant is unable to prove that has been properly prescribed shall be grounds for denial. 
c.  Any applicant receiving a positive result on a screening test who believes the results to be incorrect (false positive) may submit to an enhanced laboratory test with a SAMHSA certified testing laboratory. 
d.  Fees for any such testing(s) are the responsibility of the applicant or the company for which the applicant is applying. 
6.  Shown that the applicant is a person of good moral character; 
7.  False or misrepresented information on the application shall be grounds for denial. 
D.  If the chief of police finds the criteria in subsection C to have been met, the application shall be approved by the chief of police and forwarded to the city auditor. 
E.  The license shall be issued by the city auditor for the term or remainder of the term set forth herein. The fee for the license shall be collected prior to a license being issued. The license shall be renewable thereafter from year to year upon payment of the license renewal fee and by applying for renewal of the license by the same methods set out in subsections B, C and D above. The license shall be renewed by approval of the chief of police. The city auditor shall provide a list of all licensed taxi cab drivers to the chief of police. 
F.  The license fee, application/background check fee, and license renewal fee shall be set by resolution of the board of city commissioners, and the fees may be changed from time to time. All fees shall be collected by the city auditor or designee. 
G.  The term of the license shall commence on the first day of July of each year, and shall expire on the thirtieth day of June of the following year. 
H.  Should the holder of any taxi cab driver's license fail to meet any of the criteria set forth in subsection C, the license may be revoked by the board of city commissioners. The procedure for revocation of a taxi cab driver's license is set forth as follows: 
1.  The board of city commissioners shall direct the city auditor to send written notification by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the holder of the taxi cab driver's license and the holder of the taxi cab license for whom the driver is employed, if known, which notice shall set forth the following: 
a.  The grounds for the revocation; 
b.  Whether the revocation is effective immediately. The temporary revocation of a taxi cab driver's license may be taken if the board of city commissioners determines such action is in the best interest of the public; 
c.  The date, time and location of the hearing on whether to revoke the taxi cab driver's license or to make the revocation permanent if there has been an immediate temporary revocation. 
2.  The hearing on the license revocation will be before the board of city commissioners no earlier than ten days and not more than thirty days from when the city auditor is directed to send the notice as provided in subsection (H)(1) above. 
I.  Any applicant for a taxi cab driver's license whose application is denied by the chief of police may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the board of city commissioners by proceeding as follows: 
1.  The applicant shall file a written request for a hearing with the city auditor within ten days from when a notice of denial is sent to the applicant. Notice of denial may be sent by regular mail, email, telephonic, or personal contact. If notification is made by telephone, the time and date of notification shall be noted on the application form. 
2.  The city auditor shall set the hearing before the board of city commissioners no earlier than ten days, but no later than thirty days from when the request for a hearing is filed with the city auditor. 
3.  The board of city commissioners shall either affirm the decision of the chief of police or reverse the decision of the chief of police with any conditions placed on the license which the board of city commissioners deems appropriate. 
J.  Upon satisfactory fulfillment of the requirements for issuance of a license and payment of the fees established by resolution of the city commission, there shall be issued to the applicant a license which shall be in such form as to contain the photograph and signature of the licensee and the license number issued thereto. Any licensee who defaces, removes, or obliterates any official entry made upon their license shall be punished by the revocation of their license. 
1.  Any taxicab driver shall constantly and conspicuously display their taxicab driver's license when he/she is engaged in employment. The identification shall not be displayed after expiration of the license. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.060 - License-Revocation. 
    Any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be revocable by the board of city commissioners for due cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.070 - Street stands. 
    The police may designate places upon the public streets where licensed vehicles may stand while waiting for employment and no such vehicle shall stand upon any of the public streets of the city at any other place than so designated. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.080 - Assault and profanity prohibited. 
    No owner or driver of any licensed vehicle shall assault, threaten, abuse or use profane, violent or improper language toward any passenger or other person employing such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.090 - Schedule of fees. 
    The owner or operator of every taxicab or other vehicle for conveyance of passengers for hire shall file with the city auditor a schedule of the fees to be charged for transportation, which schedule may be changed from time to time by filing amended schedules, but no driver or operator shall charge a greater fare than that shown upon the schedule. Such charges shall at all times be subject to approval by the board of city commissioners and if the board considers any charge excessive it may require the licensee to revise the same. Refusal to revise the rate schedule in accordance with such directions within twenty-four hours after notice so to do shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.100 - Front seat occupants limited. 
    Under no circumstances and at no time shall more than one person, other than the driver of a taxicab be permitted to be carried or to ride in the driver's compartment of the taxicab or on the same seat with the driver. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.110 - Guest passengers prohibited. 
A.  No driver of any taxicab shall at any time while offering service to the public carry or have riding with him/her in the taxicab any guest or visitor while transporting any passenger(s). 
B.  Exemption: 
1.  An employee of the taxicab company may accompany a driver for the purpose of training, supervision, or security. Any such employee must meet the same criteria and be a licensed taxicab driver in accordance with Section 5.36.050. 
2.  This section shall not apply to additional persons who are a part of a group of passengers for whom a fare is charged in whole or in portion to another party or passenger. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.120 - Overloading prohibited. 
    No driver of any taxicab in the city shall at any time overload the taxicab or carry more people than the vehicle is designed to carry. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.130 - Accommodations and attention. 
    All drivers of taxicabs in the city must give passengers accommodations as are usual and reasonable, and must treat them with civility and give them a reasonable degree of attention and must assist all weak, sick, or a person with a known disability in and out of the taxicabs. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.140 - Record of calls. 
    All taxicab operators and proprietors shall at all times keep a record of all calls, showing the date, the name of the driver, the time of the call and the address of the party calling, which records shall at all times be open to the inspection of the police department. Call logs shall be maintained for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.150 - Safety inspection required. 
    As a prerequisite for the issuance or renewal of a license, any vehicle to be licensed as a taxicab must undergo a vehicle safety inspection within thirty days prior to the issuance of the license. This vehicle safety inspection shall be conducted by a certified mechanic and found to provide safe transportation and to comply with state and city laws. Every motor vehicle operating under this chapter must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. A report of every required inspection must be kept on file and furnished to the chief of police upon request. 
A.  The police department may require additional safety inspections in response to a complaint or observation of defective equipment. 
B.  A police officer observing a safety defect that cannot be immediately rectified may place a taxicab out of service subject to a safety inspection. 
C.  Any safety inspection deficiencies must be corrected before the taxicab can be placed back in service. A report of the correction of deficiencies shall be furnished to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.160 - Identification of vehicle. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee, before operating any taxicab within the city, to paint, stamp, or otherwise mark upon the body of the taxicab in reasonably large print, the name of the taxicab business name, and the license number issued by the city. Each vehicle shall have and display a unique number issued by the city auditor. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.170 - Interference with other taxi drivers 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab or other vehicle for hire to scuffle or crowd about or interfere with any other driver with whom any person is negotiating or inquiring about the transportation of persons or baggage. No driver shall interfere with or engage in conduct that harasses another taxicab or vehicle for hire or their passengers. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
5.36.180 - Advertising on taxicabs. 
    Any licensed taxicab may carry an advertisement on the cab if it is carried in a neat frame so located on the cab as not to interfere or cover the name of the cab company, the license number, or telephone number thereon. No advertisement for intoxicating liquors or tobacco products of any kind shall be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 938, 5-2-16) 
Chapter 5.44 - PAWNBROKERS* 

5.44.010 - Definitions. 
A.  "Applicant" means any person or business entity which attempts to carry on or conduct the business of pawnbroker. 
B.  "Firearms" means any weapon which will, or is designed to or restored to, expel a projectile or projectiles by the action of an explosive; the frame or receiver of any such device; or any firearm muffler or silencer. 
C.  "Pawnbroker" means any person who loans money on deposit or pledges of personal property, choses in action, or wages, or who deals in purchasing of personal property, choses in action, or wages, on condition of selling or transferring the same, or returning the same back again to the pledger or depositor, or to their agents, or assigns, at a stipulated price, shall be deemed to be a pawnbroker. 
D.  "Personal property" means all goods which are movable at the time of identification to the contract for sale are personal property. For purposes of this chapter, personal property does not include money; investment securities; alcoholic beverages, beer or liquor as defined in Chapter 5.24 of the Devils Lake Municipal Code; or firearms, except as provided herein. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to carry on or conduct the business or calling of pawnbroker within the city without first having obtained a license to do so. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.025 - License classification. 
    The following classes of pawnbroker licenses are hereby established in the city: 
A.  Class 1-Special Pawnbroker's License. A Class 1, special pawnbroker's license issued in accordance with this chapter may engage in the purchase, sale, and transfer of personal property, including firearms. 
B.  Class 2-General Pawnbroker's License. A Class 2, general pawnbroker's license issued in accordance with this chapter may engage in the purchase, sale, and transfer of personal property, not including firearms. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.030 - License fee. 
    In order to pursue or carry on the business of pawnbroker in the city, there shall be taxed and collected a fee which shall be set by resolution of the city commission. Each class of license may require a different fee for that class. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.040 - Background investigation. 
    Before a license shall be issued to any person or persons to carry on or conduct the business of pawnbroker, the chief of police, or any other police officer as the chief shall designate, shall investigate each applicant for such license and shall report back to the board of city commissioners whether or not such applicant is a person of good character. The background information to be provided by the applicant to the city shall contain the following: 
A.  The applicant's name and legal place or residence; 
B.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and legal residence of the partnership, together with the name and place of legal residence of all partners; 
C.  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and place of legal residence of the corporation. Applicant corporations must also provide evidence of proper registration with the Secretary of State. Applicant corporations must also provide the name and place of residence of all officers, board of directors, and stockholders; 
D.  Licenses currently held or previously held by applicant in the preceding ten years and the entity issuing that license. Applicant must provide information regarding the status of each license held in the preceding ten year period, including the revocation, sale, suspension, limitation, or disposition of any license held by the applicant in the last ten years, including the nature of any change in status; 
E.  Name and legal residence of all parties having a financial interest in the pawnbroker business; 
F.  Whether the applicant if an individual, any partners if the applicant is a partnership, or any promoters, officers, members of the board of directors, or stockholders if the applicant is a corporation, have been convicted of the following offenses in the past five years: 
1.  Any felony, 
2.  Any offense involving the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession for sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages, 
3.  Any offense involving the sale of drugs or felony possession of drugs, 
4.  Prostitution, 
5.  Obscenity, 
6.  Theft, 
7.  Any other offense determined by the board of city commissioners to have a direct bearing on the applicant's ability to serve the public as a pawnbroker; 
G.  The name and legal residence of any manager of the pawnbroker business, and whether the manager has been convicted of any of the offenses listed in subsection F of this section; 
H.  Proposed location of the pawnbroker business; 
I.  Any other information requested by either the city or the chief of police. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.045 - License transfers and site locations. 
A.  A license may not be issued and/or transferred to engage in the pawnbroker business within the city or any license transferred to a new or different location without license application and site approval by the board of city commissioners. 
B.  A hearing for license application and site location approval must be within twenty days of the filing of the license application. Public notice of the hearing must be published in the official newspaper one time, the publication being at least seven days prior to the hearing date. 
C.  At the hearing, the board of city commissioners shall take the following factors into account to determine if the proposed site as a pawnbroker business is proper: 
1.  Public convenience and necessity; 
2.  The proposed location to any church, public or parochial school, public library, hospital, college or university building used for academic purposes, and any premises licensed to allow the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages pursuant to Chapter 5.24 of the city code; 
3.  Compliance of the proposed site with the applicable building code requirements; 
4.  Compliance of the proposed site with the applicable health and sanitation ordinance; 
5.  Class of pawnbroker license; 
6.  Any other factors deemed reasonable by the city commission. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.050 - License term. 
    Each license issued under this chapter shall expire on the thirtieth day of June succeeding the date of its issuance, unless sooner revoked as herein provided. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.060 - Licensee-To keep record of goods pawned. 
    Every person so licensed as aforesaid shall keep at his place of business a book or register, in which he shall enter in writing a detailed description of all personal property or choses in action received on deposit, pledge, or purchase, as set forth in this chapter, the date and time when they were so received and particularly mentioning any prominent or descriptive mark that may be on such property or choses in action, together with the name of the person or persons by whom they were left, deposited, or pledged, which shall be kept clean and legible and no entry therein shall be erased, obliterated, or defaced during the period of such license. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.070 - Same-To furnish copy to chief of police. 
    It is the duty of every pawnbroker or leader in secondhand goods to make out and deliver to the chief of police, on or before the fifth day of each month, a legible and correct copy, from the book required in Section 5.44.060, of all personal property or other valuable things received, deposited, or purchased during the preceding month, together with the time when received or purchased, and a description of the person or persons by whom left in pledge or from whom the same were purchased. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.080 - Inspection of register by peace officers. 
    Every person so licensed as set out in this chapter, shall, during the ordinary hours of business, when required by any peace officer of the city, submit and exhibit such books in this chapter provided for, to said officers and shall also exhibit any goods, personal property, or choses in action that may be so left, deposited, pledged, or purchased, as herein provided, to such officers. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.090 - Sale of unredeemed pledges. 
    No sale or disposition of an unredeemed pledge shall or can be effected by a pawnbroker unless fifteen or more days have elapsed from the date any item is initially pledged. However, the sale of an unredeemed item, if done in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, shall work a complete forfeiture of the right of redemption by the original owner thereof, and the proceeds from said sale, after deduction of expenses, shall absolutely be the property of the pawnbroker. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.100 - Transactions with minors. 
    No person or persons granted a license under the provisions of this chapter shall purchase or receive any article or thing of value, or sell any dangerous weapon to any person who has not reached the age of eighteen years, without the written consent of such minor's parents or guardian. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.110 - Violation-Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction be subject to the penalty which may include a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars and a jail term not to exceed thirty days or both may be imposed. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.120 - Revocation of license. 
A.  Pawnbrokers' licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the board of city commissioners after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
1.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for a license; 
2.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the pawnbroker business; 
3.  Any violation of this chapter; 
4.  Conviction of any crime involving theft or dishonesty; 
5.  Conducting the business in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace, or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; 
6.  Any violation of the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. 
B.  A notice of the hearing for revocation must be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice must be mailed, registered mail, to the holder of the license at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing, which address will be that on file in the city offices. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
5.44.130 - Effective date. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be effective July 1, 1999, and is intended to apply to all licenses which expired June 30, 1999, and are effective July 1, 1999. 
(Ord. 826 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 5.45 - SITE AUTHORIZATION 

5.45.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the definitions adopted by Chapter 53-06.1 of the North Dakota Century Code are adopted by reference, and as those definitions contained in Chapter 53-06.1 of the North Dakota Century Code amend, the definitions on this chapter of the municipal code shall be amended. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.020 - Limit on number of sites per licensed organization. 
    No licensed organization which receives its license from the city shall hold more than one-third of the total site permits for gaming issued by the city in one year. In determining whether any licensed organization holds more than the allowed one-third of the total site permit, any fractional amount shall be rounded to the nearest whole number. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.030 - Waiver of limit on authorized sites held by one licensed organization. 
    The limitation on the number of sites authorized by the city and held by one licensed organization as restricted by Section 5.45.020 may be waived by the city commission upon one or more of the following: 
A.  That no other organization which would qualify as a licensed organization has expressed any interest in applying for the site authorization which would create more than the allowed number of sites authorized to be held by one licensed organization by Section 5.45.020; 
B.  It is determined by the city commission that the issuance of the site authorization to the licensed organization which would give that licensed organization more than one-third of the site authorizations issued by the city is in the best interests of the city, the licensed organization, the site and the intention of gaming as allowed by North Dakota law and the laws of the city; 
C.  Other factors exist, as determined by the city commission, for allowing a waiver from the restrictions of Section 5.45.020. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.040 - Procedure to obtain waiver. 
    Any licensed organization may petition the city commission for a waiver of the restrictions of Section 5.45.020 pursuant to Section 5.45.030 by the following procedure: 
A.  The licensed organization seeking the waiver must petition the city commission, in writing, of its request for a waiver by filing a petition with the city auditor. 
B.  Within thirty days from receipt of the written request, the city commission will set a day and time for a public hearing on the petition. 
C.  Public notice of the hearing must be published in the official newspaper one time, the publication being at least seven days prior to the hearing date. 
D.  At the hearing, the city commission will then determine whether the waiver should be allowed under Section 5.45.030. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.050 - Exception to limitation. 
    The restrictions in Section 5.45.020 do not apply to the following: 
A.  Licensed organization which, on the enactment of this section to the municipal code, hold more site authorizations than allowed by Section 5.45.020. This exception shall continue, however, only until the licensed organization holds less than the number of site authorizations allowed by Section 5.45.020; 
B.  A licensed organization which obtained a waiver of the restriction on the number of sites as allowed in this chapter. This exception shall continue, however, only until that licensed organization holds less than the site authorizations allowed by Section 5.45.020; 
C.  A licensed organization which is managing the site for another licensed organization and is not the actual holder of the site authorization. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.060 - City may require licensed organization to provide information. 
    Prior to issuing a site authorization in the city to a licensed organization, the city may request the licensed organization to provide certain information which must be provided: 
A.  A list of the organizations which will benefit from the gaming operations on this site; 
B.  On an annual basis, and prior to the city issuing the site authorization for the upcoming year, the licensed organization shall provide documentation of the total income received from that gaming site, the name and address of each organization which received any benefits from the gaming operation on that authorized site, and the amount of benefit each organization received from that gaming site; 
C.  A list of three references, including the name, address and phone number, regarding the licensed organi-zation's gaming operations. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.070 - Denial of request for site authorizations. 
    Upon determination by the city commission, a request for a site authorization may be denied to a licensed organization by any of the following: 
A.  That the proceeds from the gaming site have not been and are not expected to benefit organizations in the city entitled to receive the benefits from gaming; 
B.  That it is not in the best interests of the city, the gaming site, and the intention of gaming as allowed by North Dakota law and the laws of the city, for the licensed organization to conduct gaming at that site; 
C.  That the licensed organization or any of its officers or manager have had violations of the gaming laws or have been convicted of any criminal violations; 
D.  That the property taxes or special assessments for the building in which the site authorization would be located are delinquent; 
E.  That any utility bills or amounts owned to the city for services supplied to the building where the site authorization would be located are delinquent, or the licensed organization is delinquent in any amount it owes to the city; 
F.  That there are other factors which the city commission determines constitute good cause for denying the site authorization to the licensed organization. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
5.45.080 - Revocation or suspension of site authorization. 
    Any site authorization or the operation of games by a licensed organization in the city may be revoked or suspended for good cause, as determined by the city commission, subject to the following: 
A.  Before any revocation or suspension, the city auditor shall notify the licensed organization of its right to a hearing. The notice shall specify the action proposed to be taken, the reason for it, time and place of the hearing, and the right of the licensed organization to appear. The notice must be mailed to the licensed organization by certified mail, return receipt, not less than five days nor more than fifteen days before the hearing. 
B.  If after the hearing the city commission finds the violation charge has been proved by the evidence, the city commission shall issue its findings of fact, conclusions of law, and order, which shall be served upon the licensed organization. 
(Ord. 801(part), 1996) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapter 6.04 - ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER 

6.04.010 - Office created. 
    There shall be employed by the city an animal control officer who shall be under the supervision and control of the chief of police as an employee of the police department. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.04.020 - General duties. 
    The animal control officer shall have the following general duties: 
A.  He shall perform the services customarily done by animal control officers, including the destruction of impounded animals. 
B.  He shall also serve as city poundmaster and receive into his custody any animal to be impounded under the provisions of city ordinances, and shall be responsible for providing sufficient and suitable food and drink for the animals so impounded. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.04.030 - Authority. 
    The animal control officer shall have the authority to carry out all the provisions of and enforce all city ordinances relating to animals, except that he is not authorized to make arrests to individuals as is a regular police officer. He shall, however, have full authority to take all action pertaining to animals as provided in the ordinances, including the issuance of citations for violations of the provisions therein. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
Chapter 6.08 - DOG LICENSING AND CONTROL 

6.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words will have the following meanings: 
A.  "At large" means any dog not in an enclosure or under control of the owner or person authorized by the owner, either by leash, cord, chain or other physical restraint of a maximum of six feet in length. 
B.  "Dog" means either a male or female dog. 
C.  "Owner" means any person or persons, firm, association or corporation owning, keeping or harboring a dog. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.08.020 - License requirements and fees. 
A.  Dog License Required. No person, firm, association or corporation shall own, keep, or harbor a dog which is over six months of age without first having obtained a license therefor as provided in this section; provided, however, the city shall not be required to obtain a license for any dogs used for law enforcement purposes. 
B.  Dog License Fee. The owner, keeper or harborer of any dog required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter shall pay a license fee thereon to the city at its police department, for each male, female, altered or neutered male dog and each spayed female dog, in such amount as may be established from time to time by resolution of the board of city commissioners. The burden of establishing that any male dog has been altered or neutered or that any female dog has been spayed shall be upon the owner thereof and the owner shall furnish evidence to the chief of police in the form of a certificate of a veterinarian at the time the application is applied for. 
C.  Disposition of Fees. All money collected by the chief of police for dog licenses, penalties, delinquencies and duplicate tags shall be paid by him to the city treasurer, as part of the general fund of the city. 
D.  Rabies Vaccination Required. Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this chapter, the applicant shall furnish a certificate of rabies vaccination issued by a veterinarian, licensed to practice within this state, evidencing vaccination of the dog for which the license is desired; and, that such vaccination will be good for the license year(s). 
E.  Term of Dog License. The license provided for in this chapter shall be in force until the expiration date of the certificate of rabies vaccination that is valid at the time of the license application. Licenses shall be issued for periods of one, two or three years, or portion thereof depending on the expiration date of the certificate of rabies vaccination. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.08.030 - Tag and collar. 
A.  Upon payment of the license fee to the city at its police department and compliance with the provisions in this chapter, the chief of police shall issue to the owner a license certificate and a metallic tag for each dog so licensed. The tag shall have stamped thereon the number corresponding with the number on the certificate. 
B.  Each owner shall be required to provide each dog with a collar to which the license tag must be affixed and shall see that the collar and tag are constantly worn. In case a tag is lost or destroyed, a duplicate will be issued by the chief of police upon presentation of a receipt showing payment of a fee for such license fee for the current year and the payment of a fee for such duplicate. Tags shall not be transferable from one animal to another and no refunds shall be made on any license fee because of death of the animal or the owner's leaving the city before expiration of the license period. The metal rabies inoculation tag shall also be affixed to the animal's collar at all times. 
(Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.08.040 - Running at large prohibited. 
    No owner or keeper of a dog shall knowingly or unknowingly allow the dog to run at large at any time upon the streets, public places, public ways, schoolgrounds or upon the private premises of any person other than the owner or keeper of the dog without being effectively restrained by chain or leash not exceeding six feet in length and under the control of a competent person. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any dog used for law enforcement purposes under the command and control of a peace officer. 
(Ord. 725, 1989: Ord. 680 (part), 1985) 
6.08.050 - Nuisances.
