    The following standards shall be followed by the nuisance control officer in determining repair, vacation, or demolition: 
A.  If the substandard building or structure can reasonably be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter it shall be ordered repaired. 
B.  If the substandard building or structure is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of its occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated. 
C.  If the substandard building or structure is fifty percent or more damaged or decayed or deteriorated from its original value or structure, it shall be demolished, and in all cases where a building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article it shall be demolished. In all cases where a substandard building or structure is a fire hazard existing or erected in violation of the terms of this article or any ordinance of the city or statue of the state of North Dakota, it shall be demolished. The term "fifty percent or more damaged or decayed or deteriorated from its original value," as used in this section, shall mean that the reasonable value of all services, labor and materials necessary to restore the structure to building code standards exceeds fifty percent of the current value of the structure. The term "original value" as used in this section, shall mean the best available information utilizing; the current true and full value as shown in the assessment records, and appraisal of less than one year old or an average of the two. "Original value" should also reflect the pre-damaged or neglect, condition or value of the structure. 
D.  The nuisance control officer will notify the owner of the building or structure determined to be substandard whether the building is to be repaired, vacated, or demolished. The notice will include a reasonable deadline for the owner to comply with the notice of the nuisance control officer. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.040 - Procedure. 
    If a notice issued by the nuisance control officer pursuant to Section 8.32.030 is not complied with by the deadline in the notice, the nuisance control officer shall proceed as follows: 
A.  A petition can be filed with the city of Devils Lake by the nuisance control officer or by at least five residents of the city of Devils Lake charging that any dwelling is unfit for human habitation or whenever it appears to the nuisance control officer on the nuisance control officer's own motion that any dwelling is unfit for human habitation, the nuisance control officer shall, if the nuisance control officer's preliminary investigation discloses a basis for those charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner, every mortgagee of record and all parties in interest in the dwelling, including persons in possession, a complaint stating the charges in that respect. The complaint must contain a notice that a hearing will be held before the nuisance control officer or the nuisance control officer's designated agent at a place designated in the complaint not less than ten days nor more than thirty days after the serving of the complaint; that the owner, mortgagee, and parties in interest must be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the place and time designated in the complaint; and that the rules of evidence are not controlling in hearings before the nuisance control officer. 
B.  If, after the notice and hearing the nuisance control officer determines that the dwelling under consideration is unfit for human habitation, the nuisance control officer shall state in writing the findings of fact in support of the determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner of the dwelling an order which: 
1.  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the dwelling can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, the owner, within the time specified in the order, shall repair, alter, or improve the dwelling to render it fit for human habitation, or vacate and close the dwelling so it is not used for human habitation; or 
2.  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the dwelling cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, the owner, within the time specified in the order, shall remove or demolish the dwelling. 
C.  If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, alter, or improve or to vacate and close the dwelling, the nuisance control officer may cause the dwelling to be repaired, altered, or improved, or to be vacated and closed. 
D.  If the owner fails to comply with an order to remove or demolish the dwelling, the nuisance control officer may cause the dwelling to be removed or demolished. 
E.  The amount of the cost of any repairs, alterations, or improvements, or vacating and closing, or removal or demolition by the nuisance control officer constitutes a lien against the real property upon which the cost was incurred and the lien, including an allowance of the nuisance control officer's costs and necessary attorney's fees, may be foreclosed in judicial proceedings in the manner provided by law for loans secured by liens on real property. If the dwelling is removed or demolished by the nuisance control officer, the nuisance control officer shall sell the materials of the dwelling and credit the proceeds of the sale against the cost of the removal or demolition. Any balance remaining must be paid to the parties entitled to it as determined by proper judicial proceedings instituted by the nuisance control officer after deducting the costs of the judicial proceedings, including necessary attorney's fees incurred in those proceedings by the public officer, as determined by the court. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.050 - Determination. 
    The nuisance control officer may determine that a dwelling is unfit for human habitation if the nuisance control officer finds that conditions exist in the dwelling which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of the occupants of the dwelling, the occupants of neighboring dwellings, or other residents of the city of Devils Lake, or which have a blighting influence on properties in the area. Those conditions may include defects in the dwelling increasing the hazards of fire, accident, or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; dilapidation; disrepair; structural defects; uncleanliness; overcrowding; inadequate ingress and egress; inadequate drainage; or any violation of health, fire, building, or zoning regulations, or any other laws or regulations relating to the use of land and the use and occupancy of building and improvements. The nuisance control officer shall also consider the factors set out in Sections 8.32.020 and 8.32.030 in making the nuisance control officer's determination. 
    Complaints or orders issued by the nuisance control officer pursuant to this chapter must be served upon persons either personally or by registered or certified mail, but if the location of those persons in unknown and cannot be ascertained by the nuisance control officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the nuisance control officer shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of the complaint or order upon those persons may be made by publishing the complaint or order once each week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper printed and published in the city of Devils Lake. A copy of the complaint or order must be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. A copy of the complaint or order must also be filed with the clerk of Ramsey County, where the dwelling is located, and the filing of the complaint or order has the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.060 - Injunctive relief. 
    Any person affected by an order issued by the nuisance control officer may petition the district court, in accordance with the procedure provided in N.D.C.C. Section 28-34-01, for an injunction restraining the nuisance control officer from carrying out the provisions of the order, and the court may, upon that petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the nuisance control officer pending the final disposition of the cause. Hearings must be held by the court on the petitions within twenty days, or as soon thereafter as possible, and must be given preference over other matters on the court's calendar. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and enter a final order or decree in the proceeding. In the proceeding, the findings of the nuisance control officer as to facts, if supported by evidence, are conclusive. The court may assess costs. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.070 - Exclusive remedies. 
    The remedies provided under this chapter are exclusive remedies and a person affected by an order of the public officer may not recover any damages for action taken pursuant to any order of the nuisance control officer, or because of compliance by that person with any order of the nuisance control officer. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.080 - Powers of the nuisance control officer. 
    This chapter authorizes the nuisance control officer to exercise those powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this chapter, including the following powers in addition to other authority granted in this chapter: 
A.  To investigate the dwelling conditions in the municipality in order to determine which dwellings are unfit for human habitation, or substandard buildings or structures; 
B.  To administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence; 
C.  To enter any premises for the purpose of making examination, provided that entry must be made in a manner that causes the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession, and to obtain an order for this purpose from a Court of competent jurisdiction in the event entry is denied or resisted; 
D.  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as the nuisance control officer deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the chapter; and 
E.  To delegate any of the public officer's functions and powers under this chapter to such officers, agents, and employees as the nuisance control officer may designate. The city commission shall designate who will conduct any hearings provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.090 - Estimate of expenses. 
    As soon as the ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted by the city of Devils Lake, the city commission shall prepare an estimate, as soon as possible, of the annual expenses or costs to provide the equipment, personnel, and supplies necessary for periodic examinations and investigations of the dwellings in the municipality for the purpose of determining the fitness of the dwellings for human habitation, and for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
8.32.100 - Nonexclusive provisions. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter may not be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of any court or the City of Devils Lake to enforce any ordinances, laws, statutes, or regulations, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by the ordinance codified in this chapter are in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other ordinance, law, statute, or regulation. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter may not be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city of Devils Lake to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
    The city of Devils Lake may adopt additional ordinances prescribing minimum standards for the use and occupancy of dwellings throughout the city of Devils Lake and to prevent the use or occupancy of any dwelling which is injurious to the public health, safety, morals, or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 901, 9-17-12) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
DIVISION I. - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT 
Chapter 9.01 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

9.01.010 - Generally. 
    Words and phrases used in this title of the municipal code shall have the meanings and be defined as provided in the North Dakota Century Code Title 12.1, and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this title to the municipal code. 
    The provisions of this title of the municipal code are declared to be severable, and if any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this title shall for any reason be held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining sections, sentences, clauses and phrases of this title, but they shall remain in effect, it being the legislative intent that this title shall stand notwithstanding the invalidity of any part. 
(Ord. 800, 1996) 
Chapter 9.02 - RESISTING POLICE 
Sections: 

9.02.010 - Unlawful to flee. 
    Any person, other than the driver of a motor vehicle under Section 39-10-71 of the North Dakota Century Code, who willfully fails or refuses to stop or who otherwise flees or attempts to elude, in any manner, a pursuing peace officer, when given a visual or audible signal to stop, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor for a first and second offense and a class A misdemeanor for a subsequent offense. A signal to stop complies with this section if the signal is perceptible to the person and: 
A.  If given from a vehicle, the signal is given by hand, voice, emergency light, or siren and the vehicle is appropriately marked showing it to be an official law enforcement vehicle; or 
B.  If not given from a vehicle, the signal is given by hand, voice, emergency light, or siren, and the officer is in uniform and prominently displays the officer's badge of office. 
(Ord. 564, 1974) 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1, 1-18-11) 
9.02.020 - Resisting an officer. 
    Any person who shall, after being advised by a police officer that he is under arrest, resist the police officer, and any person who interferes with or impedes a police officer in making any arrest or in taking any arrested person to the police station or before the police magistrate or who wilfully interferes with or impedes a police officer in the performance of his official duty shall be guilty of resisting an officer. 
(Ord. 371 § 1, 1954) 
9.02.030 - Escape. 
    Any person who escapes from a police officer after he has been arrested or who escapes from the city jail after having been placed therein or who escapes from the place where he may be working out his sentence after conviction shall be guilty of escape. 
(Ord. 371 § 2, 1954) 
9.02.040 - Assisting escape. 
    Any person who assists any person who has been arrested or imprisoned to escape from the officer having him in charge or from the city jail or from any place where he may be employed shall be guilty of assisting escape. 
(Ord. 371 § 3, 1954) 
Chapter 9.04 - OBSTRUCTING FIREMEN 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - Resistance unlawful. 
    No person shall, at any fire, wilfully hinder, delay or resist, or obstruct any officer, fireman or other person in the discharge of his duty or shall neglect or refuse to obey or observe any lawful commands of any officer, or shall conduct himself in a riotous or disorderly manner. 
(Ord. 276(part), 1940) 
9.04.020 - Restrictions. 
A.  No automobile, truck or other vehicle shall follow any fire truck or any fire equipment being utilized by the fire department in the course of its duty, in going to or returning from any fire, within a distance of five hundred feet, nor stop within or traverse in any block in which the fire department may be operating in the performance of its duty. 
B.  Any automobile, truck or other vehicle of any kind or character which may be overtaken by any fire truck or equipment utilized in the performance of duty by members of the fire department in going to or returning from any fire, shall immediately pull to the curb and remain there until the fire truck or equipment has passed, and shall then as quickly as possible and as soon as convenient turn to a side street if the continuance of such street would bring them within the distances prohibited in this chapter. 
C.  The provisions of this section shall not relate to any fireman in using his own or any other vehicle in the course of his duty, in attending to or returning from fires, and it shall be the duty of each member of the fire department to place upon his automobile, or such vehicle that he may use in the course of his duty, a sign plainly visible containing the word "Fireman," and it shall be the duty of the fire department to designate the color of the letters and the size of the sign to be so used by the members of the department as early as possible. 
(Ord. 276(part), 1940) 
Chapter 9.06 - FALSE INFORMATION TO OFFICERS 
Sections: 

9.06.010 - Unlawful. 
    No person shall give false information to any police officer relative to any violation of any of the ordinances of the city or relative to any violations of the state statutes. 
(Ord. 560 § 1, 1974) 
9.06.020 - Custody of person driving while intoxicated. 
    Any person charged with the offense of driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs upon posting of a bond on such charge, may be released from custody; provided, that the person shall not be allowed to drive a motor vehicle until his or her blood alcohol level is less than one-tenth of one percent. However, any third person who signs a form to the effect that he will be responsible for the person charged with this offense will take the person to his place of residence, and not allow the person to drive a motor vehicle, will be allowed to provide transportation to the person charged with this offense for the purpose of transporting him to his home. However, if any person charged with driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle is released to a responsible third person pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and the third person signs a written statement agreeing to be responsible as indicated in this section, the third person upon being found to have allowed the person charged to drive such vehicle, will be guilty of violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 560 § 2, 1974) 
DIVISION II. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 
Chapter 9.14 - GENERAL OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 
Sections: 

9.14.010 - Assault and battery. 
    An individual is guilty of an offense of assault and battery if that individual: 
A.  Wilfully causes bodily injury to another human being; or 
B.  Negligently causes bodily harm to another human being by means of a firearm, destructive device or other weapon, the use of which against a human being is likely to cause death or serious bodily injury. 
C.  In addition to other sentencing alternatives given at the discretion of the court, an individual convicted of assault and battery as described in this section must be sentenced as follows: 
1.  For a first offense a court must impose a fine of at least three hundred dollars or imprisonment for at least ten days or both. The court may not defer or stay the imposition of sentence or judgment provided herein. 
2.  For a second offense a court, must impose a fine of at least five hundred dollars or imprisonment for at least twenty days or both. The court may not defer, suspend or stay the imposition of sentence or judgment provided in this section. 
3.  For a third or subsequent offense a court, must impose a fine of at least one thousand dollars or imprisonment for at least thirty days or both. The court may not defer, suspend or stay the imposition of sentence or judgment provided in this section. 
(Ord. 831, 2000: Ord. 789 (part), 1994: prior code § 288) 
9.14.011 - Arrest without warrant. 
    A law enforcement officer may arrest a person without a warrant if from the time the officer determines there is probable cause to arrest for an assault of a family or household member as defined in Section 14-07.1-01 of the North Dakota Century Code, and all subsequent amendments, the officer has twelve hours in which to make a warrantless arrest, whether or not the assault took place in the presence of the officer. After twelve hours has elapsed, the officer must secure an arrest warrant before making an arrest. A law enforcement officer may not arrest a person pursuant to this subdivision without first observing that there has been recent physical injury to, or impairment of physical condition of the alleged victim. 
(Ord. 789 (part), 1994) 
(Ord. No. 919, 3-17-14) 
9.14.020 - Unguarded or unsafe openings unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person in the city to leave or keep open, uncovered or unguarded, any cellar door, pit, grating or any vault or other subterranean passage opening from, into or upon any street, alley or sidewalk; nor is it lawful for any person to suffer any such cellar door or vault, grating or other opening or place of a like nature, connected with the premises owned or occupied by him or her to remain in an insecure or other unsafe condition, so that persons may fall into or be otherwise injured by it. 
(Prior code § 296) 
9.14.030 - Criminal trespass. 
    A person is guilty of criminal trespass in either of the following instances: 
A.  If, knowing that person is not licensed or privileged to do so, that person enters or remains in any place as to which notice against trespass is given by actual communication to the actor by the person in charge of the premises or other authorized person or by posting in a manner reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders. The name of the person posting the premises must appear on either sign in legible characters; 
B.  If that person remains upon the property of another after being requested to leave the property by a duly authorized person. 
    This section of the Devils Lake Municipal Code is adopted from North Dakota Century Code Section 12.1-22-03(3) and (4), and as those sections of North Dakota law are amended or modified, this section of the Devils Lake Municipal Code shall by reference likewise be amended and modified. 
(Ord. 805, 1997) 
Chapter 9.16 - STEALING AND RECEIVING STOLEN PROPERTY 
Sections: 

9.16.010 - Theft of property or services. 
    No person shall commit theft of property or services anywhere in the city. For the purpose of this section, a person commits theft when he or she, with intent to deprive the owner thereof, knowingly: 
A.  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of another; or 
B.  Obtains by deception control over property of another; or 
C.  Obtains by fraud, stealth or deception the services of another. 
(Ord. 799, 1996: Ord. 736, 1989: Ord. 488 § 1, 1968) 
9.16.020 - Possession of stolen property. 
    Any person who is in possession of any personal property that has been stolen from another, knowing it to have been stolen, and with intent to deprive the owner thereof, shall be guilty of possession of stolen property; and, upon conviction thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 673 § 2, 1984) 
DIVISION III - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY 
Chapter 9.24 - NUISANCES AND OFFENSES 
Sections: 

9.24.010 - Designated. 
    The following are public nuisances affecting public morals and decency: 
A.  All gambling devices, slot machines and punch-boards and all games of chance, gambling and betting; 
B.  All houses kept for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse, gambling houses, houses of ill fame and bawdy houses and resorting to any such place or enticing others to resort thereto; 
C.  All domestic animals in the act of copulation exposed to public view; 
D.  All places where intoxicating liquors are manufactured, sold, bartered or given away in violation of law or where persons are permitted to resort for the purpose of drinking intoxicating liquors kept for sale, barter or distributed in violation of law and all liquors, bottles, kegs, pumps, bars and other property kept at and used for maintaining such a place; 
E.  Any vehicle used for any immoral or illegal purpose; 
F.  All indecent or obscene pictures, books, pamphlets, magazines and newspapers; 
G.  The public use of profane or obscene language; 
H.  Betting, bookmaking and all apparatus used in such occupation; 
I.  Places used for the holding of public dances unless conducted as provided by law. 
(Prior code § 66) 
9.24.020 - Spitting or throwing litter. 
    No person shall spit or expectorate nor throw fruit, fruit parings or skins, nuts or nut shells upon the sidewalks or crossing of any street, avenue, alley or driveway, within the corporate limits of the city, nor in or upon the floors, stairs, or hallways within, or sidewalks leading to or from any public building, theater, public hall or any railway depot or platform, connected therewith, or leading thereto, whether the public building, theater, hall or depot belongs to the city or not, nor shall any person spit or expectorate in or upon the floor or platform of any public conveyance. 
(Prior code § 303) 
9.24.030 - Cruelty to animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city to inhumanely, unnecessarily or cruelly beat, injure or otherwise abuse any dumb animal. 
(Prior code § 292) 
Chapter 9.26 - MARIJUANA 
Sections: 

9.26.010 - Possession unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person not authorized by law to possess marijuana in the city. 
(Ord. 649 § 1, 1982) 
Chapter 9.28 - PROSTITUTION 
Sections: 

9.28.010 - Prostitution-Unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to be an inmate of a house of prostitution or otherwise engaged in sexual activity as a business or to solicit another person with the intention of being hired to engage in sexual activity. 
(Ord. 707 (part), 1987) 
9.28.020 - Penalty-Violation. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter may receive a fine not to exceed the sum of five hundred dollars or a jail term not to exceed thirty days and/or both. 
(Ord. 707 (part), 1987) 
9.28.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  A "house of prostitution" is any place where prostitution is regularly carried on by a person under the control, management, or supervision of another. 
B.  An "inmate" is a prostitute who acts as such in or through the agency of a house of prostitution. 
C.  A "prostitute" is a person who engages in sexual activity for hire. 
D.  "Sexual activity" means sexual act or sexual contact as those terms are hereby defined: 
1.  "Sexual act" means sexual contact between human beings consisting of contact between the penis and the vulva, the penis and the anus, the mouth and the penis, or the mouth and the vulva; or the use of an object which comes in contact with the victim's anus, vulva, or penis. For the purposes of this subsection, sexual contact between the penis and the anus or an object and the anus, vulva, or penis of the victim, occurs upon penetration however slight. Emission is not required. 
2.  "Sexual contact" means any touching of sexual or other intimate parts of the person for the person for the purpose of arousing or satisfying sexual or aggressive desires. 
(Ord. 707 (part), 1987) 
Chapter 9.30 - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA 

9.30.010 - Unlawful possession of drug paraphernalia. 
    A person may not use or possess with intent to use drug paraphernalia to process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body marijuana or marijuana derivatives. Any person violating this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 928, 8-17-15) 
9.30.020 - Definitions-Drug paraphernalia. 
    Drug paraphernalia is defined as objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana derivatives into the human body, including but not limited to any of the following: 
1.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls. 
2.  Water pipes. 
3.  Carburetion tubes and devices. 
4.  Smoking and carburetion masks. 
5.  Objects, sometimes commonly referred to as roach clips used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand. 
6.  Chamber pipes. 
7.  Carburetor pipes. 
8.  Electric pipes. 
9.  Air-driven pipes. 
10.  Chillums. 
11.  Bongs. 
12.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
(Ord. No. 928, 8-17-15) 
9.30.030 - Guidelines-Drug paraphernalia. 
    In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court or other authority shall consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, any of the following: 
A.  Statements by an owner or anyone in control of the object concerning its use. 
B.  Prior convictions, if any, of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, under any state or federal law relating to any controlled substance. 
C.  The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation of NDCC Chapter 19-03.1 or equivalent ordinance. 
D.  The proximity of the object to controlled substances. 
E.  The existence of any residue of controlled substances. 
F.  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner, or of any person in control of the object, to deliver the object to another person whom the owner or person in control of the object knows, or should reasonably know, intends to use the object to facilitate a violation of NDCC Chapter 19-03.1, or equivalent ordinance. The innocence of an owner, or of any person in control of the object, as to a direct violation of NDCC Chapter 19-03.1 or equivalent ordinance may not prevent a finding that the object is intended or designed for use as drug paraphernalia. 
G.  Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning the object's use. 
H.  Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict the object's use. 
I.  National or local advertising concerning the object's use. 
J.  The manner in which the object is displayed for sale. 
K.  Whether the owner, or anyone in control of the object, is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products. 
L.  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the object or objects to the total sales of the business enterprise. 
M.  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
N.  Expert testimony concerning the object's use. 
O.  The actual or constructive possession by the owner or by a person in control of the object or the presence in a vehicle or structure where the object is located. 
P.  Written instructions, directions, or recipes to be used, or intended or designed to be used, in manufacturing, producing, processing, preparing, testing, or analyzing a controlled substance. 
(Ord. No. 928, 8-17-15) 
DIVISION IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 
Chapter 9.34 - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE DESIGNATED 
Sections: 

9.34.010 - Begging prohibited. 
    No person shall within the city place himself upon any sidewalk or public street for the purpose of begging or receiving alms, or go about the city from place to place, begging alms without the written permission of the president of the board or city commissioners. 
(Prior code § 300) 
9.34.020 - Certain assemblies on streets unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any number of persons to assemble upon any sidewalk, bridge, street, alley or public way in the city, which may tend to hinder or impede free public travel thereon, or hinder or impede free egress to and from any place of business, public hall, church or other building, and any of the persons so assembled who shall refuse or neglect to move away, depart and give free passage, after being requested to do so by the chief of police or any police officer, or by the owner, occupant or manager, of any such place of business, hall or church, obstructed as aforesaid, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 286) 
9.34.030 - Setting up stand for sale of goods unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person upon any of the streets or public grounds within the city to set up any stand or wagon for the purpose of selling therefrom or exposing for sale any meat, provisions, refreshments, or any goods or merchandise, or to cry out or expose for sale any property without the written permission of the president of the board of city commissioners or the board of city commissioners. 
(Prior code §298) 
9.34.040 - Certain games in streets prohibited. 
    No person shall within the city, upon any street or alley, take part in any game of ball, nor shall any person upon any such street or alley take part in any game or play tending to frighten teams or to impede or endanger public travel thereon. 
(Prior code §301) 
9.34.050 - Throwing missiles unlawful. 
    No person shall throw or cast or encourage, aid or assist others in throwing or casting any stone or other missiles into, upon or against any building, erection or other public or private property, or at any person or persons within the city. 
(Prior code §280) 
Chapter 9.36 - DISORDERLY CONDUCT 
Sections: 

9.36.010 - Vandalism. 
    A person is guilty of an offense if he wilfully tampers with tangible property of another so as to endanger person or property; or if he wilfully damages tangible property of another. 
(Ord. 661 §2, 1983) 
9.36.020 - Disorderly conduct designated. 
    An individual is guilty of the offense of disorderly conduct if, with intent to harass, annoy or alarm another person or in reckless disregard of the fact that another person is harassed, annoyed or alarmed by his behavior, the individual: 
A.  Engages in fighting, or in violent, tumultuous or threatening behavior; 
B.  Makes unreasonable noise, including, but not limited to, the illegal discharge of fireworks; 
C.  In a public place, uses obscene language or fighting words or makes an obscene gesture; 
D.  Obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or the use of public facilities; 
E.  Persistently follows a person in or about a public place or places; 
F.  While loitering in a public place for the purpose of soliciting sexual contact, he solicits such contact; 
G.  Creates a hazardous, physically offensive or seriously alarming condition by any act which serves no legitimate purpose; 
H.  Engages in harassing conduct by means of intrusive or unwanted acts, words or gestures that are intended to adversely affect the safety, security or privacy of another person; 
I.  Knowingly allows or permits another individual to engage in any illegal conduct; 
J.  This section does not apply to constitutionally protected activity. If an individual claims to have been engaged in a constitutionally protected activity, the court shall determine the validity of the claim as a matter of law and, if found valid, shall exclude evidence of the activity. 
(Ord. 871 (part), 2006: Ord. 830 (part), 2000: Ord. 693, 1986; Ord. 692, 1986: Ord. 661 §3, 1983) 
9.36.025 - Disorderly house/disorderly vehicle. 
    An individual who knowingly permits disorderly conduct as described in Section 9.36.020 of this chapter to occur within or upon any premises, property or motor vehicle owned, possessed, or under the individual's control, is guilty of the offense of disorderly house/disorderly vehicle, which is an offense. 
(Ord. 871 (part), 2006: Ord. 830 (part), 2000) 
9.36.030 - Discharging firearms. 
    A person is guilty of an offense if he or she discharges any gun or firearm within the limits of the city, subject to the following exceptions: 
A.  Duly appointed law officers acting in the performance of their duty shall not be considered. 
B.  Indoor Shooting Ranges-License Required. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person, firm, association, group or corporation to operate or conduct a shooting range in this city without first having obtained a license to do so. The term "shooting range" as used in this section, means any public or private indoor place or range for shooting and discharging firearms at a target. 
2.  Any shooting range already operational prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section shall not be required, however, to obtain a license. 
C.  Qualifications of Applicant. No license shall be issued to any person unless the applicant shall file a sworn application, accompanied by the required fees, showing the following qualifications: 
1.  Applicant, if an individual, must be a citizen of the United States and be a person of good moral character and be at least twenty-one years of age. 
2.  Applicant or manager must not have been convicted of a felony involving violence or intimidation, or the use of firearms of any offense related to the use, control, possession or sale of firearms within ten years of the date of application; or to any person prohibited from possessing firearms as provided by North Dakota Century Code, Section 62.1-02-01. 
3.  Any building in which business is to be conducted must meet federal, state and local requirements regarding sanitation and safety. 
4.  If the applicant's place of business is to be conducted by a manager or agent, the manager or agent must possess the same qualifications of the licensee. 
D.  Application. Any person, firm, association, group or corporation desiring a license to operate or conduct any shooting range as hereinabove described, shall make and present a written verified application to the city commission of the city, filed with the city auditor containing the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; if the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each member of the partnership; if the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of the corporation and the manager of the licensed premises; 
2.  The legal description and the address of the premises for which a license is sought; 
3.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any felony involving violence or intimidation, or the use of firearms or any offense related to the use, control, possession or sale of firearms within ten years of the date of application; 
4.  Whether the applicant is a person prohibited from possessing firearms as provided by North Dakota Century Code Section 62.1-02-01. 
E.  Fee. The fee for a license to conduct or operate a shooting range or gallery shall be ten dollars per year. 
F.  Ballistic Security. A professionally designed and commercially fabricated bullet trap and/or backstop shall be installed in all shooting areas. It shall be constructed of forged steel or other material capable of stopping the flight of any bullet and preventing penetration. Provisions shall be made to stop glancing bullets or particles of bullets at the sides of the target area. 
G.  Alcohol Prohibited. No alcoholic beverages shall be possessed or consumed on the premises and no person under the influence of alcohol, mind-altering drugs, or controlled substance as defined by Chapter 19.03.1 of the North Dakota Century Code shall be allowed on the premises. 
H.  Smoking Prohibited. Smoking is prohibited in any area of the premises where powder or primers are in storage. Smoking shall be allowed within the shooting range or gallery, at the discretion of the range officer. 
I.  Minors. Person under the age of eighteen utilizing the shooting range shall be accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or responsible adult. 
J.  Presence of Bystanders. Persons not shooting or coaching shooters shall not be permitted within the immediate area of the shooting range or gallery, unless a secure and separate viewing area is constructed. 
K.  Location of Persons Beyond Shooting Line. No person shall be allowed beyond a designated shooting line unless in the performance of normal maintenance in the absence of shooters. 
L.  Storage and Transportation of Firearms. All firearms shall be stored and/or transported in an unloaded condition and in a secured case holster, cabinet or vault. 
M.  Access Under Continuous Control. Access for entrance to the shooting range shall be continuous control, monitoring and supervision by the licensee, agent or employee. 
N.  Ammunition and Weapons Prohibited. 
1.  No person shall use or permit to be used any armor piercing, or other ammunition designed for penetrating metal, or tracers, incendiary, gas or explosive ammunition within any shooting range governed hereunder. Ammunition caliber shall be limited to .22 or less and firearms allowed are specifically limited to those firearms firing .22 short, long or long rifle and to spring and gas powered pellet guns. 
2.  No person shall use or permit to be used any machine gun, submachine gun, or fully automatic weapons within any shooting range governed hereunder. 
3.  Center fire ammunition and firearms may only be allowed at the discretion of the city commission in a premises that would provide the increased backstop security and fresh air ventilation that such ammunition requires. 
4.  As used in this section, unless a context otherwise requires, the terms "machine gun," "submachine gun," or "fully automatic weapon" mean a firearm, mechanism or instrument not requiring that the trigger be pressed for each shot, and having a reservoir, belt or other means of storing and carrying ammunition which can be loaded into the firearm, mechanism or instrument and fired therefrom at a rate of five or more shots to the second. 
O.  Compliance with Applicable Laws. The conduct and operation of any shooting range shall be in compliance with any and all federal, state and/or local laws, rules, codes and/or regulations. 
P.  Noise. Adequate noise baffling or buffering shall be installed to prevent injury to the hearing of unprotected persons outside of the area where firearms are actually being discharged and to prevent disturbance to the neighborhood surrounding the shooting area. Under no circumstances shall a license be granted for any firing range which is located within a residentially zoned area or in close proximity thereto. 
Q.  Ventilation. In any range in which a .22 caliber rimfire or center fire ammunition in being used, a positive flow ventilation system shall be installed prior to use. Such a system shall be adequate to remove contaminants in the air as not to endanger the health of users, coaches, spectators or employees. A positive flow ventilation system is not required, if the range is only to be used for spring or gas-powered pellet guns. 
R.  Revocation or Suspension of License. The chief of police and/or chief of the fire department shall revoke any license issued hereunder if the license has, since the granting of the same: 
1.  Ceased to possess the qualifications required for an applicant for a license as set out herein; 
2.  Been convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section; 
3.  Conducted the business in violation of health, sanitary or safety regulations or other ordinances of the city; 
4.  For any cause deemed by the city commission to be sufficient cause and justified by reason of public health or public safety. 
S.  Transfer of License. No license under the provisions of this section shall be transferable either as to licensee or as to premises without first making application to and receiving approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. 768, 1992: Ord. 661 § 4, 1983) 
Chapter 9.38 - PROWLING OR LOITERING* 
Sections: 

9.38.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meaning: 
A.  "Loitering" means remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time loitering, loafing, wandering, standing or remaining idle, whether said loitering is done while an individual is in a motor vehicle or outside of a motor vehicle. 
B.  "Public" includes that which is open to common use and used by an individual, without restriction, permit or permission. 
(Ord. 785 (part), 1994) 
9.38.020 - Loitering prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to loiter either alone and/or in concert with others in a public place in such manner as to: 
A.  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk, public parking lot, or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tend to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians; 
B.  Commit in or about any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or public parking lot, or any other place or building, any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk, public parking lot or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress, therein, thereon and thereto; 
C.  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace, or create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
D.  The making of unsolicited remarks of any offensive, disgusting or insulting nature or which are calculated to annoy or disturb the person whom, or in whose hearing, they are made. 
(Ord. 785 (part), 1994) 
9.38.030 - Refusal to disperse unlawful. 
    When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in this chapter, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such order shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 785 (part), 1994) 
9.38.040 - Violations designated. 
    A person commits a violation if: 
A.  A person loiters or prowls in a place, at a time, or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm is warranted is the fact that the actor takes flight upon appearance of a police officer, refuses to identify himself or herself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or herself, or any object; 
B.  Unless flight by the actor or other circumstance makes it impractical, a police officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under Section 9.38.040(A), afford the actor an opportunity to dispel any alarm which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the actor identify themselves and explain their presence or conduct; 
C.  No person shall be convicted of an offense under subsection A of this section if the police officer did not comply with subsection B of this section, or if it appears at the trial that the explanation given by the actor was true, and if believed by the police officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm; 
D.  An individual violates any of the provisions set out in Section 9.38.020, and refuses to disburse, upon request under Section 9.38.030. 
(Ord. 785 (part), 1994: Ord. 566 (part), 1974) 
9.38.050 - Loitering in parking lots. 
A.  Definitions. As used in this section: 
    "Loitering" means remaining idle in essentially one location and includes the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or walking about aimlessly, and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around," whether loitering is done while an individual is in a motor vehicle or outside of a motor vehicle. 
    "Parking lot" includes any areas within the city of Devils Lake which area would allow for the parking of four or more motor vehicles. 
B.  Types of Loitering Which Are Prohibited by This Section. No persons shall loiter in a parking lot in such manner as to: 
1.  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace; 
2.  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
3.  Obstruct a free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; or 
4.  Obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
    This section shall include the making of unsolicited remarks of any offensive, disgusting or insulting nature or which are calculated to annoy or disturb the person to whom, or in whose hearing, they are made. 
C.  Notice and Signs. 
1.  All parking lots which are owned by the city shall have posted signs stating this prohibition against loitering which signs shall contain the following language: 
"Loitering prohibited under Section 9.38.050 of the Municipal Code." 
2.  Any parking lot not owned by the city, which includes those parking lots owned by the Devils Lake parking authority, shall be subject to the same provisions of this section, if, the owner of that parking lot does place signs identical to those referred to in subsection (C)(1) of this section. These signs are to be placed on that parking lot by the owner of the parking lot, and the owner shall bear the expense of obtaining and placing those signs upon the parking lot. The city may provide assistance in obtaining and placing these signs in the parking lot, however, all cost is to be paid by the owner of the parking lot. 
D.  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each time a violation does occur under this section. 
E.  Enforcement of Section. This section can be enforced by any person, including a law enforcement officer who has witnessed any violation of this section. 
F.  Inapplicability of Section and Permits. This section shall not apply to any activities which are conducted by and under the direction of an owner of a parking lot, which is owned by an entity other than the city. Additional activities can be conducted upon parking lots, however, it shall be necessary to file with the city auditor an application for a permit to conduct such activity, and it shall be within the discretion of the city commission whether or not to allow such activity and the city commission shall further set forth any rules or guidelines which govern that activity. 
(Ord. 821, 1998) 
Chapter 9.40 - ADVERTISING VEHICLES AND LOUDSPEAKERS 
Sections: 

9.40.010 - Permit required. 
    No person, copartnership, firm or corporation can use the streets of the city for advertising purposes without first filing an application with the city auditor stating generally the nature of the vehicle or the equipment sought to be used and the time and purpose of such use; and it shall be the duty of the city auditor to present the application to the chief of police, who shall examine it and ascertain if the purposes set forth violate any ordinance of the city. If approved by the chief of police, the city auditor shall issue a permit and such person, copartnership, firm or corporation shall pay a license fee as shall be established by resolution of the city commission, and revised as it may see fit. 
(Ord. 677 (part), 1984: Ord. 275 § 1, 1940) 
9.40.020 - Disturbing the peace unlawful. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to make any unseemly noises with loudspeakers or other equipment so as to unduly disturb the peace and quietude of the city. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person, copartnership, firm or corporation to whom a permit has been granted to use such loudspeaker or other advertising apparatus while passing by a church, hospital or theater and no such loudspeaker or other advertising equipment shall be used on the streets of the city on a Sunday. 
(Ord. 275 § 2, 1940) 
9.40.030 - Obstruction of view unlawful. 
    No vehicle or other conveyance used for advertising purposes shall be so constructed as to unduly obstruct the view of pedestrians or persons driving or being conveyed in any vehicle of any kind or character. 
(Ord. 275 § 3, 1940) 
Chapter 9.42 - THEATERS, MOTION PICTURE SHOWS AND OTHER PLACES OF ENTERTAINMENT 
Sections: 

9.42.010 - Hours of use. 
    No theater, motion picture house, carnival or other place of amusement shall conduct any public show, picture, act, exhibition or theatrical performance of any kind between the hours of twelve-thirty a.m. and eight a.m.; provided, however, that for good cause shown, the commission may grant a special permit for any such performance when in its opinion it will not cause unreasonable disturbance of the peace of the city. 
(Ord. 347 § 1, 1952) 
Chapter 9.44 - ENGINE BRAKES AND COMPRESSION BRAKES 
Sections: 

9.44.010 - Unlawful use of engine brakes and compression brakes. 
A.  It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within the city limits of the city of Devils Lake, any engine brake, compression brake, or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle that results in excessive, loud, unusual, or explosive noise from such vehicle. 
B.  The scheduled fine for a violation of this section shall be fifty dollars. 
(Ord. 866 (part), 2005) 
9.44.020 - Severability. 
    If any section, provision, or any part of this chapter shall be adjudged to be invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect the validity of the ordinance codified in this chapter as a whole or any section, provision, or any part thereof, not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. 866 (part), 2005) 
9.44.030 - Effective date. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be in effect after its final passage, approval and publication as provided by law. 
(Ord. 866 (part), 2005) 
DIVISION V - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
Chapter 9.50 - DAMAGING PUBLIC PROPERTY 
Sections: 

9.50.010 - Entry for unlawful purpose prohibited. 
    Any person who enters any store, residence, boxcar, automobile or other building, structure or vehicle for the purpose of committing any crime or breach of peace shall be guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 659 § 2, 1983: prior code § 282) 
9.50.020 - Injuring streetlights unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to mar, disfigure or in any way injure, break or destroy any street signpost or any ornamental street lightpost or any of the fixtures, globes or incandescent bulbs used in connection herewith, or to otherwise interfere with the street lighting system of the city. 
(Prior code § 276) 
9.50.030 - Setting fires while smoking unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person, who by smoking or attempting to light cigarettes, cigars, pipes or tobacco, or otherwise, to set fire to any fittings, furnishings, or part of any hotel, motel, roominghouse, lodginghouse or other place of public abode, so as to endanger life or property in any way, or to any extent. 
(Ord. 677 (part), 1984: Ord. 601, 1976) 
9.50.040 - Encroachment on public property. 
    It is unlawful to encroach upon any public street, right-of-way, alley, boulevard, or other public property by placing thereon any personal property; or erecting thereon any building or structure; except as may be specified by ordinance or approved by the city engineer. Any encroachment may be removed, obliterated or corrected by order of the city engineer and the total cost thereof shall be paid by the person responsible for the encroachment. 
(Ord. 684, 1986) 
Chapter 9.52 - LITTERING AND EXPECTORATING 
Sections: 

9.52.010 - Littering streets or alleys. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons, firm or corporation, to throw, place or leave upon any street or alley within the city, any paper, cloth or waste material, or leave in any yard or place where it may blow, or be liable to blow upon any street or alley within the city, any paper, cloth or waste material. 
(Prior code § 295) 
9.52.020 - Littering or expectorating in public places. 
    No person shall spit nor expectorate nor throw fruit, fruit parings or skins, nuts or nut shells upon the sidewalks or crossing of any street, avenue, alley or driveway within the corporate limits of the city, nor in or upon the floors, stairs or hallways within, or sidewalks leading to or from any public building, theater, public hall or any railway depot or platform, connected therewith, or leading thereto, whether the public building, theater, hall or depot belongs to the city or not; nor shall any person spit or expectorate in or upon the floor or platform of any public conveyance. 
(Prior code § 303) 
Chapter 9.54 - HANDBILLS 
Sections: 

9.54.010 - Consent to post required. 
    No person shall, without first obtaining the consent of the owner or proprietor, paste up, stick up or post up handbills, placards or posters, or make, print or mark any word, letter or advertisement of any kind upon any private house, store or other building, or upon any fence, railing, wall or other property, or shall post up, stick up, nail up or paste any handbills, placards or posters of any kind, or make, print or mark any word, character or advertisement upon any public building, bridge, fence, railing, sidewalk, telegraph pole, telephone pole, electric light pole, or other public property within the city, except in compliance with the requirements of law in the posting of legal notices. 
(Prior code § 293) 
9.54.020 - Distribution restricted. 
    No person shall distribute any handbills, circulars, cards or other advertising matter by placing them in or upon any street, alley or other place where they are likely to be blown by the wind, or by placing them in automobiles. But such handbills or other matter may be distributed by placing them in business places or residences in such manner as not to be a nuisance. 
(Prior code § 294) 
Chapter 9.56 - BREAKING AND ENTERING 
Sections: 

9.56.010 - Designated. 
    Any person who enters any store, residence, boxcar, automobile or other building, structure or vehicle for the purpose of stealing, pilfering or damaging any property or for the purpose of committing any crime or breach of the peace or who steals or takes with intent to deprive the owner thereof of any personal property shall be guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 282) 
DIVISION VI - CONSUMER PROTECTION 
Chapter 9.64 - SOLICITATION WITHOUT INVITATION 
Sections: 

9.64.010 - Prohibited. 
    The practice of going in and upon private residences or privately owned property in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants, transient vendors of merchandise, photographers and magazine and periodical subscription agents, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of such private residences or private property, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and/or peddling or hawking them, and for the purpose of soliciting subscriptions to magazines or periodicals and/or for the purpose of taking photographs is declared to be a nuisance and unlawful. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 4 § 1, 1974) 
9.64.020 - Nuisance abatement. 
    The chief of police and all police officers in the city are required and directed to suppress solicitation without invitation and to abate any such nuisance as described in Section 9.64.010. 
(Ord. 565 Art. 4 § 2, 1974) 
DIVISION VII - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS 
Chapter 9.72 - CURFEW 
Sections: 

9.72.010 - Regulations. 
A.  It is unlawful for any child fourteen years of age or less to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play on or upon or drive or ride about in a vehicle or be in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, or public buildings, places or grounds between the hours of ten-thirty p.m. and five a.m. on any weekday, Monday through Thursday. 
B.  It is unlawful for any child fifteen years of age or less to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play in or upon, or drive or ride about in a vehicle or be in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, or public buildings, places or grounds between the hours of eleven p.m. and five a.m. on any weekday, Monday through Thursday. 
C.  It is unlawful for any child sixteen years of age or less to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play in or upon, or drive or ride about in a vehicle or be in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, or public buildings, places or grounds between the hours of twelve a.m. and five a.m. on any weekday, Monday through Thursday. 
D.  All of the foregoing curfew times and limitations shall be extended one hour to the age groups enumerated above on the evenings of Friday, Saturday, and Sunday and during the summer months commencing on June 1st and ending on August 31st thereof. 
(Ord. 756 (part), 1991: Ord. 456 § 1(part), 1965: Ord. 359 § 1(part), 1953: Ord. 342 § 1(part), 1951: Ord. 294 § 1(part), 1945: prior code § 20(part)) 
9.72.020 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter does not apply to: 
A.  Any child accompanied by a parent, guardian or other adult having their care and custody, or to any child upon emergency errands, or legitimate business directed by their parent, guardian, or the adult person having their care and custody, or to any child traveling to or from a location outside the city on legitimate business or with the consent of a parent or guardian. 
B.  A child in attendance at or traveling between that child's home and a place of legitimate employment or an event or activity sponsored by or associated with school, church or similar organization, or an organized sporting, political, theatrical, or other like event or activity within thirty minutes of the end of the work shift or the conclusion of the event or activity. 
(Ord. 756 (part), 1991: Ord. 456 § 1(part), 1965: Ord. 359 § 1(part), 1953: Ord. 342 § 1(part), 1951: Ord. 294 § 1(part), 1945: prior code § 20(part)) 
9.72.030 - Authority of police officer. 
    A police officer who has probable cause to believe that a child is in violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall take such child to the police station where the child's parents or guardian shall be immediately contacted. If after this contact there is still probable cause to believe that the child was violating the ordinance codified in this chapter, the child shall be held until the parent or guardian comes to take the child home. When the parent or guardian arrives, he or she must be given a copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter. If no parent or guardian has arrived within two hours, the child shall be turned over to the juvenile authorities until a parent or guardian can take custody of him or her. 
(Ord. 756 (part), 1991: Ord. 456 § 1(part), 1965: Ord. 359 § 1(part), 1953: Ord. 342 § 1, 1951: Ord. 294 § 1(part), 1945: prior code § 20 (part)) 
9.72.040 - Parental responsibility. 
    It is unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit or by inefficient control allow a violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter by a child in his or her custody or control. 
(Ord. 756 (part), 1991: Ord. 456 § 1(part), 1965: Ord. 359 § 1(part), 1953: Ord. 342 § 1(part), 1951: Ord. 294 § 1(part), 1945: prior code § 20(part)) 
9.72.050 - Penalty-Violation. 
    Any child, parent, or guardian violating this chapter shall be guilty of an infraction. Each violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 756 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 9.73 - SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS 
Sections: 

9.73.010 - Intent. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter is to preserve and protect the public's health, safety and welfare from the inherent risks and dangers of tobacco use by prohibiting the sale of tobacco products from vending machines, the sale or distribution of tobacco products to minors and the purchase of tobacco products by minors. 
(Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
9.73.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, as used in this chapter, shall be defined as follows: 
A.  "City" means the city of Devils Lake. 
B.  "Distribute" means to give tobacco products to the general public at no cost or at a nominal cost for product promotional purposes. 
C.  "E-cigarette, electronic cigarette or smoking devices" shall all mean any electronic oral device, such as one composed of a heating element and battery or electronic circuit or both, which provides a vapor of nicotine or any other substances, and the use of inhalation of which simulates smoking. The term shall include any such device, whether manufactured, distributed, marketed or sold as an e-cigarette, e-cigar, and e-pipe or under any other produce name, or descriptor and also includes any cartridge or other component of the device. 
D.  "Minor" means any person, regardless of sex, who has not yet reached the age of eighteen. 
E.  "Person" means any individual, partnership, corporation, or other business or other legal entity. 
F.  "Retail tobacco dealer" means any person, as defined herein, selling, offering for sale, exposing for sale or having in possession for sale, at retail, tobacco as defined herein. 
G.  "Sell" besides its ordinary purposes, means dispensing from a vending machine. 
H.  "Tobacco product" means any product that is made from or derived from tobacco, which contains nicotine or a similar substance, and is intended for human consumption or is likely to be consumed, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed, dissolved, inhaled or ingested by any other means, including, but not limited to, a cigarette, a cigar, pipe tobacco, chewing tobacco, snuff, snus, or an electronic smoking device. Tobacco product also includes pipes and rolling papers, but does not include any product specifically approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for legal sale as a tobacco cessation product and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose. The term shall also include e-cigarettes. 
I.  "Vending machine" means any kind of device or mechanical machine which, upon the insertion of a coin or coins, tokens or other objects will release tobacco products in packages or otherwise. 
(Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
(Ord. No. 923, 10-20-14) 
9.73.030 - Sale of tobacco products through vending machines prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to sell or dispense any tobacco product through the use of a vending machine, provided, however, tobacco products may be offered for sale or sold within the city from a vending machine in a licensed on sale or a licensed off sale alcoholic beverage establishment in any area of the premises where persons under twenty one years of age are prohibited and where the vending machine is located within the immediate vicinity, plain view and control of a responsible adult employee, so that all tobacco purchases will be readily observable by the employee. The vending machine shall not be located in the coatroom, restroom, unmonitored hallway, outer waiting area or similar unmonitered area; nor shall the vending machine be accessible to the public when the establishment is closed. 
B.  The effective date of the ordinance codified in this section shall be August 28, 1997. 
(Ord. 807 (part), 1997: Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
9.73.031 - Behind the counter sale of tobacco products. 
A.  Except on licensed alcohol premises, as set forth in Section 9.73.030 of this chapter, no tobacco products may be stored or displayed in a retail outlet in an area or in a manner which allows for self-service access by customers. 
B.  The effective date of the ordinance codified in this section shall be August 28, 1997. 
(Ord. 807 (part), 1997) 
9.73.040 - Sale of tobacco products to minors prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell or distribute tobacco products to a minor. 
(Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
9.73.050 - Purchase and possession of tobacco products by minors prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for a minor to purchase, attempt to purchase, or to have in the possession of the minor any tobacco products. 
(Ord. 802, 1996: Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
9.73.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person violating the provisions of Section 9.73.040 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to a penalty of five hundred dollars. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate punishable offense. 
B.  Any person violating the provisions of Section 9.73.050 of this chapter shall upon conviction, be subject to a penalty of fifty dollars. 
C.  Any person violating the provisions of Section 9.73.030 or 9.73.031 of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty of a fine of up to five hundred ($500.00) dollars for each violation. 
D.  The effective date of the ordinance codified in this section shall be August 28, 1997. 
(Ord. 807 (part), 1997; Ord. 777 (part), 1993) 
DIVISION VIII - WEAPONS 
(RESERVED) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.02 - DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

10.02.010 - Generally. 
    Words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings and be defined as provided in the North Dakota Century Code in Title 39, and North Dakota Century Code S39-01-01 and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this chapter. In this chapter, unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires, the words defined in this chapter will have the meanings listed in Sections 10.02.020 through 10.02.730. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-1(part), 1976) 
10.02.020 - Authorized emergency vehicles. 
A.  "Class A authorized emergency vehicles" means: 
1.  Vehicles of a governmental-owned fire department; 
2.  Vehicles when operated by or under the control of a police officer having authority to enforce the provisions of this title or by a salaried employee of any municipal police department within the municipality or by any sheriff or deputy sheriff not to include special deputy sheriffs, or by the warden of the state penitentiary and his authorized agents; 
3.  Ambulances; 
4.  Vehicles operated by or under the control of the commissioner, and district deputy commissioner, and district deputy game warden of the North Dakota game and fish department; 
5.  Vehicles owned or leased by the United States government used for law enforcement purposes; 
6.  Vehicles designated for the use of the adjutant general and assistant adjutant general in cases of emergency; and 
7.  Vehicles operated by or under the control of the director, assistant director, and park superintendents of the North Dakota parks and recreation department. 
B.  "Class B authorized emergency vehicles" means: 
1.  Wreckers and such other emergency vehicles as are authorized by the local authorities. 
C.  "Class C authorized emergency vehicles" means those vehicles authorized by state and local disaster emergency services organizations and those vehicles used by volunteer firemen while performing their assigned disaster and emergency responsibilities. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 11(part), 1976) 
10.02.030 - Bicycle. 
    "Bicycle" means every device propelled solely by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, either of which is more than twenty inches (50.8 centimeters) in diameter. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 1-2, 1976) 
10.02.040 - Bus. 
    "Bus" means every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. Provided, every motor vehicle designed for carrying not more than fifteen persons and used for a ridesharing arrangement, as defined in Section 8-02-07 of the North Dakota Century Code, is not a "bus." 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 1-3, 1976) 
10.02.050 - Business district. 
    "Business district" means the territory contiguous to a highway when fifty percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of three hundred feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-4, 1976) 
10.02.060 - Commercial freighting. 
    "Commercial freighting" means the carriage of things, other than passengers, for hire, except that the term shall not include: 
A.  The carriage of things other than passengers within the limits of the same city; 
B.  Carriage by local dray lines of baggage or goods to or from a railroad station from or to places in the city or in the immediate vicinity thereof, in this state, and not to exceed two miles from the corporate or recognized limits of the city; or 
C.  Hauling done by farmers for their neighbors in transporting agricultural products to or from market. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-6, 1976) 
10.02.070 - Commercial passenger transportation. 
    "Commercial passenger transportation" means the carriage of passengers for hire, except that the term shall not include: 
A.  The carriage of passengers within the limits of a city; or 
B.  The carriage by local bus lines of passengers to or from a railroad station from or to places within any city or within two miles (3.22 kilometers) of the limits thereof; or 
C.  The carriage of passengers under a ridesharing arrangement, as defined in section 8-02-07 of the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 1-5, 1976) 
10.02.080 - Commissioner. 
    "Commissioner" means the commissioner of the state highway department, acting directly or through his authorized agents. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-7, 1976) 
10.02.090 - Controlled access highway. 
    "Controlled access highway" means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from it except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-8, 1976) 
10.02.100 - Crosswalk. 
    "Crosswalk" means that part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; or any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-9, 1976) 
10.02.110 - Dealer. 
    "Dealer" means every person, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of buying, selling or exchanging motor vehicles, or who advertises, or holds himself out to the public as engaged in the buying, selling or exchanging of motor vehicles, or who engages in the buying of motor vehicles for resale. Any person, partnership, corporation or association doing business in several cities or in several locations within a city shall be considered a separate dealer in each such location. 
(Ord. 599 1-10, 1976) 
10.02.120 - Department. 
    "Department" means the Motor Vehicle Department of this state. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-11, 1976) 
10.02.130 - Director. 
    "Director" means the director of the Division of Public Safety of this state. 
(Ord. 599 1-12, 1976) 
10.02.140 - Division. 
    "Division" means the Division of Public Safety of this state. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-13, 1976) 
10.02.150 - Driver. 
    "Driver" means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-14, 1976) 
10.02.160 - Essential parts. 
    "Essential parts" means all integral and body parts of a vehicle of a type required to be registered under this title, the removal, alteration or substitution of which would tend to conceal the identity of the vehicle or substantially alter its appearance, model, type or mode of operation. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-15, 1976) 
10.02.170 - Explosives. 
    "Explosives" means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by percussion, or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or by destroying life or limb. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-16, 1976) 
10.02.180 - Farm tractor. 
    "Farm tractor" includes every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement for drawing plows, moving machines and other implements of husbandry. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-17, 1976) 
10.02.185 - Farm trailer. 
    "Farm trailer" includes those trailers and semitrailers towed by a bona fide resident farmer hauling his own agricultural, horticultural, dairy, and other farm products if the gross weight, not including the towing vehicle, does not exceed twenty-four thousand pounds (10,886.22 kilograms). 
(Ord. 689 (part), 1986) 
10.02.190 - Flammable liquid. 
    "Flammable liquid" means any liquid which has a flash point of seventy degrees Fahrenheit, or less, as determined by a tagliabue or equivalent closed-cup test device. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-18, 1976) 
10.02.200 - Gross weight. 
    "Gross weight" means the weight of a vehicle without load plus the weight of any load thereon. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-20, 1976) 
10.02.210 - Guest. 
    "Guest" means and includes a person who accepts a ride in any vehicle without giving compensation therefor. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-19, 1976) 
10.02.220 - Highway. 
    "Highway" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel and of every way privately maintained within a mobile home park, trailer park, or campground containing five or more lots for occupancy by mobile homes, travel trailers, or tents when any part thereof is open for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 1-21, 1976) 
10.02.230 - House car. 
    "House car" means a motor vehicle which has been reconstructed or manufactured for private use as a temporary or recreational dwelling and having at least four of the following permanently installed systems: 
A.  Cooking facilities; 
B.  Icebox or mechanical refrigerator; 
C.  Potable water supply including plumbing and a sink with faucet either self-contained or with connections for an external source, or both; 
D.  Self-contained toilet or a toilet connected to a plumbing system with connection for external water disposal, or both; 
E.  Heating or air conditioning system or both, separate from the vehicle engine or the vehicle engine electrical system; 
F.  A 110-115 volt alternating current electrical system separate from the vehicle engine electrical system either with its own power supply or with a connection for an external source, or both, or a liquefied petroleum system and supply. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 1-21.1, 1976) 
10.02.240 - Implement of husbandry. 
    "Implement of husbandry" means every vehicle designed and adapted exclusively for agricultural, horticultural or livestock raising operations or for lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry and in either case not subject to registration if used upon the highway. 
(Ord. 599 § 1-22, 1976) 
10.02.250 - Intersection.
