In all other cases, the appropriate state's attorney shall prosecute the appeal. 
G.  The city must prove the commission of a charged violation at the hearing or appeal under this section by a fair preponderance of the evidence. Upon an appeal under subsection F of this section, the court and parties shall follow, to the extent applicable, the North Dakota Rules of Civil Procedure. If on appeal from the finding of the official the finding is affirmed, costs may be assessed at the discretion of the trial judge. 
H.  As used in Sections 10.46.250 through 10.46.270, the word "official" means a district judge, a judge of a county court, a municipal judge, or, when provided by statute, a person appointed by a district judge to serve as official for all or a specified part of a judicial district. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 20-5, 1976) 
10.46.270 - Failure to appear means admission of guilt. 
A.  The provisions of North Dakota Century Code 39-06.1-04 and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this title. 
B.  If a person fails to choose one of the methods of proceeding set forth in Sections 10.46.250 or 10.46.260, he shall be deemed to have admitted to commission of the violation charged, and the municipal court shall report such fact to the licensing authority within ten days after the date set for the hearing. Failure to appear at the time designated, after signing a promise to appear, without paying the statutory fee or posting and forfeiting bond shall be an offense. Failure to appear without just cause at the hearing shall also be deemed an admission of commission of the violation charged. 
(Ord. 599 § 20-6, 1976) 
10.46.280 - When appeal not permitted. 
A.  The provisions of North Dakota Century Code 39-06.1-05 and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this title. 
B.  The procedures authorized under Sections 10.46.250 and 10.46.260 may not be utilized by a person charged with one of the following offenses: 
1.  Driving or being in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of a controlled substance or intoxicating liquor in violation of Section 10.46.030; 
2.  Reckless driving or aggravated reckless driving in violation of Section 10.46.040; 
3.  Leaving the scene of an accident in violation of Sections 10.46.050 through 10.46.070; 
4.  Driving while license or driving privilege is suspended or revoked in violation of Section 10.46.080; 
5.  Violating Section 10.46.100; 
6.  Driving without a license in violation of Section 10.46.090; 
7.  Operating a modified motor vehicle in violation of Section 10.46.180. 
(Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 20-7, 1976) 
(Ord. No. 920, 3-17-14) 
10.46.290 - Fees for violations. 
A.  The provisions of North Dakota Century Code 39-06.1-06 and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this title. 
B.  The fees required for a noncriminal disposition pursuant either to Section 10.46.250 or Section 10.46.260 shall be as follows: 
1.  For a nonmoving violation as defined in Section 10.46.020, a fee of ten dollars; 
2.  For a moving violation as defined in Section 10.46.010, a fee of twenty dollars; 
3.  For a violation of Section 10.08.020, or an equivalent ordinance, a fee established as follows:

(Ord. 724, 1988; Ord. 688 (part), 1986: Ord. 599 § 20-8, 1976) 
(Ord. No. 920, 3-17-14) 
10.46.300 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  The provisions of North Dakota Century Code 39-07-06 and all subsequent amendments shall be and are incorporated by reference in this title. 
B.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter for which another criminal penalty is not provided specifically, shall be guilty of an infraction. As used in this section, the phrase "another criminal penalty" includes provision for payment of a fixed fee for violating another section in this chapter, but does not include any other administrative sanction which may be imposed. 
(Ord. 599 § 20-11, 1976) 
Chapter 10.47 - RAILROAD CARS AND TRAINS 
Sections: 

10.47.010 - Speed limit of railroad cars and trains. 
    All railroad trains, engines, cars and other equipment or vehicles moving on fixed rails within the inhabited and business limits of the city shall be run and operated at a speed not to exceed that mandated by the Federal Railroad Safety Act, 45 USC Section 434, and relevant regulations covering train speed pursuant to Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations. 
(Ord. 769, 1992: Ord. 762, 1991) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Materials and methods. 
    All sidewalks to be located in public rights-of-way shall be constructed of such materials and by such methods as are specified within the most current edition of the construction specifications of the city for the construction of public sidewalks. 
(Ord. 642 § 1, 1981) 
12.04.020 - Width as required by engineering department. 
    All sidewalks shall be constructed in such a manner that the developed width of the sidewalk will be as required by the city engineering department. 
(Ord. 642 § 2, 1981) 
12.04.030 - Permit required. 
    Prior to the commencement of construction or removal of any sidewalk located, or to be located, in a public right-of-way, a permit shall be obtained for such work from the city engineering department. 
(Ord. 642 § 3, 1981) 
12.04.040 - Inspection prior to and after completion of work. 
A.  All work to be conducted under such permit shall be caused to be inspected, prior to the placement of concrete, by a representative of the city engineering department who will establish the sidewalk grade for the purposes of drainage, public safety and walkway continuity. No permitted work shall proceed without the prior approval of the representative of the city engineering department. 
B.  Upon completion, all such work shall be inspected by a representative of the city engineering department to insure that the completed work has been accomplished in compliance with the construction specifications of the city. 
C.  It shall be the responsibility of the person, or persons, doing the work to arrange inspections with the city engineering department. 
(Ord. 642 § 4, 1981) 
12.04.050 - Permit fee rates established by board of city commissioners. 
    Permit fee rates for construction or removal of sidewalks located, or to be located, in a public right-of-way shall be established by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 642 § 5, 1981) 
12.04.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    In the event that a party constructing or removing sidewalk in a public right- of-way fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter the city commission may refuse to issue further city permits to that party. The commission may impose an administrative fine upon that party in a sum not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars. 
(Ord. 642 § 6, 1981) 
Chapter 12.08 - OPENING STREETS FOR INSTALLATION AND REPAIR OF PUBLIC UTILITIES 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Application and fee for permit. 
A.  Any person, contractor or other entity desiring to open any street or alley within the city for the purpose of installing or repairing public utilities shall, before commencing the installation or repair, apply to the commissioner of the street department or such other person as may be designated by the commissioner of the street department, for permit to open the paved street or alley. 
B.  The fee for opening any street or alley for the installation or repair of public utilities shall be set by resolution of the city commission, and revised as it may see fit. The fee shall be payable within ten days of application for the permit mentioned in subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 685 (part), 1986; Ord. 677 (part), 1984; Ord. 643 § 1, 1981) 
12.08.020 - Regulations. 
A.  The contractor shall have the opening in the street prepared for resurfacing, pursuant to the requirements of this chapter, within seventy-two hours of the original opening. In the event the closure is delayed for good cause shown, the street commissioner or his designee may grant an extension of time for closure not to exceed five additional days. 
B.  When the contractor is opening the street or alley, the opening in the street or alley shall be vertical, with straight edges. 
C.  During the period from when the opening is commenced and until such time as the opening in the street or alley is prepared for resurfacing, the contractor shall barricade the opening, the reflectorized signs and barriers which shall have the name of the contractor affixed on them. When it is necessary to close the street, barricades shall be erected at the nearest intersections on both sides of the opening. 
(Ord. 643 § 2, 1981) 
12.08.030 - Procedure and charge for closure. 
A.  The contractor shall backfill the ditch in maximum eight-inch (loose) lifts to the top of the surfacing and shall notify the director of utilities or his designee at least one day in advance as to the time that the backfilling operation will begin. The director of utilities or his designee shall be present at the site during the backfilling. If employees are required to be present at a backfill site after five p.m. Monday through Friday or anytime on Saturday or Sunday a charge of twenty-five dollars per hour shall be necessary. The bill for the charge shall be sent directly to the contractor with a letter sent to the property owner explaining that the bill is a result of the contractor's planned time of closing. 
B.  The backfill material shall be placed in such a manner that no further settlement occurs. The degree of compaction and moisture content shall be equivalent to the surrounding soil. 
C.  The charge for an employee's time required at a backfill site after five p.m. Monday through Friday or anytime on Saturday or Sunday shall be set by the city commission by January 1st of each year by resolution. 
(Ord. 685 (part), 1986; Ord. 643 § 3, 1981) 
12.08.050 - Replacement of concrete in certain areas. 
    In areas paved with concrete and asphalt, the contractor shall replace the concrete to its original thickness and leave the surface of the concrete two inches below the finished grade. 
(Ord. 643 § 5, 1981) 
12.08.060 - Contractors must have license. 
    All persons contracting to do this type of work shall have a North Dakota contractor's license along with a city contractor's license and have a liability insurance in the minimum amount of three hundred thousand dollars. 
(Ord. 643 § 6, 1981) 
12.08.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    In the event the party opening the street or alley fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter, the city commission may revoke the contractor license and refuse to issue further city permits to the contractor. The commission may impose an administrative fine upon the contractor in a sum not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars per violation. 
(Ord. 643 § 7, 1981) 
Chapter 12.12 - SNOW REMOVAL AND STREET SWEEPING* 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Definitions. 
    It is understood that streets generally run east and west, and avenues generally run north and south. 
(Ord. 763 (part), 1991) 
12.12.020 - Publication of notice for snow removal. 
A.  On or before November 1st of each year a notice shall be published in the official newspaper of the city for seven consecutive days stating that following each snowfall of the winter season the city will remove snow from streets and avenues of the city, and that all vehicles shall be removed from them accordingly. Such notice will state the schedule to be followed. 
B.  In the event of a snowfall prior to the notice, which justifies snow removal, the department head of the street department shall announce a special warning on the radio which gives notice to remove vehicles from the streets or avenues affected. However, the vehicles shall not be removed by the city nor shall penalties described in this section apply unless a minimum of twelve hours have elapsed from the time of this special warning. 
(Ord. 763 (part), 1991) 
12.12.030 - Publication of notice for sweeping. 
A.  On or before April 1st of each year a notice shall be published in the official newspaper of the city for seven consecutive days giving notice to residents that the streets and avenues of the city will be swept on designated days and that all vehicles shall be removed from them on these days. 
B.  Certain days of the week shall be designated for the sweeping of streets and other certain days of the week shall be designated for the sweeping of avenues 
(Ord. 763 (part), 1991) 
12.12.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    All persons who fail to remove their vehicle from the streets or avenues of the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may have their vehicles removed by employees of the city, or their agents to an impound lot or such other convenient place as may be deemed necessary and be subject to a penalty as set forth in the fees and rates as set by the city commission. 
(Ord. 763 (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 959, 12-3-18) 
Chapter 12.13 - OBSTRUCTIONS CAUSED BY SNOW REMOVAL 
Sections: 

12.13.010 - Snow placed on streets. 
    No person shall deposit, place, move, push or locate snow and leave the snow on streets or alleys in the city. 
(Ord. 839 (part), 2000) 
12.13.020 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to the following: 
A.  Snow shoveled from sidewalks to the street or alley in the downtown area, provided the downtown property has no place other than the sidewalk and street to put the snow. For the purposes of this exception, the downtown area is defined as the area between the following: one-half of the block on the outside of 6th Street, the one-half of the block on the outside of 6th Avenue, and the one-half of the block on the outside of Railroad Avenue. 
B.  City employees, while in the course of their employment for the city, may place snow on the streets or alleys while removing the snow from the city. 
C.  By motion of the city commission, the ordinance codified in this chapter may be suspended for a time period and upon conditions set by the city commission. 
(Ord. 839 (part), 2000) 
12.13.030 - Penalty. 
    The penalty for a violation of this chapter shall be set in the fees and rates adopted by the city commission. 
(Ord. 839 (part), 2000) 
12.13.040 - Payment of penalty. 
    The person causing the violation of this chapter shall be responsible to pay the penalty. Should that person fail to pay the penalty, these charges shall be assessed to the property from where the snow was taken. 
(Ord. 839 (part), 2000) 
Chapter 12.14 - REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE 
Sections: 

12.14.010 - Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks. 
    The owner of any lot or parcel of land abutting any sidewalk shall: 
A.  Keep the sidewalk clean and unobstructed at all times. 
B.  Remove snow and ice within twenty-four hours after the snow falls or ice forms, and keep the sidewalk free of ice and snow. Sand, salt, or any chemical product approved by the city engineer may be used to make the area safe for pedestrian travel if removal of ice is impracticable. 
(Ord. No. 957, 12-3-18) 
12.14.020 - Assessment for removal of snow and ice. 
    Should snow and ice not be removed in the manner required, it shall be removed under the direction of the department head of public works or the city engineer, and costs assessed to the abutting property pursuant to Chapter 40-29 and any subsequent amendments. 
(Ord. No. 957, 12-3-18) 
Chapter 12.16 - SHADE TREES* 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words shall have the following meanings: 
A.  "Shade tree foreman" is the forester, tree warden or other qualified official of the municipality assigned to carry out the enforcement of this chapter under the supervision of the shade tree committee. 
B.  "Small trees" are designated as those attaining a height of twenty to thirty feet. 
C.  "Street" or "highway" means the entire width of every public way or right-of-way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
D.  "Tree lawn" is that part of a street or highway, not covered by a sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 636 § 2, 1980) 
12.16.020 - Permits required. 
A.  No person shall plant, prune, remove, cut aboveground or otherwise disturb any tree on any street or municipal-owned property without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the shade tree foreman or otherwise specified municipal authority designated by the shade tree committee. The person receiving the permit shall abide by the aboricultural specifications and standards of practice adopted by the shade tree committee. 
B.  If chemicals used to fertilize or spray for disease and/or insects on any street or municipal-owned property are chemicals that require the applicant to have a license when using, then a permit is required. 
C.  Application for permits should be made at the office of the shade tree foreman or other designated authority not less than forty-eight hours in advance of the time the work is to be done. 
D.  The shade tree foreman shall issue the permit provided for in this section if, in his judgment, the proposed work is desirable and the proposed method and workmanship thereof are of a satisfactory nature. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of expiration and the work shall be completed in the time allowed on the permit and in the manner described in the permit. Any permit shall be void if its terms are violated. 
E.  Notice of completion shall be given within five days to the shade tree foreman for his inspection. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(I), 1980) 
12.16.030 - Application specifications and removal of improper planting. 
A.  Permit Data. The application required in Section 12.16.020 shall state the number of trees to be set out; the location, grade specified, cultivar or variety of each tree; the method of planting; and such other information as the shade tree foreman shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
B.  Improper Planting. Whenever any tree is planted or set out in conflict with the provisions of this chapter, it shall be lawful for the shade tree foreman to remove or cause removal of it, and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to the owner as provided by law in the case of special assessments. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(II), 1980) 
12.16.040 - Improvement projects. 
    All municipal improvement projects that may impact boulevard trees shall be considered by the shade tree committee or its designated representative prior to the finalization of plans or the commencement of construction. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(A), 1980) 
12.16.050 - Application and permit for removal. 
    No person or property owner shall remove a tree from the treelawn for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason, without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the shade tree foreman, and without replacing the removed tree or trees in accordance with the adopted arboricultural specifications. The replacement shall meet the standards of size, species and placement as provided for in a permit issued by the shade tree foreman. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of removal and replacement of all trees removed if the tree does not constitute a nuisance. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(B), 1980) 
12.16.060 - Hazards to be pruned or removed. 
A.  All trees and shrubs within the municipality shall be pruned or removed when the trees or shrubs constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a threat to other trees or shrubs within the city. 
B.  The shade tree committee has the power and authority to prune or remove, or order to prune or remove, any such trees or shrubs on private property. The shade tree committee, or its designee, shall notify, in writing, the owners of such trees or shrubs. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000; Ord. 636 § 7(III)(C), 1980) 
12.16.070 - Notice of removal of public nuisance. 
    If it is determined that a tree is a public nuisance as provided in this chapter, or if the city determines that any dead or substantially dead elm trees, or dead elm wood, is a public nuisance as provided in this chapter, the shade tree foreman shall serve or cause to be served upon the owner of record of the lot or parcel of land on which the tree or dead elm wood is located, a written notice requiring the owner to comply with the provisions of this chapter. The notice shall require the property owner to correct the violation within thirty days from the receipt of the notice. The notice shall specify the legal description of the premises and, if possible, the street address of the premises. The notice shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner at his last known address, or by personal service. If any of the owners are absent from the city and their address is unknown, the notice may be given by publishing it in the official county newspaper for two successive weeks, the time for the notice beginning on the date of the first publication. The notice shall also advise the owner that if he should fail to abate the nuisance within thirty days after receipt of the notice, the nuisance shall be abated by the city and the cost of the abatement as provided in Section 12.16.090 shall be levied as a special assessment against the property. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(D), 1980) 
12.16.080 - Authority to abate nuisance. 
    Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner notified to correct a violation of this chapter within thirty days of receipt of notice as provided for in Section 12.16.070, or if the notice is returned to the city because of the inability of the United States postal service to make delivery; provided the notice was properly addressed and mailed to the last known address of the owner, the shade tree foreman and/or his delegate is authorized to abate a public nuisance as defined in this code. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(E), 1980) 
12.16.090 - Cost and record of nuisance abatement. 
    Where the city has used its equipment and personnel to abate a nuisance, the cost of the service shall be carefully itemized by the shade tree foreman or other designated official or employee and the bill shall be sent to the responsible property owner. If the bill is not paid when due, the amount thereof shall be assessed against the premises on which the work is done, or for which the service is rendered and collected and returned in the same manner as other municipal taxes are assessed, certified, collected and returned. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(F), 1980) 
12.16.100 - Maintenance and review of special assessments book. 
A.  The city auditor shall keep in his office a book called Nuisance Abatement, Special Assessment Book, and shall enter the cost of the abatement of a nuisance as declared by the city commission therein as a special assessment against the lot or parcel of land from which the nuisance was abated, with the name of the owner, if known to him. 
B.  At the regular meeting of the city commission in October of each year, the city commission shall review all such assessments and hear all complaints against them and approve them as finally adjusted, and the city auditor shall certify to the county auditor a list of the lots and parcels of land specially assessed for the purpose, and the sum shall be collected as other city taxes are collected. 
(Ord. 636 § 7(III)(G), 1980) 
12.16.120 - Duty to prune trees and action by city upon violation. 
A.  It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real property bordering on any street upon which property there may be trees, to prune the trees in such manner that they will not obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks, obstruct vision of traffic signs or obstruct view of any street or alley intersection. The minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be ten feet over sidewalks and twelve feet over all streets except truck routes, which shall have a clearance of sixteen feet. 
B.  Should any person or persons owning real property bordering on any street fail to prune trees as provided in subsection A of this section, the shade tree foreman shall order such person, or persons, within eight days after receipt of written notice, to so prune such trees. 
C.  The order required in subsection B of this section shall be served by mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the property owner, by certified mail, registered mail or hand delivered. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000; Ord. 636 § 8, 1980) 
12.16.130 - Responsibilities of public utilities. 
A.  Trees on public land trimmed by or under the direction of any public utility to afford clearance for wires or any other purpose should require a permit from the shade tree foreman, and such work shall be done in accordance with the regulations in the community forestry management plan. 
B.  All wires belonging to public utilities, city or individual, shall be securely fastened and maintained so as to safeguard the trees against any damage from them. An inspection should be made periodically to prevent damage to shade trees, or adjustments made whenever requested by the shade tree foreman. 
C.  Trenching operations shall be made in accordance with Section 12.16.150, and applicable criteria in the community forestry management plan. 
D.  Exemptions are made to subsections A, B and C of this section in the event of an emergency condition as determined by the public utilities companies. 
E.  Following an emergency condition in which any tree damage occurs, the public utilities are required to notify the shade tree foreman of the location of the emergency condition and the extent of the tree damage. 
F.  The public utility companies shall be required to submit to the shade tree foreman the names of tree care personnel used by the utility company to assure that they have been certified by the shade tree foreman. 
(Ord. 636 § 9, 1980) 
12.16.140 - Damaging public trees prohibited. 
    Unless specifically authorized by the shade tree foreman, no person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree; attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters or other contrivance to any tree, allowing any gaseous liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when the fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree. 
(Ord. 636 § 10, 1980) 
12.16.150 - Protection during construction. 
A.  All trees on any street or other publicly owned property near any excavation or construction of any building, structure or street work, shall be guarded with a good, substantial fence, frame or box not less than four feet high and eight feet square, or at a distance in feet from the tree equal to the diameter of the tree in inches D.B.H. (Diameter at breast height approximately four and one-half feet), whichever is greater, and all building material, dirt or other debris shall be kept outside the barrier. 
B.  No person shall excavate any ditches, tunnels, trenches or lay any drive within a radius of ten feet from any public tree without first obtaining a written permit from the shade tree foreman. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000; Ord. 636 § 12, 1980) 
12.16.160 - Storing construction materials under trees. 
    No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public place of the municipality, any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials, which may impede the free passage of water, air and nutrients to the roots of any tree growing therein, except by written permit of the shade tree foreman. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000: Ord. 636 § 13, 1980) 
12.16.170 - Interfering with enforcement prohibited. 
    No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the shade tree foreman or any of his assistants while engaged in carrying out the execution or enforcement of this chapter; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction, for the protection of property rights by the owner of any property within the municipality. 
(Ord. 636 § 11, 1980) 
12.16.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, which fine shall be equal to the amount of physical damage sustained. 
(Ord. 833 (part), 2000: Ord. 660 § 1, 1983: Ord. 636 § 14, 1980) 
Chapter 12.20 - PARKS 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - State laws accepted. 
    The provisions of the Act of the legislature of the state, being Sections 4055 to 4083 inclusive, Compiled Laws 1913, as amended, are accepted by the board of city commissioners, for and on behalf of the city, it being the intent and desire of the city, acting by and through the board of city commissioners, to accept all of the benefits and provisions of the act. 
(Prior code § 476) 
Chapter 12.24 - MAILBOXES 
Sections: 

12.24.010 - Definitions of terms used in this chapter. 
A.  "Mailbox" means a residential or commercial mail delivery receptacle, the design and construction of which is approved by the U.S. Postal Service for delivery of mail directly from the operator of a motor vehicle; said receptacle is typically fastened to a free standing post and adjacent to the shoulder of a road or the curbs. 
B.  "Newspaper box" means a residential or commercial receptacle for newspapers typically fastened to a post adjacent to the shoulder of a roadway or behind the curb enabling the placement of newspapers therein directly from a motor vehicle. 
C.  "Right-of-way" means a strip of land designed or dedicated for streets, boulevards, alley, sidewalks, railroad, electric transmission line, telephone and telegraph lines, oil or gas pipeline, sanitary and storm sewer, or water systems. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.020 - Prohibition of mailboxes or right-of-way. 
    Mailboxes are not permitted within the right-of-way on any four lane road, any two lane road with center left turn lanes, and any roads with diagonal parking unless the city engineer determines there are adequate parking and stopping areas outside the lanes of traffic on those roads. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.030 - Mailboxes in areas with greater than twenty-five mile per hour speed limits. 
    All mailboxes along routes with posted speed limit greater than twenty-five miles per hour must be installed with breakaway posts according to the standards established by the North Dakota Department of Transportation. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.040 - Multiple area service. 
    Multiple mailboxes for area service are recommended, wherever possible. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.050 - Damage to mailboxes. 
    The city is not liable for any damage which may result to any mailbox during the city's normal maintenance operation (i.e. snow removal, street sweeping, etc.). The owner of the mailbox shall be responsible for any such damage to their mailbox. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.060 - Removal, resetting or relocation of mailboxes. 
A.  The removal, resetting or relocation of any mailbox shall be the responsibility of the owner of the mailbox. This includes the removal, resetting or relocation of any mailbox because of street or city utility construction or maintenance operations, or if the location of the mailbox is a safety hazard as determined by the city engineer. 
B.  If the removal, resetting or relocation of any mailbox is necessary, the city will provide the owner of the property upon which the mailbox is located written notice. This notice will inform the property owner of the grounds for the request and that the property owner has ten days from the date of the notice to remove, reset or relocate the mailbox. 
C.  If the property owner has not removed, reset or relocated the mailbox within those ten days, the city shall do it and the cost to the city shall be assessed to the property where the mailbox is located. 
D.  The property owner may appeal the determination of the city engineer set out in paragraph A above. To do so, the property owner must file with the city auditor a notice of appeal no later than seven days from the date of the notice to remove, reset or relocate the mailbox. The city auditor shall set the hearing before the city commission no later than thirty days from receiving the notice of appeal. The city auditor shall send to the property owner the date, time and location of the hearing no later than seven days prior to the date of the hearing. Should there be an emergency, as determined by the city commission, the dates set forth herein may be reduced by action of the city commission. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.070 - Mailbox supports. 
    The use of the mailbox supports that, when struck, could damage vehicles and cause serious injury to vehicle occupants, are prohibited. Heavy metal posts, railroad ties, concrete posts, brick base, and items such as farm equipment or supports filled with concrete are also prohibited. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.080 - Newspaper box. 
    All newspaper boxes within the city, installed or replaced subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall be as close as practical to the residential and commercial mailboxes specified and utilized by the United States Postal Service. It is the intention of this chapter that these newspaper boxes shall be attached to the pole and/or other edifice used for the delivery of mail by the United States Postal Service. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.090 - Penalty provision. 
    Any violation of this chapter shall result in a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars. Further, the city may request, and the court shall order, the removal of any delivery mailbox and/or newspaper box which violates any provision of this chapter and the cost of the removal shall be assessed as a cost to the defendant in addition to the fine. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
12.24.100 - Existing mailboxes. 
    This chapter does not effect any mailboxes which exist on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, which mailboxes may be in violation of the provisions of this chapter. If any of these existing mailboxes are removed, replaced, reset, relocated, or repaired, those mailboxes must then be in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. 846(part), 2001) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.08 - WATER AND SEWER UTILITY 
Sections: 

13.08.010 - Water facilities. 
    The water facilities now and hereafter owned by the city shall henceforth constitute a public utility of the city, to be held, operated and administered by it as an undertaking to be known as the water utility. The properties shall include the pumping plant, water treatment plant, other buildings and machinery in all such buildings, the water mains, hydrants and connections as now or hereafter constructed or erected, the water line, wells and appurtenances and all other systems, plants, works, instrumentalities, equipment, material and supplies and all lands, easements, rights in land, water rights, contract rights, franchise, reservoirs, mains, conduits, pumping stations and all parts and appurtenances of any of the foregoing which are or shall be used or useful in connection with the obtaining of a water supply and the conservation, treatment and distribution of water for public and private uses. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.020 - Sewerage facilities. 
    The sewerage facilities now and hereafter owned by the city shall henceforth constitute a public utility of the city, to be held, operated and administered by it as a separate undertaking to be known as the sewer utility. The properties shall include all systems, plants, works, instrumentalities, equipment, material and supplies and all lands, easements, rights in land, contract rights, franchises, mains, conduits, pumping stations, lagoons and all parts and appurtenances of any of the foregoing which are or shall be used or useful in connection with the collection, treatment and disposal of sewage waste and stormwater. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.030 - Authority of city commissioners. 
    Each of the utilities shall at all times be under the management and control of the board of city commissioners and shall be operated and maintained in such manner as to provide its services and facilities with maximum efficiency and at the minimum cost therefor which is compatible with the plan of operation described in this chapter. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.040 - Charges to maintain self-sufficiency. 
    Each of the utilities shall at all times be operated, maintained, used, extended and improved, and the rates and charges for the services, facilities and benefits produced and furnished thereby shall be fixed in such manner as to make the utility self-supporting and self-perpetuating. The charges from time to time imposed and collected for the service, facilities and benefits of each utility shall be made and kept adequate to pay all costs of operation and maintenance thereof, and to repay principal and interest on all money borrowed to establish and maintain reasonable reserves for the aforesaid purposes, and also to produce reasonable surplus money in amounts substantially comparable to a fair return upon the city's capital investment in each of the utilities, which surplus money, when actually on hand, may be appropriated from time to time by the board of city commissioners to pay or contribute to the cost of any other city functions, subject to the limitations prescribed by law. The foregoing appropriations and provisions shall not, however, be deemed or construed to preclude the city from using at any time any special assessment method or methods nor or hereafter permitted by for defraying all or any part of the expense of any improvement to, or enlargement or extension of, either of the utilities, whenever and to the extent the board is of the opinion that it is fair and equitable to do so. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.050 - Funds established. 
    There shall be maintained by the city, a water fund and a sewer fund, of which all receipts and disbursements for each of the utilities shall be entered and reflected. The funds shall be permanent ones and shall be separate and distinct from all other city funds, but the moneys from time to time on hand, which are to be credited to and disbursed from each of the funds, shall always constitute public municipal funds and shall be deposited and their safekeeping secured in the same manner as other city funds. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.060 - Director to supervise connections and repairs. 
    The director of utilities or his appointed representative shall supervise the making of all connections and repairs with the waterworks system, shall follow the instructions of the city auditor in turning on or turning off the water for any consumer, and shall see that all of the provisions of the waterworks ordinance are strictly complied with. In addition to these duties the director of utilities or the city engineer shall keep an accurate account, showing when and where all locations in the streets and alleys of all valves, cutoffs, connections and other matters connected with the city waterworks system. He shall make and file with the city auditor a full report in writing at the close of each month of all the work of his office. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.070 - Duties of director. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of utilities to perform the following acts as set forth in this section or as may be set forth in other city ordinances: 
A.  To issue permits to tap mains or make connections with the service pipes or extensions, or to make extensions, and to keep a record of all permits issued and a copy to the city engineer; 
B.  To keep a record of any and all applications issued for water service and discontinue them upon notice of failure to pay for such water thereunder as provided in this chapter; 
C.  To notify the city auditor of the filing of all applications for water service, permits issued for tapping mains, making connections or extensions, and when application has been duly made and all requirements of this chapter complied with, order the water turned on pursuant to the application. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.080 - Applications for tapping of mains. 
    Applications for the excavations and tapping of water or sewer mains must be made in writing by a master plumber or licensed water or sewer contractor. Such application shall be made to the director of utilities before any such work is commenced. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.090 - Applications for house sewer connections. 
    No person other than a master plumber or licensed water or sewer contractor shall be permitted to excavate for or construct a house sewer and application for such permits shall be made to the director of utilities on or before any such work is commenced. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.100 - Standards for connecting to city mains. 
    All work in connection with the excavation or construction for a sewer or water connection to the city mains shall be done in accordance with the ordinances of the city and the state plumbing code. Wye connections must be used except with special approval of the city utility director. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.110 - Inspections-Liability. 
    Inspections made by the engineering department shall not in any manner be construed to relieve the master plumber or licensed water and sewer contractor doing such work from any liability or responsibility as is imposed upon him under the ordinances of the city or by law. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.120 - Assessment payment required for connections. 
    No permit shall be granted to any person to lay, relay, repair or extend any branch water service pipes or sewer pipes or connect them with the waterworks or sewer system of the city for water service for any property which is not within the improvement district or has not been assessed for the waterworks or sewer system, except where systems have been paid for without special assessments against the property benefited. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.130 - Standards for pipe connections. 
    No connection shall be made unless the service pipe between the water main and the curbline and/or the water meter is constructed of copper or approved plastic, and no such service pipes shall be less than the size specified in the state plumbing code, and it is unlawful for any person to connect more than one house or building to each corporation cock of the water main distribution system of the city. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.140 - Curb cock regulations. 
    The curb cock used in making all connections with the city mains shall be the Mueller Inverted Key, Minneapolis, Minnesota, pattern, round way curb cock for a copper or approved plastic service pipe or such other make of curb cock as shall be approved by the city engineer for copper or approved plastic couplings with Minneapolis type stop box to be approved by the utility director. The top of cap of the stop box shall be in all cases on a level with the top of the curb, and if there is no curb it shall be placed on the sidewalk, not more than six inches from the roadway side of the walk. When there is a curb, the stop box shall be placed outside the curb and as near to it as possible. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.150 - Responsibility for expense. 
    Persons desirous of taking water from or connecting in any manner with the waterworks system must pay all the expenses and the cost of the corporation cock, stop cock and the iron shutoff box attached to it. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.160 - Responsibility for maintenance. 
    All service pipes, stop cocks, corporation cocks and other fixtures from the main to the curb stop and including the shutoff box must be laid and attached and kept in repair and kept from frost at the expense of the city, and will remain under the control of the city, the property owner waiving and releasing all claims thereto of control. All service pipes and connecting pipes located or on the property owner side of the curb stop shall be maintained by the property owner. 
(Ord. 855 (part), 2003: Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.170 - Water meters-Required. 
A.  Every separate piece of property now connected or hereinafter connected with the city water main and shall be provided with a water meter by the city for the measurement of water consumed at such place. 
B.  Immediately after any service pipe connected with the city waterworks system has been placed within the property line and made ready for using water from it, there shall be installed on the service pipe a water meter and remote reading system provided, or specifically approved, by the city. 
C.  All meters must have a remote reading capability at or above ground level with easy accessibility for reading as determined by the city. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.180 - Depth of service pipe. 
    All service pipe for water mains must be laid at least seven feet, six inches below the street grade from the water main to the inside of the building. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.190 - Taps or lawn cocks-Unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to have any tap, lawn cock, sill cock or other opening in the service pipe between the corporation cock and the water meter so placed. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.200 - Waterworks use regulations. 
    The rules and regulations of the city waterworks are established as follows: 
A.  Every person taking or using water from the city waterworks shall comply with and abide by the following regulations: 
B.  In the case of making repairs or construction of new work, the city reserves the right to shut off the water at once, and keep it shut off as long as may be necessary to accomplish such purpose. The director of utilities shall, in case of users of steam boilers who are consumers of the city water, give such reasonable notice of the shutting off as may be practicable. 
C.  It is expressly provided that the city shall in no event be or become liable to any consumer of water for a deficiency in the supply of water or the quality thereof, whether by shutting off the water to make repairs or to construct new work or for any other cause whatsoever. 
D.  No person shall turn or cause to be turned on the supply of water to any premises to which the supply of the water has been shut off for any cause by the city, without first making the application for and obtaining the permit described in this chapter. 
E.  No person shall turn or cause to be turned on the supply of water into any new supply pipe without first making application and obtaining the permit described in this chapter. 
F.  Whenever the director of utilities has caused the water to be turned off from any service pipe he may, whenever he suspects any probability of tampering with the pipes, cause them to be severed from the main. 
G.  No person except the city employees in performance of their official duties shall open or cause to be opened 
H.  No person shall open, interfere or tamper with any hydrant connected with the city waterworks system without permission from the director of utilities. This section shall not apply when the opening is under the supervision of the fire department or employees thereof. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.210 - Authority to shut off due to abandonment. 
    The city utility director has the right to shut off any water service lines at the main where the service lines are abandoned by the owners thereof, either by reason of the substitution of a new or different service line or the abandonment or disuse of the water service line. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.08.220 - Stubbing on new residential areas required. 
    All new residential areas shall be stubbed in for water and sewer to the property line, before hard surfacing is started. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 13.12 - SEWER REGULATIONS 
Sections: 
ARTICLE I. - DEFINITIONS 

13.12.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
A.  "Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
B.  "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
C.  "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
D.  "Combined sewer" means a sewer intended to receive both wastewater and stormwater or surface water. 
E.  "Easement" means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
F.  "Fee" shall mean a charge fixed by resolution by the city Commission from time to time and revised as it may see fit. 
G.  "Floatable oil" is oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
H.  "Garbage" means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
I.  "Industrial wastes" means the wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
J.  "Natural outlet" means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
K.  "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
L.  "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of 7 and a hydrogen-ion concentration of 10-7. 
M.  "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
N.  "Public sewer" means a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
O.  "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
P.  "Sewage" is the spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater," Section 13.12.250. 
Q.  "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
R.  "Slug" means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen minutes more than five times the average longer twenty-four-hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
S.  "Storm drain" (sometimes termed "storm sewer") means a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted water from any source. 
T.  "Superintendent" means the director of public works or his designee. 
U.  "Suspended solids" means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
V.  "Unpolluted water" is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
W.  "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
X.  "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
Y.  "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant or water pollution control plant. 
Z.  "Watercourse" means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE II. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED 

13.12.020 - Deposit of Waste-Unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.030 - Control of discharqes to natural outlets. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.040 - Private disposal system restricted. 
    Except as provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.050 - Toilet facilities and sewer connection required. 
    The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect the facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within sixty days after date of official notice to do so; provided, that the public sewer is within two hundred feet of the property line. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 

13.12.060 - Private systems permitted when. 
    Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.070 - Permit required. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the superintendent, and pay the fee required. The application for the permit shall contain any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.080 - Installation to be inspected. 
    A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. The superintendent shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within twenty-four hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.090 - Regulation compliance required. 
    The type, capacities, location and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the Department of Public Health of the state. No permit shall be issued for any private wastewater disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than twenty thousand square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.100 - Connection with public sewer. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within sixty days, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.110 - Maintenance in sanitary manner. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. Sludge removal from private disposal systems shall be performed by licensed operators. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.120 - Additional requirements may be imposed. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by proper health officials. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE IV. - SANITARY SEWERS, BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

13.12.130 - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.140 - Permit-Application and fee. 
A.  The two classes of building sewer permits are, residential and commercial service, and for establishments producing industrial wastes. 
B.  In either case, the owner shall make application and the application shall contain any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. A fee shall be paid when the application is filed. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.150 - Building sewer cost responsibility. 
    All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.160 - Separate connection and exception. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection mentioned in this section. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.170 - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.180 - Conformance required. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of all sanitary sewers, including building sewers, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of suitable code provisions or in amplification thereof, the superintendent shall decide. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.190 - Elevation of building sewer. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings to which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by the building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.200 - Surface runoff or groundwater connection. 
    No person shall make connection or roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless the connection is approved by the superintendent for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.210 - Building sewer connection standards. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M.. All such connections shall be made gas-tight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent before installation. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.220 - Notice to inspect. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.230 - Hazard protection and public property restoration. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE V. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 

13.12.240 - Unpolluted waters. 
A.  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sewer, except stormwater runoff from limited areas, which stormwater may be polluted at times, may be discharged to the sanitary sewer by permission of the superintendent. 
B.  Stormwater other than that exempted and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent and other regulatory agencies. Unpolluted industrial cooling water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.250 - Wastes prohibited from discharge. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described water or wastes to any public sewers: 
A.  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
B.  Any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to contaminate the sludge of any municipal system, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in or have an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge for the treatment works; 
C.  Any waters or wastes having pH lower than 5.5, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the wastewater works; 
D.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, ground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.260 - Limits of concentrations or quantities. 
    The following described substances, materials, waters or waste shall be limited in discharges to municipal systems to concentrations or quantities which will not harm nor wither the sewers, wastewater treatment process of equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream or will not otherwise endanger lives, limb, public property or constitute a nuisance. The superintendent may set limitations lower than the limitations established in the regulations set out in this section if in his opinion such more severe limitations are necessary to meet the above objectives. In forming his opinion as to acceptability, the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, the wastewater treatment process employed, capacity of the wastewater plant, degree of treatability of the waste in the wastewater treatment plant and other pertinent factors. The limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of waste or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which shall not be violated without approval of the superintendent as follows: 
A.  Wastewater having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five degrees celsius); 
B.  Wastewater containing more than twenty-five milligrams per liter of petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils or product of mineral oil origin; 
C.  Wastewater from industrial plants containing floatable oils, fats or grease; 
D.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers; 
E.  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic substances to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the superintendent for such materials; 
F.  Any waters or wastes containing odor-producing substances exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent; 
G.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
H.  Quantities of flow, concentrations or both which constitute a slug; 
I.  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment process employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters; 
J.  Any water or wastes which, by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer system, release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system, or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.270 - Treatment of hazardous discharges. 
A.  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated herein, and which in the judgement of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise creates a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
1.  Reject the wastes; 
2.  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
3.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
4.  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing sewer charges. 
B.  When considering the alternatives listed heretofore, the superintendent shall give consideration to the economic impact of each alternative on the discharger. If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.280 - Interceptors required when. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captivated material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the superintendent. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the owner must be performed by currently licensed wasted disposal firms. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.290 - Pretreatment or flow equalization facilities. 
    Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.300 - Industrial waste measurement facilities. 
    When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such structures, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The structure shall be installed by the owner, and shall be maintained so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.310 - Compliance information required when. 
    The superintendent may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this chapter. These requirements may include: 
A.  Wastewaters discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period; 
B.  Chemical analysis of wastewaters; 
C.  Information on raw materials, processes and products affecting wastewater volume and quality; 
D.  Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to sewer use control; 
E.  A plot plan of sewers of the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location; 
F.  Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities; 
G.  Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal sewer. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.320 - Waste measurement standards. 
    All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods of the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling methods, location, times, durations and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.330 - Industrial waste treatment agreement authorized. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE VI. - POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS 

13.12.340 - Right of entry for inspection. 
    The engineer and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.350 - Authority to obtain information. 
    The engineer or other duly authorized employees are authorized to obtain information concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the wastewater collection system. The industry must establish that the revelation to the public of the information in question might result in an advantage to competitors. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.360 - Observation of safety rules required. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties, the employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees, and the city shall indemnify the company against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.370 - Authority to enter property lying within easement. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within the easement. All done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
ARTICLE VII. - VIOLATION-PENALTIES 

13.12.380 - Damaging or defacing wastewater facilities. 
    No persons shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the wastewater facilities. Any person in violation of this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.390 - Notice of violation. 
    Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter shall be served with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in the notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.400 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who continues any violation after the time limit provided for in Section 13.12.390 of Article VII of the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined in the amount not exceeding five hundred dollars for each violation. Each day in which any such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
13.12.410 - Liability for city losses. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. 767 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 13.14 - SEWER CONNECTIONS IN MOBILE HOME COURTS AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 
Sections: 

13.14.000 - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to ensure sanitary sewer service connections within mobile home courts and recreational vehicle parks are properly sealed to prevent rainfall runoff and snow melt from entering the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. 865 (part), 2005) 
13.14.010 - Sewer connections in mobile home courts and recreational vehicle parks. 
    The following shall apply to all sewer connections in mobile home courts and recreational vehicle parks in the city of Devils Lake: 
A.  All connections from sewer service to mobile homes, manufactured homes, or recreational vehicles must be water tight. 
B.  All sewer services not in use must be capped with a water tight connection. 
C.  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the mobile home court or recreational vehicle park to ensure that sewer connections and services are water tight. 
D.  If the owner fails to ensure sewer services are properly sealed, the owner will be subject to a fine as stated in the resolution of fees and rates, and will also be responsible for any and all damages which may result. 
(Ord. 865 (part), 2005: Ord. 858 (part), 2003) 
13.14.020 - Notification to city. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the mobile home court to notify the city of Devils Lake engineering department when a mobile home or manufactured home does move in or out of the owner's mobile home court. This notification shall be provided to the city not later than seven calendar days from when a mobile home or manufactured home moves in or moves out of the mobile home court. If the owner fails to notify the city within the required time, the owner will be subject to a fine as stated in the resolution of fees and rates, and will also be responsible for any and all damages which may result from the owner's failure to timely notify the city when a mobile home or manufactured home moves in or out of the owner's mobile home court. 
(Ord. 865 (part), 2005: Ord. 858 (part), 2003) 
13.14.030 - Inspections. 
    The city of Devils Lake does reserve the right to inspect any and all sewer connections. The city of Devils Lake, or its agents or representatives, have the right to enter all mobile home courts and recreational vehicle parks within the city of Devils Lake to conduct their inspection of the sewer connections. 
(Ord. 865 (part), 2005: Ord. 858 (part), 2003)
