16.04.080 - Comprehensive plan-Objectives. 
    These regulations are administered and enforced to implement the comprehensive plan of the city, a document adopted by the board of city commissioners as a guide for the physical development of the city including the following objectives: 
A.  To conserve and enhance the taxable value of land and buildings in the city and environ; 
B.  To encourage the most appropriate use of land in the city and environ; 
C.  To preserve and increase the amenities of the city and environ; 
D.  To protect residential, commercial and manufacturing areas alike from harmful encroachment by incompatible uses; 
E.  To protect the character and maintain the stability of residential, commercial and industrial areas and to promote orderly development; 
F.  To regulate and restrict the location and intensity of use of buildings and land for residential, commercial, industrial and other uses; 
G.  To separate and control unavoidable nuisance-producing uses to minimize the adverse impacts on the surrounding areas or uses; 
H.  To minimize the expenditure of public funds through selecting cost-effective alternatives for expansion of the city services; 
I.  To minimize business interruption; 
J.  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water mains, sewer mains and streets. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.04.090 - Effective date. 
    These regulations shall be effective upon adoption by the board of city commissioners as provided by the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.08 - RULES AND DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

16.08.010 - Rules of construction. 
    In construction of these regulations, the rules and definitions contained in this section shall be observed and applied except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
A.  Words used in present tense shall include the future. 
B.  Words used in singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural number the singular. 
C.  Shall is a mandatory word and not discretionary. 
D.  May is a permissive word. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.08.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this title: 
    "Alley" means a public right-of-way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Applicant" means the owner of land to be subdivided or his/her representative. 
    "Block" means a group of lots, tracts or parcels of land bounded by streets, parks, railroad rights-of-way, shoreline of water ways, lakes or the city corporate limits. 
    "Building" means any structure designed or intended for shelter, housing, business, office and accommodation of persons, animals, chattel or property. 
    "Building area" means that portion of the lot that can be occupied by the principal building, excluding the front, rear and side yards. 
    "Building line" means a line establishing the minimum distance that structures may be placed from lot lines or street rights-of-way. 
    "Capital improvement program" means a proposed schedule of future infrastructure including water, sewer, street, curb, gutter and sidewalk together with cost estimates and the anticipated means of financing each part. 
    "Channel" means a natural or manmade water course conducting the flowing water. 
    "City planning commission" means a body of citizens appointed by the board of city commissioners under the authority of Chapter 40-47 of the North Dakota Century Code to review the planning issues, prepare plans, review the zoning requests, amendments and conditional uses and make recommendations to the city commission for final decisions. The city planning commission shall have the authority to review and approve all preliminary and final plats and replats within the city and in the extraterritorial planning area. 
    "Comprehensive plan" means a guide for physical development of the city as provided by Section 16.04.080. 
    "Cul-de-sac" means a local street with one open end to traffic and the other end terminated by a vehicular turnaround. The length of a cul-de-sac shall not exceed five hundred feet. 
    "Dedication" means deliberate appropriation of land by the owner to any public use. 
    "Developer" means the owner of land to be subdivided or his/her representatives. 
    "Development" means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but not limited to the construction of buildings, structures or accessory structures, the construction of additions or alternations to buildings or structures, ditching, lagooning, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation and drilling operations. 
    "Development plan" means a document, including maps and data, for physical development of an area as provided by Section 16.16.050. 
    "Dwelling" means any building or portion thereof, used exclusively for human habitation including single-family and multiple-family units but not including hotels or motels. 
    Dwelling, Detached. "Detached dwelling" means a single-family residential unit surrounded by open space on the same lot. 
    Dwelling, Multiple-Family. "Multiple-family dwelling" means a single building or portion thereof, containing two or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling, Single-Family. "Single-family dwelling" means a building containing one dwelling unit only. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms designed for occupancy for one or more persons living as a house keeping unit. 
    "Easement" means a right to use land for a specific purpose, such right being held by someone other than the owner who holds the title to the land. 
    "Encroachment" means any fill, building, structure or use including accessory uses projecting into the required yard areas or public and private property. 
    "Establishment" means a place of business for processing, production, assembly, sales, service of goods and materials. 
    "Family" means two or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption occupying a dwelling unit. A family may include not more than two unrelated persons by blood, marriage or adoption. 
    "Final plat" means the map, plan or record of a subdivision and any accompanying material prepared in conformance with these regulations. 
    "Floodplain" means an area which may be covered by flood water including but not limited to regional floods. 
    "Floor area" means the total square footage of floor space within the exterior walls of a building excluding garages and carports. 
    "Frontage" means the front part of a lot abutting a public street. 
    "Frontage street" means any street in which the development shall take place for access to abutting lots. 
    "Grade" means the slope of a road, street or lot defined in percentage. 
    "Improvements" means street grading, surfacing, installation of sidewalks, curb, gutter, water, sanitary and storm sewer systems, culverts, bridges, trees or other such installations as may be required by the city planning commission. 
    "Lot area" means the area within the lot lines. 
    "Lot" means a piece, parcel, lot or area of land of continuous assemblage established by survey, plat or deed. 
    Lot, Corner. "Corner lot" means a lot abutting two public streets at their intersection. 
    Lot, Depth. "Depth lot" means the average horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line. 
    Lot, Double Frontage. "Double frontage lot" means a lot having frontage on two separately designated streets. 
    Lot, Interior. "Interior lot" means a lot located in the interiors of a block and not a corner lot. 
    "Lot lines" means the property lines bounding the lot. 
    "Lot of record" means a lot which is a part of a subdivision which has been recorded in the office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds, or a parcel of land, the deed to which has been recorded in the office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds. 
    "Lot width" means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines of a lot, measured at the front building setback line. 
    "Major plat" means a plat of a subdivision containing four or more lots. 
    "Minor plat" means a plat of subdivision containing less than four lots. 
    "Nonresidential plat" means a plat whose intended use is other than residential such as commercial or industrial. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership or legal entity. 
    "Planned development" means a grouping of buildings and structures on a site of five or more acres in single ownership which is not limited by the yard or building height limitations but is based on a detailed development plan and recorded in the office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds upon approval by the board of city commissioners. 
    "Preliminary plat" means the preliminary plan of a subdivision and any accompanying material prepared in accordance with the requirements of these regulations. 
    "Premises" means a lot together with all buildings and structures on it. 
    "Public roadway or public way" means any recorded right-of-way including alleys, sidewalks, streets, roads, highways, viaducts, tunnels, bridges and public easements. 
    "Regional flood" means a flood determined by the city, state and federal authorities which is representative of large floods known to have occurred in Ramsey County, North Dakota. 
    "Replat" means a change in an approved or recorded plat requiring changes in street layout, lot lines or blocks. 
    "Right-of-way" means a strip of land designated or dedicated for streets, sidewalks, railroad, electric transmission line, telephone and telegraph lines, oil or gas pipeline, sanitary and storm sewer, or water systems. 
    "Sign" means any emblem, name, identification, description or illustration which is used for outdoor advertising having permanent location on the ground or attached to or painted on a building including bulletin boards, billboards and poster boards, flags, but excluding real estate for-sale signs, political campaign signs, public information and traffic signs. 
    "Story" means that portion of a building between the surface of any floor and the surface of the next floor above it, or if there is no floor above it, then space between the floor and the ceiling above it. A basement shall be counted as a story, if more than one-half of it is above grade. 
    "Street" means any public way which affords traffic circulations and a principal means of access to abutting property. Streets include alleys, highways, roads, viaducts, tunnels, bridges. 
    Street, Arterial. "Arterial street" means public way which provide for movement of large volumes of traffic as designated by the city. 
    Street, Collector. "Collector street" means a public way intended to carry traffic to and from minor streets and to and from the major streets as designated by the city. 
    "Street line" means the outer boundary of any public right-of-way. 
    Street, Local. "Local street" means a public way intended for low volume of traffic which provides access to collector and arterial streets. 
    Street, Major. "Major street" means a public way, arterial or collector streets, used primarily for carrying a large volume of traffic. 
    Street, Minor. "Minor street" means a public way intended to provide pedestrian and vehicular access to the abutting properties. 
    "Structure" means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent location on the ground including advertising signs and billboards. 
    "Subdivider" means any person, group, corporation, entity or agency dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision. 
    "Subdivision" means the division of a tract or parcel of land into lots for the purpose whether immediate or future, of sale or of building development, and any plat or plan which includes the creation of any part of one or more streets, public easement, or other rights-of-way, whether public or private, for access to or from such lots and the creation of new or enlarged parks, playgrounds, plazas or open spaces. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.12 - SPECIAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

16.12.010 - Land suitability. 
    No land shall be divided or subdivided for a use which is held unsuitable by the city for reasons of flooding, potential, soil limitations, drainage or any other condition likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future residents or poses difficulty for the city. A developer or subdivider may as a part or preapplication procedures, request a determination of land suitability, provided that he shall submit all necessary data and information to the city for such a determination. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.12.020 - Dedication of land for streets. 
    Whenever a parcel of land to be subdivided as a subdivision contains a street or public way, such street or public way shall be dedicated to the city at the location and details shown on the final plat. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.16 - APPLICATION PROCEDURE AND REVIEW PROCESS 
Sections: 

16.16.010 - Preapplication procedure. 
    Prior to preparing a preliminary plat, the subdivider may consult with the code administrator and the city engineer concerning the regulations governing the division or subdivision of land in the city, access to the city utilities, services and conformance with the comprehensive plan. Specifically the areas for consultation shall include: 
A.  Feasibility of development related to the land suitability, elements of the comprehensive plan, efficient use of utilities and public services. 
B.  Review of the subdivision regulations for required improvements, developers agreement and the bonding needs. 
C.  Responsibility of the city for extension of services, acceptance of dedication for street rights-of-way, drainage courses and open spaces. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.020 - Preliminary plat-Application. 
    The preliminary plat shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor and shall be submitted to the city engineer for review and approval by the city planning commission. The preliminary plat shall cover the entire contiguous area owned or controlled by the subdivider if it is under forty acres even though only a small portion of it is proposed for the development at the time. The subdivider may be required to submit a development plan if he owns or controls more than forty contiguous acres of land. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.030 - Preliminary plat-Content. 
    The preliminary plat shall include the following requirements, data and information: 
A.  The preliminary plat drawn at a scale of not smaller than one inch equals one hundred feet; 
B.  Name and location of the subdivision; 
C.  Date, graphic scale and north point; 
D.  Boundary line of the proposed subdivision indicated by a solid heavy line, accurately drawn to scale and showing distances and bearings; 
E.  Total acreage within the subdivision; 
F.  Location, right-of-way width and names of any existing or proposed streets including type and width of surfacing or public ways, easement, railroad, utility rights-of-way, parks and other public open spaces, permanent buildings or structures, corporate boundaries and section lines within or adjacent to the subdivision; 
G.  Location of existing property lines, buildings, drives, streams, water courses, wooded areas and drainage ways; 
H.  Existing water mains, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, culverts, bridges and other utility structures within the tracts, indicating pipe size, grades and location as obtained from public records; 
I.  Existing zoning of the proposed subdivision and the zoning of the adjacent tracts of land; 
J.  Boundary line of adjacent tracts of land or lots showing owners' name(s); 
K.  Contour at vertical intervals of not more than two feet; 
L.  Location and dimension of any site to be reserved or dedicated for public uses including drainage ways, parks and open spaces; 
M.  Layout of the proposed streets, alleys, crosswalks and easements, showing widths and street names; 
N.  Layout, number and dimensions of all lots and blocks; 
O.  Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or reserved for public use or set aside for the use of property owners within the subdivision; 
P.  Building setback lines, showing dimensions; 
Q.  A key map at a scale of one inch equals four hundred feet or less, showing the boundary of the proposed subdivision and covering an area within one half mile around the subdivision. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.040 - Preliminary plat-Submission requirements. 
A.  The subdivider shall apply on appropriate forms provided by the city engineer to the city planning commission at least fifteen days prior to its regularly-scheduled meeting. 
B.  The subdivider shall submit six prints of the preliminary plat to the city engineer at the time the application is made. The plat shall comply with the provisions of these regulations. The city engineer may refuse to accept the preliminary plat, if he finds the plat in conflict with one or more provisions of these regulations. Fees charged for the filing of the subdivision plat shall be paid in full at the time of application in accordance with Section 16.36.010 of these regulations. 
C.  The subdivider may submit any instrument whereby he/she proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision for protecting the proposed development. 
D.  The subdivider shall provide other data related to drainage, soil suitability, financing of improvement and other related information which the city engineer or the code administrator request. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.050 - Development plan. 
    Where a development plan is required for a tract of land, the following shall be included in the plan. 
A.  Location of existing property lines, buildings, drives, streams, wooded areas and other significant natural features. 
B.  General layout of proposed streets and location of blocks for designated uses. 
C.  Location of open spaces and facilities for public uses. 
D.  Existing drainage pattern based on the available topographic information from the U.S. Geological Survey Maps and other similar information. 
E.  The development plan shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equaling four hundred feet. 
F.  The city planning commission may require other information as a part of the development plan. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.060 - Preliminary plat-Review process. 
A.  The city engineer shall retain one copy of the preliminary plat and submit copies with a request for comment within five days to the county health officer, school district, the utility companies. He/she shall appoint a time for staff review to determine if all requirements of these regulations are met and the preliminary plat is consistent with the comprehensive plan as well as policies of public agencies and the private utility companies. For lands within the extraterritorial planning area, a representative of Creel Township be invited to the staff review meeting. The public agency may include any of the city agencies as well as the concerned county or state agencies. 
B.  If the city engineer finds the preliminary plat in substantial conformity with these regulations and the comprehensive plan he/she shall submit the preliminary plat together with the review comments of public agencies and private agencies to the city planning commission. 
C.  The city planning commission shall review the preliminary plat and the comments of the public and private agencies upon which it may approve, approve conditionally or deny the application and the preliminary plat. The city planning commission may require additional information before it takes action. The city planning commission shall cite the reasons for denying the application. 
D.  The conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall clearly state the nature and extent of the conditions which shall be met before a final plat is submitted for review and approval. Tentative approval of a preliminary plat by the city planning commission is not an acceptance of a subdivision plat, but is an expression of approval of a general plat as a guide to preparation of a subdivision for final plat review and approval. 
E.  The city planning commission may require the subdivider to submit a revised preliminary plat before the subdivider proceeds with the preparation of the final plat. 
F.  Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of twelve months within which a final plat shall be prepared. If the final plat is not submitted within this time period, the city planning commission may require the subdivider to resubmit the preliminary plat for review and approval. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.070 - Final plat-Generally. 
    The final plat shall cover the area which is realistically designated for transfer or sale of lots. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.080 - Final plat-Content. 
    The final plat shall conform to all provisions of these regulations and conditions set forth by the city planning commission: 
A.  Name of subdivision and date of tentative approval by the city planning commission; 
B.  Location by section, township and range, or other legal description; 
C.  Names of owners and surveyor or other professional person preparing the plat; 
D.  Scale which shall be one inch equals one hundred feet or less; 
E.  Date, graphic scale and north point; 
F.  Boundary line of subdivision based on an accurate traverse, showing distances and bearings; 
G.  Exact location, width and name of all streets within and adjoining the subdivision, and the exact location of all alleys and crosswalks; 
H.  True bearing and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments which shall be accurately described on the plat; 
I.  City, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the boundary lines of the subdivision by bearing and distance; 
J.  Radii, internal angles, points of curvature, tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs; 
K.  All easements for right-of-way provided for public services and public utilities; 
L.  All lot number and lot lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths; 
M.  Accurate location of all monuments, which shall be of material and size in accordance with the standards of the city and the state; 
N.  Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas (not including streets, alleys or public utility easements) to be dedicated or reserved for public use; with the purposes indicated thereon; and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for common use of all property owners; 
O.  Building setback lines, accurately shown with dimensions; 
P.  Where required, detailed engineering drawings, cross-sections or profiles of street, utility lines, catch basins or other installations of improvements as installed; 
Q.  Certification by registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him, and that the monuments shown thereon exist as located and that all dimensional and geodetic details are correct; 
R.  Notarized certification by the owners of the land of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of sewers, water distribution lines and other improvements and of streets and other public areas; 
S.  Proper form for the approval by the city planning commission and for acceptance of plat and amendment of master street plan by the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.090 - Final plat-Submission requirements. 
    The subdivider shall apply on appropriate forms to the city planning commission for approval of the final plat, if he/she holds a valid approval of the preliminary plat. 
A.  The subdivider shall submit the final plat plan in two plastic or cloth tracings and five prints to the city engineer at least two weeks before the regularly-scheduled meeting of the city planning commission. 
B.  The final plat shall comply with all provisions of these regulations and conditions and requirements set forth as a part of review and approval of the preliminary plat. All filing fees shall be paid to the city at the time of filing the final plat for approval in accordance with the provisions of Section 16.36.010. 
C.  The city engineer may require the subdivider to submit detailed drawings for grading of the lots, blocks, streets, detailed drawings for pavement, curb, gutter and sidewalk, drawings for installation of water, sanitary and storm sewer facilities. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.100 - Final plat-Review process. 
A.  The city engineer shall review the final plat with other city agencies and other agencies including the county health officer, school district and the utility companies as prescribed in Section 16.16.050 of these regulations. 
B.  If the city engineer finds the final plat in conformance with the requirements stipulated for approval of the preliminary plat, he/she shall submit the final plat to the city planning commission with the review comments of the public and private agencies. The city engineer shall review the detailed drawings and specifications for the required improvements. 
C.  For subdivisions outside of the city corporate limits, a print of the final plat shall be submitted to the Ramsey County planning commission. The approval of the county planning commission is necessary for all plats outside of the city. 
D.  Upon receipt of the final plat by the city engineer, the secretary of the city planning commission shall give notice of public hearing on the proposed subdivision by date, time and place of hearing, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least five days prior to the date of hearing. 
E.  The subdivider shall furnish the name and address of the owner of the land, or his/her agent, at the time of application, who should be notified of the public hearing, date, time and place by registered mail at least five days before the hearing. 
F.  The city engineer shall prepare an estimate of the cost of providing the required improvements based on the city design standards for street, curb, gutter, sidewalk, sanitary sewer, storm sewer and water lines. The city engineer shall make a determination for adequacy of posted deposit or surety bond for the required improvements. 
G.  The city planning commission after the public hearing shall determine that: 
1.  The requirements of these regulations for preparation of a plat have been met; 
2.  The necessary fees have been collected or paid; 
3.  All taxes and assessments on the property have been paid, evidenced by a certificate or receipt; 
4.  Detailed design and specifications for improvements have been approved by the city engineer; 
5.  Other requirements by the city planning commission have been met. 
H.  If all conditions and requirements have been met, the city planning commission shall approve the final plat by entering the signature of the secretary and chairman of the city planning commission on the original. The city planning commission shall act on the request for approval of the final plat within thirty days. Failure to act within such period shall be deemed as approval of the subdivision if an extension of time is not negotiated. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.110 - Amendment of comprehensive plan. 
    Upon final approval of a subdivision involving the creation of new streets, the widening, decreasing or vacation of existing streets or alleys, or the creation, enlargement or decrease of other lands devoted to public use, the city planning commission shall at the time and without further public hearing, approve such change in streets, alleys or public lands as an amendment to the comprehensive plan. The city planning commission shall transmit notice of such action to the board of city commissioners together with appropriate recommendations concerning the acceptance of the dedicated streets and alleys or the vacation thereof, and of the acceptance of other dedicated lands. In the case of streets, alleys and public lands outside of the city corporate limits, notice of action of the city planning commission and appropriate recommendations shall be forwarded to the board of county commissioners. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.16.120 - Filing of subdivision plat. 
    The subdivider, upon approval of the final plat, shall file the plat with the Register of Deeds of Ramsey County. Sale of any lot prior to filing of the final plat is in violation of these regulations. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.20 - DESIGN STANDARDS 
Sections: 

16.20.010 - Conformance with provisions required. 
    The subdivider shall prepare the preliminary and final plat in conformance with the standard set forth herein. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.020 - Street design. 
A.  The arrangement, character, classification, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the comprehensive plan and shall be designed in relation to existing and planned streets, topographic conditions, existing natural features, public convenience and safety and the proposed uses of land served by such streets and to the most advantageous development of adjoining uses. 
B.  Where it is not shown on the comprehensive plan, the arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing collector or arterial streets in surrounding areas or conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved by the city planning commission to meet a particular situation where topographic or other physical conditions make conformance to the existing street pattern impractical. 
C.  Local streets shall be laid out so as to discourage through traffic. 
D.  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street or highway, the city planning commission may require service streets, reverse frontage lots with screen planting in a reservation strip along the rear property line, deep lots with rear service alleys abutting the primary street or highway, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and for separation of through and local traffic. 
E.  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the city planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of the right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land. Such distances shall be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
F.  Reserve strips in private ownership controlling access to streets are prohibited. 
G.  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred fifty feet shall be avoided. 
H.  A tangent at least one hundred feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major and collector streets. 
I.  When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure a sight distance of not less than four hundred feet for local and collector streets, and of such greater radii as the city planning commission shall determine for special cases. 
J.  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at less than eighty degrees. 
K.  Curb radii on all block corners shall be ten feet and a five-foot radius shall be used at intersections of streets and alleys. 
L.  Urban street rights-of-way shall be as shown on the comprehensive plan, where not shown on the plan, shall be not less than the following: 
1.  Primary arterial streets, one hundred feet; 
2.  Secondary arterial streets, one hundred feet; 
3.  Collector streets, eighty feet; 
4.  Local streets, sixty feet; 
5.  Cul-de-sac, one hundred ten feet in diameter for a turnaround; 
6.  Alleys, residential district, sixteen feet; 
7.  Sidewalks, four feet; 
8.  Graded widths of rural roadways shall be as shown on the comprehensive plan but shall be not less than the following: 
a.  Primary arterial streets, forty-eight feet, 
b.  Secondary arterial streets, forty-four feet, 
c.  Collector streets, forty feet, 
d.  Local streets, thirty-two feet, 
e.  Cul-de-sac, eighty-five feet in diameter for a turnaround, 
f.  Alleys, sixteen feet, 
g.  Sidewalks, four feet. 
M.  Half streets are prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision and in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the city planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever an existing half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
N.  Cul-de-sacs shall not be longer than five hundred feet. 
O.  General considerations for intersection design are that: 
1.  Intersections of more than two streets at a point shall not be permitted. 
2.  Alleys shall be discouraged in residential districts but may be provided in commercial and industrial districts. 
P.  Dead-end streets without a suitable turnaround are prohibited. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.030 - Block design. 
    The length, width and shape of blocks shall be suited to the planned use of land, zoning requirements, needs for convenient access, control of safety of street traffic, and the topographic conditions. 
A.  Residential block length shall not exceed nine hundred feet. The length of blocks is considered to be the distance from one street centerline to opposite street centerline and is measured through adjacent back lot lines or through the center of the block. 
B.  Pedestrian crosswalks not less than ten feet wide may be required in blocks longer than six hundred feet where the crosswalks are deemed by the city planning commission to be essential to provide circulation, or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation or other community facilities. 
C.  The width of the blocks shall generally be sufficient to allow two tiers of lots and shall be at least two hundred feet wide. 
D.  Blocks intended for commercial and industrial use shall be specifically designated for such purposes with adequate space set aside for off-street parking and delivery facilities. The city planning commission may require service drives or frontage roads along arterial and collector streets for commerce and industry. 
E.  Where frontage is on an arterial street, the long dimension of the block should front it. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.040 - Lot design. 
A.  The shape, size and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision. The lots should be designed to provide an aesthetically pleasing building site. For residential low density a north-south lot orientation is encouraged. Residential lot dimension within the city corporate limits shall be: 
1.  Minimum width at building line, fifty feet; 
2.  Minimum depth, one hundred feet; 
3.  Minimum lot area, seven thousand square feet. 
For nonresidential lots, the provisions of appropriate zoning districts stipulated in Title 17 of this code shall apply. 
B.  Residential lot dimensions within the extraterritorial planning area shall be: 
1.  Minimum width at building line, one hundred feet; 
2.  Minimum depth, two hundred feet; 
3.  Minimum lot area, twenty thousand square feet. 
C.  Residential lots abutting arterial and collector streets shall have extra depth of at least twenty feet to allow for proper setbacks. 
D.  All lots shall front a public street. 
E.  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles. 
F.  Residential corner lots shall have an extra width of ten feet to permit adequate building setbacks from the side streets. 
G.  In case a parcel is subdivided into smaller parcels, such parcels shall be arranged as to allow the resubdivision of any such parcels into normal lots in accordance with these regulations. 
H.  Lot lines shall follow the city corporate limits. 
I.  Double frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of development from arterial streets. 
J.  Depth and width of lots reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial uses shall be adequate to provide for off-street parking and service facilities required by the type of use and development and the provisions of the appropriate zoning district. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.050 - Street names. 
A.  The city planning commission may disapprove the name of any street shown on the plat which has already been used elsewhere in the area, or because of similarity that may cause confusion. 
B.  Where a street maintains the same general direction, except for curvilinear changes for a short distance, the same name shall continue for the entire length of the street. 
C.  A name assigned to a street, which is not presently a through street, shall be continued for the separate part of a through street. 
D.  Street designation shall be limited to the following conditions: 
1.  Boulevard, meaning a divided pavement; 
2.  Circle or court, meaning a cul-de-sac or circle; 
3.  Drive, meaning a through street; 
4.  Lane, meaning a street one block long. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.060 - Utility easements. 
A.  Easements across lots or along rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least five feet wide on each side of the lot line and shall be designated as "utility easements." 
B.  All lots shall be served by underground electric, cable television and telephone lines unless waived by the city planning commission due to topographic conditions or excessive costs. 
C.  All utility lines for electric power, cable television and telephone service carried overhead shall be placed in utility easement. 
D.  Utility lines installed in the utility easement shall not be closer than one foot to the property line or three feet to any monument. The utility easement grade shall be set by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.070 - Grading and drainage. 
A.  When required, the subdivider shall provide a detailed grading and drainage plan showing the grades of streets and drainage improvements. 
B.  The drainage shall not discharge into any sanitary sewer facility. 
C.  When required, the subdivider shall provide suitable drainage facilities for any surface run-off affecting the subdivision. The drainage facilities shall be located in street right-of-way or in drainage easements. 
D.  The grading and drainage system shall be approved by the city engineer. 
E.  Grading established in any subdivision shall not be changed without approval of the city engineer. 
F.  Street grades, wherever feasible, shall not exceed the following, with due allowance for reasonable vertical curves: 
1.  Arterial streets (primary and secondary), four percent; 
2.  Collector streets, five percent; 
3.  Local streets, six percent. 
G.  No street grade shall be less than one-half of one percent. 
H.  Flat grades are preferred extending fifty to one hundred feet from an intersection, but in no case shall grades exceed four percent for a distance of at least fifty feet from an intersection. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.080 - Drainage way easement. 
    Where a subdivision is traversed by a water course or drainage way an adequate drainage way easement shall be provided. The location, width, alignment and grading of such easement shall be set by the city engineer to accommodate the anticipated discharge from the property being subdivided and also the anticipated run-off from the adjoining properties. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.090 - Public use dedication. 
A.  Where a park, playground, school or other site for public use shown on the comprehensive plan is located in whole or in part in the applicant's subdivision, the city planning commission may require the dedication or reservation of such area within the subdivision. 
B.  Where deemed essential by the city planning commission upon consideration of the type of development proposed in the subdivision, and especially in large-scale developments not anticipated in the comprehensive plan, the city planning commission may request the dedication or reservation of such other areas or sites of a character, extent or location suitable to the needs created by the development for schools, parks and other neighborhood facilities. 
C.  When required, all subdivisions shall be assessed an equitable amount in dollars and/or land to implement the public sites and open space segments of the comprehensive plan. The form and amount of assessment shall be fixed by the city planning commission at the meeting when the preliminary plat is reviewed. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.100 - Tree planting. 
    The planting of trees of an appropriate species and at appropriate locations may be required by the city planning commission in accordance with the standards established by the shade tree committee master plan. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.20.110 - Street lights. 
    Street lights and their location shall be in accordance with the minimum design standards established by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.24 - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

16.24.010 - Generally. 
    Before installation of improve-ments in any subdivision, the city engineer shall make a determination for improvements required, based on a schedule of improvements including the standards, and class of construction. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.020 - Completion assurance. 
    To cover the cost of improvements, as determined by the city engineer, the subdivider may either provide a certified check for twenty-five percent of the cost or post a bond or submit a letter of credit from an acceptable financial institution in an amount sufficient to construct such improvements. The form and surety of the bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.030 - Survey monuments. 
    The subdivider shall install survey monuments in all lots and block corners in the subdivision in accordance with the requirements of the city and state of North Dakota. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.040 - Public water. 
A.  Water mains shall be installed so as to provide individual service to each lot within the subdivision. 
B.  Water mains shall extend to the boundary of the subdivision, except where in the opinion of the city engineer, it is deemed impractical. 
C.  A rural water supply shall comply with the requirements of Ramsey County and state of North Dakota. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.050 - Sanitary sewer. 
A.  All subdivisions shall be provided with sanitary sewers to each lot. 
B.  Sanitary sewer shall be extended to the boundary of the subdivision, except where in the opinion of the city engineer it is deemed impractical. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.060 - Storm sewer. 
    The storm sewer drainage facilities shall be installed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.070 - Grading and surfacing. 
    The full width of all rights-of-way shall be graded and all streets shall be paved in accordance with the city street classification and pavement standards. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.080 - Curbs, gutters and sidewalks. 
    Concrete curbs and gutters shall be installed in all subdivisions in accordance with the city standards. Where the city requires construction of a sidewalk, it shall be in accordance with the design standards established by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.090 - Installation of improvements. 
A.  Construction of all improvements is contingent on approval by the city engineer. The subdivider shall be responsible for furnishing the necessary data required for such approval. 
B.  At the time the plans, profiles and specifications are submitted for review, the city engineer shall prepare an estimate for cost for all improvement. All work done by the city engineer in connection with checking, computing and review of plans for improvement and in connection with field inspection of the construction thereof shall be charged to the deposit. If, during the progress of the work, it appears that the cost will exceed the amount so deposited, the city engineer shall notify the subdivider of this fact and shall do no further work in connection with the review of field inspection until the subdivider has deposited the additional amount of money necessary to cover the cost of the work. 
C.  Upon completion of the work of checking plans and inspecting the construction of improvements, the city engineer shall forward to the city auditor a statement of the amount of the engineering and inspection costs to be charged against the deposit made by the subdivider. The city auditor shall thereupon refund to the subdivider any unexpected balance of the deposit. If the engineering and inspection charges shall for any reason exceed the amount of the deposit, the city auditor shall collect the balance due and issue a statement that the charges have been paid. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.24.100 - Certification of final approval. 
    At the time of filing an application for installation of improvements, the subdivider shall submit: 
A.  A certificate signed by the city engineer that plans, specifications and profiles for the improvements have been filed with and approved by him/her. 
B.  A certificate signed by the city auditor that a certified check, or satisfactory surety bond, or a letter of credit from an acceptable financial institution has been posted for completion of improvements. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.28 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

16.28.010 - Organization. 
    Administration of these regulations is vested in three offices of the city: 
A.  The office of the code administrator; 
B.  The office of the city engineer; 
C.  The city planning commission. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.28.020 - Office of the code administrator. 
    The code administrator is a duly appointed city official authorized by the board of city commissioners and is responsible to administer zoning regulations, subdivision regulations, building code and housing code and to assist and make recommendations to the city planning commission and to the board of city commissioners on any matter to planning for and development of the city. 
A.  Duties and Responsibilities. The code administrator shall be specifically responsible for interpretation and enforcement of these regulations including assisting the city engineer in facilitating the review and approval of the plat. 
1.  Receive, file and forward to the city planning commission all applications for preliminary and final plats and the supporting documents; 
2.  Forward all recommendations of the city plan-ning commission to the board of city commissioners for final action; 
3.  Notify in writing the property owner or user upon finding violation of these regulations and cite the nature of violation clearly and require compliance within a reasonable time. If the notification is not replied to or steps are not taken to correct the violations within thirty days, the code administrator shall make a report of the findings to the city attorney, and the board of city commissioners. 
B.  Interpretation of regulations. All questions of interpretation of these regulations shall be first presented to the code administrator and that such questions shall be presented to the city planning commission only on appeal from the decision of the code administrator and that the recourse from the city planning commission shall be made to the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.28.030 - Office of the city engineer. 
    The city engineer is a duly appointed city official authorized by the board of city commissioners and is responsible for review and coordination of the review and approval process for the preliminary and final plats. 
    Duties and Responsibilities. The city engineer shall be specifically responsible for the design of engineering standards for the city improvement programs and coordination with the code administrator to assure compliance. 
A.  Review the plans and specifications provided by the subdivider and make recommendations to the city planning commission; 
B.  Coordinate the review process of the preliminary and final plats among the city, county, state agencies and utility companies; 
C.  Prepare cost estimate for all improvement and coordinate the financing mechanism with the city auditor; 
D.  Design and prepare the appropriate utility plans for improvements of the subdivisions the cost of which shall be born by the subdivider; 
E.  Conduct inspection of the subdivision to assure compliance with the terms and conditions of subdivision approval. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
16.28.040 - The city planning commission authority. 
    The city planning commission, a citizen body, nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the board of city commissioners, is vested with authority and jurisdiction to review planning, annexation, zoning, subdivision plat approval and city development matters and make recommendation to the board of city commissioners. 
A.  The city planning commission shall consist of no more than ten members, with two members who reside outside of the city corporate limits but within the extraterritorial zoning area and to be appointed by the Ramsey County board of commissioners. Five citizen members are nominated by the mayor and approved by the board of city commissioners. The other three voting members shall consist of the mayor, city attorney and the city engineer. 
(Chapter 2.24.020 of Devils Lake Municipal Code) 
    The term of office for members representing the city shall be three years and overlapping which may be reviewed by the board of city commissioners. The term of office for members appointed by the county: one shall be for five years and one for three years. 
B.  Duties and Responsibilities. 
1.  To hear, review and act on all applications for preliminary and final plats of subdivisions; 
2.  To hear and act on all other matters referred to by the board of city commissioners; 
3.  To study, examine and make recommendations to the board of city commissioners regarding comprehensive planning for the future development of Devils Lake; 
4.  To hear and decide all appeals forwarded by the code administrator related to the subdivision regulations. 
C.  Officers. The city planning commission shall elect its own officers according to its by-laws and may establish rules and procedures for all cases before it. The code administrator may serve as nonvoting secretary. 
D.  Notice of Hearings. The city planning commission shall fix a reasonable date for hearing of applications for preliminary and final plats and other matters before it, and give public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least one week prior to the hearing. The notices shall state the purpose of the hearing and that the applications and supporting documents for preliminary and final plats are available for public inspection in the office of the city engineer during the normal working hours. 
E.  Meetings. Meetings of the city planning commission shall be held at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the city planning commission may determine. All meetings shall be open to the public and any person may testify for or against an application for preliminary or final plat approval. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.32 - VARIANCES 
Sections: 

16.32.010 - Procedure. 
A.  Upon application by the subdivider, and where it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of these regulations would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography, or other such conditions, thus retarding the achievement of the objective of these regulations, the city planning commission may vary, modify or waive requirements so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided, that the variance, modification or waiver will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of these regulations or of the comprehensive plan. 
B.  In no case shall any variance, modification or waiver be more than a minimum of the requirements, and in no case shall it have the effect of reducing the traffic capacity of any major or secondary streets, and in no case shall it be in conflict with existing zoning regulations. 
C.  In granting variances, modifications or waivers, the city planning commission may require any condition that will secure substantially the objectives of these regulations and the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.36 - FEES 
Sections: 

16.36.010 - Fees. 
    In order to cover the costs of advertising, holding public hearings and other expenses incidental to the review and approval of a subdivision, the subdivider shall pay a fee at the time of application for tentative approval of a preliminary plat. The fee will be based upon the square footage of the land to be subdivided. If the subdivider fails to submit a final plat within twelve months after receiving tentative approval of a preliminary plat, it may be necessary to resubmit a preliminary plat for approval. 
A.  The fees for approval of a subdivision shall be charged and collected as established by resolution of the board of city commissioners, and revised as it may see fit. 
B.  All fees collected for the approval of subdivision shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
C.  All fees established by this chapter are in addition to any sums paid to cover the costs of review of improvement plans and field inspection of construction required under the provisions of these regulations. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 16.40 - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES 
Sections: 

16.40.010 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any owner, or the agent of any owner or land located within the territory of a subdivision that is subject to the approval of the city planning commission, who transfers, sells, agrees to sell or negotiates to sell any land by reference to or exhibition of a plat of a subdivision, or by any use thereof, before the plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded as approved in the office of the county register of deeds, shall forfeit and pay a penalty of one hundred dollars for each lot or parcel transferred or sold or agreed or negotiated to be sold. The description of the lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling of transferring shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties or from the remedies provided in this chapter. The governing jurisdiction may enjoin the transfer, sale or agreement by an action for injunction, or it may recover the penalty by civil action. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Title 17 - ZONING* 
Chapter 17.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

17.04.010 - Title for citation. 
    These regulations shall be known, cited and referred to as the Devils Lake zoning regulations. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.020 - Purpose and intent. 
A.  To promote public health, safety, morals, comfort, convenience, prosperity and general welfare of the city and environs; 
B.  To lessen congestion in the streets; 
C.  To secure safety from fire, panic, noxious fumes and other dangers; 
D.  To promote adequate light, air, privacy and convenience of access to property; 
E.  To prevent the overcrowding of land; 
F.  To avoid undue concentration of population; 
G.  To facilitate the adequate provisions of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public facilities; 
H.  To promote orderly development of land and water resources and to prevent conflict among land uses and structures. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.030 - Adoption authority. 
    These regulations are adopted under the authority granted by Chapter 40-47 of the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.040 - Jurisdiction. 
    These regulations shall apply to the use and enjoyment of all lands within the city and two miles outside of the corporate limits of the city as provided by Chapter 40-47 of the North Dakota Century Code. The city zoning regulations apply to not only all property within the corporate limits of the city, but shall extend a distance of two miles from the corporate limits of the city, as provided in North Dakota Century Code Section 40-47-01.1 as amended. 
(Ord. 819, 1998: Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.050 - Interpretation of provisions. 
    These regulations shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted for promotion of purposes cited in Section 17.04.020. Whenever the requirements of these regulations are at variance with the requirements of other lawfully adopted rules, regulations, ordinances, deed restrictions or covenants, the most restrictive shall govern unless otherwise specifically stated. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.060 - Severability. 
    If any part, provision or portion of these regulations is adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this title shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.070 - Comprehensive plan-Objectives. 
    These regulations are administered and enforced to implement the comprehensive plan of the city, a document adopted by the board of city commissioners as a guide for the physical development of the city including the following objectives: 
A.  To conserve and enhance the taxable value of land and buildings in the city and environ; 
B.  To encourage the most appropriate use of land in the city and environ; 
C.  To preserve and increase the amenities of the city and environ; 
D.  To protect residential, commercial and manufacturing areas alike from harmful encroachment by incompatible uses; 
E.  To protect the character and maintain the stability of residential, commercial and industrial areas and to promote orderly development of such areas; 
F.  To regulate and restrict the location and intensity of use of buildings and land for residential, commercial, industrial and other uses; 
G.  To separate and control unavoidable nuisance producing uses to minimize the adverse impacts on the surrounding areas or uses; 
H.  To minimize the expenditure of public funds through selecting cost-effective alternatives for expansion of the city services; 
I.  To minimize business interruption; 
J.  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water mains, sewer mains and streets. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.04.080 - Effective date. 
    These regulations shall be effective upon adoption by the Board of City Commissioners as provided by the North Dakota Century Code. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 17.08 - RULES AND DEFINITIONS 

17.08.010 - Rules of construction. 
    In construction of these regulations, the rules and definitions contained in this chapter shall be observed and applied except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
A.  Words used in present tense shall include the future. 
B.  Words used in singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural the singular. 
C.  Shall is a mandatory word and not discretionary. 
D.  May is a permissive word. 
(Ord. 788 (part), 1994) 
17.08.020 - Definitions. 
    "Accessory building and uses" means a subordinate building or portion of the main building the use of which is clearly incidental to and serves exclusively the principal building or principal use. The accessory building or use shall be located on the same zoning lot and it is established to contribute to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the principal building or principal use. 
    "Accessory dwelling unit" means an auxiliary or subordinate dwelling unit on the same lot/parcel or within an existing detached single family structure. The unit includes its own independent living provisions for sleeping, cooking, and sanitation, designed for residential occupancy independent of the primary dwelling unit. 
    "Airport" means any area designated for the landing and take-off of aircraft and any appurtenant areas which are used or intended for use for airport buildings and structures including runways, taxi ways, aircraft storage and tie down areas, hangars and other related facilities and open spaces. 
    "Alley" means a public right-of-way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Animal confinement operation" means an agricultural operation in which all animals are kept and raised within a completely enclosed structure. 
    "Animal rescue operation" means any facility used to house and distribute for adoption as pets any stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted animals, operated or maintained by a public body, an established humane society, animal welfare society, society for the prevention of cruelty to animals or other nonprofit organizations, or by a person or persons devoted to the welfare, protection and humane treatment of animals. 
    "Apartment" means a room or suite of rooms in a multiple-family dwelling used or designed for human occupancy. 
    "Basement" means a story partly underground with more than one-half of its height below grade. A basement is not included in computing the number of stories for the purpose of measuring the building height unless more than one-half of its height is above grade. 
    "Bed and breakfast" means any place of temporary lodging that provides more than four rooms for rent and is the owners' personal residence. 
    "Board of adjustment" means the body appointed by the board of city commissioners to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged errors or inequities in the literal administration or enforcement of these regulations exist. 
    "Boarding house" means any dwelling in which unrelated persons are housed for rent with or without meals. 
    "Building" means any structure designed or intended for shelter, housing, business, office, and accommodation of persons, animals, chattels or property. 
    "Building area" means that portion of the zoning lot that can be occupied by the principal use, excluding the front, rear and side yards. 
    "Building height" means vertical distance from the grade to the highest point to the roof. 
    "Building line" means a line establishing the minimum distance that structure may be placed from the lot lines or street right-of-way. For the purposes of these regulations the building line is the same as setback line. 
    Building, Principal. "Principal building" means a building in which the principal use of the lot is conducted including single-family and multifamily dwellings, and offices, shops, stores and other uses. 
    "Campground" means any parcel of land containing three or more lots intended for occupancy by travel trailers or tents. 
    "Central area" means that part of the city bounded by Sixth Street, Sixth Avenue and the Burlington Northern Railroad right-of-way. 
    "Channel" means a natural or manmade water course for conducting the flowing water. 
    "City planning commission" means a body of citizens appointed by the board of city commissioners under the authority of Chapter 40-47 of the North Dakota Century Code to review the planning issues, prepare plans, review the zoning requests, amendments and conditional uses and make recommendations to the city commission for final decisions. 
    "Comprehensive plan" means a guide for physical development of the city as provided by Section 17.04.070. 
    "Conditional use" means use for a special nature not automatically permitted in a zoning district and which requires review and approval of the board of city commissioners after public hearing. 
    "Conforming building or structure" means a building or structure which complies with all requirements of these regulations and other regulations adopted by the city. 
    "Development" means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but not limited to the construction of buildings, structures or accessory structures, the construction of additions or alterations to buildings or structures, ditching, lagooning, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation and drilling operations. 
    "Development plan" means a document including maps and data for physical development of an area as provided by Section 17.60.040. 
    "District" means a section or sections of the city for which regulations governing the use of building and premises, the building height, size of yards, lot area, lot width and the intensity of use are uniform. 
    "Dwelling" means any building or portion thereof, used exclusively for human habitation including single-family and multiple-family units but not including hotels or motels. 
    Dwelling, Detached. "Detached dwelling" means a single-family residential unit surrounded by open space on the same lot. 
    Dwelling, Multiple-Family. "Multiple-family dwelling" means a single building or portion thereof, containing two or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling-Single Family. "Single-family dwelling" means a building containing only one dwelling unit designed to be located on a permanent foundation as defined in this section and, if site built, constructed in accordance with the provision of the applicable city codes governing construction; or, if manufactured off-site, constructed in accordance with either the city codes governing construction or the HUD manufactured home construction and safety standards (24 CFR 3280). All single-family dwellings shall be considered and taxed as real property, as provided by law. All single-family dwellings shall have minimum overall front width of twenty-four feet, minimum overall depth of twenty feet, and minimum main floor living space square footage of nine hundred square feet, and a minimum ceiling height of seven feet. 
    Dwelling, Two-Family. "Two-family dwelling" means a building containing two dwelling units only. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms designed for occupancy for one or more persons living as a housekeeping unit. 
    "Efficiency unit" means a dwelling containing one principal room in a dwelling unit for human occupancy excluding bathroom, kitchen hallway and closets. 
    "Emergency medical air transport services" means a service in conjunction with a hospital and/or clinic used to transport patients by helicopter in need of emergency medical care at a medical facility either in Devils Lake or other medical facilities throughout the region. 
    "Encroachment" means any fill, building, structure or use including accessory uses projecting into the required yard areas or public and private property. 
    "Establishment" means a place of business for processing, production, assembly, sales, service of goods and materials. 
    "Family" means two or more persons related by blood, marriage, adoption, or child foster care occupying a dwelling unit. A family may include not more than two unrelated persons by blood, marriage, or adoption. 
    "Feed lot" means a parcel of land which contains a commercial operation for feeding and raising animals that are provided feed with little or no vegetation for forage and/or grazing. 
    "Floodplain" means an area which may be covered by flood water including but not limited to regional floods. 
    "Floor area" means the total square footage of floor space within the exterior walls of a building excluding garages and car ports. 
    "Frontage" means the front part of a lot abutting a public street. 
    Garage, Private. "Private garage" means an accessory building or portion of a principal building designed and used for the storage of not more than four vehicles owned and used by the occupant of the building to which it is accessory. 
    Garage, Public. "Public garage" means a building or portion thereof, designed and used for repair, maintenance, sale, service and storage of motor vehicles. 
    Garage, Storage. "Storage garage" means a building or portion thereof, designed and used exclusively for accommodating more than four motor vehicles. 
    "Grade" means the land elevation at the horizontal intersection of the ground and the building. 
    "Home occupation" means any occupation carried on in a dwelling unit by a member or members of the family and which meets these requirements: 
1.  The occupation is conducted within the principal building or an accessory building; such occupations operated in an accessory building shall be limited to activities that do not generate objectionable noise, dust or fumes. Operations such as body shops and auto repair shall not be permitted. All home occupancy activities shall be conducted inside the home or accessory building and all supplies and materials shall be stored indoors; 
2.  That the occupation is incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling unit; 
3.  That only the members of the immediate family residing on the premises may be employed, unless authorized by the board of adjustment by a variance; 
4.  That no stock-in-trade is kept or commodities sold other than those produced on the premises unless authorized by the board of adjustment; 
5.  That samples may be kept but not sold on the premises; 
6.  That no more than twenty-five percent of the floor area of the dwelling is devoted to such home occupation; 
7.  That no sign or display other than a name plate not more than two square feet in area shall be used outside of the premises. 
    "Hotel or motel" means a building in which lodging accommodations, with or without meals, are provided for compensation. 
    Hotel, Apartment. "Apartment hotel" means a building in which some of the accommodations are dwelling units or are occupied by permanent residents. 
    "Institution" means building or buildings occupied by a nonprofit private corporation or a public body for public use. 
    "Junk or salvage yard" means an open area where waste or scrap material, including parts of used motor vehicles, appliances and farm implements are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, baled, parked, disassembled or handled. 
    Kennel, Animal. "Animal kennel" means any premises where dogs, cats and other household pets are boarded, bred and maintained for compensation. 
    "Lodging house" means a residential building or portion thereof which accommodates three or more unrelated persons with meal privileges for compensation. 
    "Lodging room" means a room rented as a sleeping and living quarters without kitchen facilities or meals. 
    "Lot" means a piece, parcel, lot or area of land of continuous assemblage established by survey, plat or deed. 
    "Lot area" means the area within the lot lines. 
    Lot, Corner. "Corner lot" means a lot abutting two public streets at their intersection. 
    "Lot depth" means the average horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line. 
    Lot, Double Frontage. "Double frontage lot" means a lot having frontage on two separately designated streets. 
    Lot, Interior. "Interior lot" means a lot located in the interior of a block and not a corner lot. 
    "Lot lines" means the property lines bounding the lot. 
    "Lot of record" means a lot which is a part of subdivision which has been recorded in the Office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds, or a parcel of land, the deed to which has been recorded in the Office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds. 
    "Lot width" means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines of a lot, measured at the front building setback line. 
    Lot, Zoning. "Zoning lot" means a single lot, parcel, tract of land located within a single block developed or to be developed as a single unit. 
    "Manufactured home" means a factory-built structure which is to be used as a place for human habitation, which is not constructed with or equipped with a permanent hitch or other device allowing it to be moved other than to a permanent site, which does not have permanently attached to its body or frame any wheels or axles, and which bears a label certifying that it was built in compliance with the Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act 1974 (24 CFR 3280) which became effective June 15, 1976, promulgated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
    "Medical marijuana dispensary" means a facility that has been approved by the North Dakota State Health Department, as per Chapter 19-24.1 NDCC and Article 33-44 of the North Dakota Administrative Rules, to house, dispense, and sell approved marijuana products for medical purposes. 
    "Medical marijuana manufacturing" means the process of preparing legal medical marijuana products as per Chapter 19-24.1 NDCC and Article 33-44 of the North Dakota Administrative Rules, for distribution and sale at approved medical marijuana dispensaries. 
    "Mobile home" means a transportable, factory-built home, designed to be used as a year-round residential dwelling and built prior to enactment of the Federal Manufactured Home Constructed and Safety Standards Act of 1974 (24 CFR 3280), which became effective June 15, 1976. A mobile or portable structure constructed to be towable on its chassis, connected to utilities and used for year-round living. It can consist of one or more units that can be telescoped when towed, or two or more units separately towable, but designed to be joined into one integral unit. 
    "Mobile home lot" means a lot or parcel of land platted or planned to accommodate a mobile home. 
    "Mobile home park" means a parcel of land for which a detailed plan indicating the location of lots, blocks, streets, neighborhood facilities and parks and playgrounds exists. 
    "Nonconforming building" means any building which does not comply with any or all of these regulations. 
    "Nonconforming use" means any principal use of land or building which does not comply with any or all of these regulations. 
    "Nursing home or convalescent home" means a home for the aged or infirm in which unrelated persons are accommodated for compensation. 
    "Outdoor storage" means the keeping of vehicles with current license and registration, recreational vehicles, boats, ATVs, snowmobiles, trailers, equipment and storage containers for an extended period of time without usage, outside of a completely enclosed building. Storage containers shall comply with Chapter 17.78 of the zoning regulations. Outdoor storage does not pertain to the lawful display of retail goods and equipment for sale on commercially zoned properties. Outdoor storage of junk and/or rubbish shall not be allowed and shall be governed by Title 8 of the municipal code. 
    "Permanent foundation" means a foundation designed and placed in compliance with the North Dakota State Building Code as adopted by the City of Devils Lake. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership or legal entity. 
    "Planned development" means a grouping of buildings and structures on a site of five or more acres in single ownership which is not limited by the yard or building height limitations but is based on a detailed development plan and recorded in the Office of Ramsey County Register of Deeds upon approval by the board of city commissioners. 
    "Premises" means a lot together with all buildings and structures on it. 
    "Public roadway or public way" means any dedicated and recorded right-of-way including alleys, sidewalks, streets, roads or highways. 
    "Recreational vehicle" means a travel trailer. 
    "Regional flood" means a flood determined by the city, state and federal authorities which is representative of large floods known to have occurred in Ramsey County, North Dakota. 
    "Service station" means any building or premises where automotive fuels, automotive related services, lubricants, parts and supplies are made available to the motorist. 
    "Sign" means any emblem, name, identification, description or illustration which is used for outdoor advertising having permanent location on the ground or attached to or painted on a building including bulletin boards, billboards and poster boards, flags, but excluding real estate for-sale signs, political campaign signs, public information and traffic signs. 
    "Site plan" means a detailed plan for making improvements to parcel(s) of land for the purpose of building and development as provided in Section 17.32.040. 
    "Special use" means use of a special nature not automatically permitted in a district and not listed among the conditional uses. Approval of any special use requires the review and approval of the board of adjustment. 
    "Story" means that portion of a building between the surface of any floor and the surface of the next floor above it, or if there is no floor above it, then space between the floor and the ceiling above it. A basement shall be counted as a story, if more than one-half of it is above grade. 
    Story, Half. "Half story" means that part of a building between the eaves and the ridge line of pitched roofs, not for human occupancy unless approved by the board of adjustment. 
    "Street" means any public way which affords traffic circulations and a principal means of access to abutting property. 
    "Street line" means the outer boundary of any public right-of-way. 
    "Structural alterations" means any change in the supporting elements of a building including bearing walls, partitions, columns, beams, girders, roofs and exterior walls. 
    "Structure" means anything constructed or erected, the use of which require permanent location on the ground including advertising signs and billboards. 
    "Tavern" means any place in which alcoholic beverages are sold primarily for consumption on the premises, whereas a liquor store is a place where alcoholic beverages are sold exclusively for consumption off the premises. 
    "Tent" means a collapsible shelter of canvas or other fabric stretched and sustained by poles and used for camping outdoors. 
    "Travel trailer" means any portable unit designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel or recreational purposes. The term travel trailer includes the following: 
1.  An independent travel trailer, which is a travel trailer containing toilet and lavatory facilities. 
2.  A dependent travel trailer, which is a travel trailer containing either toilet or lavatory facilities or having neither facility. 
    "Used or occupied" means intended, arranged or designed to be used for occupancy. 
    "Variance" means the relaxation of the terms of the zoning regulations in relationship to building height, size of the front, rear and side yards, and use of a property, where the literal enforcement of these regulations could create unreasonable hardship, but it is not contrary to the purposes of the city comprehensive plan and these regulations. 
    "Yard" means an open space on the zoning lot which is unoccupied or unobstructed by any portion of a structure from the ground upward. 
    Yard, Front. "Front yard" means an open space extending across the front of the lot between the side lot lines and extending from the front lot line to the front of the principal building or any projection thereof.
